Shiftry.comments:
Other Options

Swords Dance variants can run Leaf Blade over Leaf Storm to have a more consistent Grass STAB move to clean, better dealing with walls such as Poliwrath and Carbink. However, Leaf Blade is worse at wallbreaking in the early- and mid-game because it lacks raw power and relies on Swords Dance.

Checks and Counters

Colbur Berry: Thanks to Colbur Berry, Uxie and Cofagrigus can stomach a boosted Knock Off from Shiftry and OHKO it back with U-turn and Body Press respectively.

Dark-resistant Pokemon: Dark-resistant foes such as Silvally-Dark, Gurdurr, and Alcremie can comfortably take Shiftry's Knock Off and OHKO Shiftry with their super effective moves. However, most of these Pokemon have to watch out for Shiftry's less spammable Leaf Storm, which can heavily damage them, and are obliterated by a boosted Solar Blade.

U-turn: Shiftry's 4x weakness to Bug makes it extremely susceptible to common U-turn users such as Silvally-Dark, Liepard, and Thwackey.

Faster Attackers: While Shiftry's Sucker Punch is very powerful and able to easily clean teams after a single Swords Dance, it is not strong enough to threaten faster Pokemon when unboosted. Therefore, faster attackers such as Silvally-Poison, Articuno, and Rotom-S can force Shiftry out.

Priority Moves: While Shiftry resists Thwackey's Grassy Glide and opposing Shiftry's Sucker Punch, it takes heavy damage from other priority moves such as Kangaskhan's Fake Out, which can pick off a very weakened Shiftry in sun. Piloswine's Ice Shard and Gurdurr's Mach Punch are noteworthy, as they need significantly less chip damage to take out Shiftry.

Mixed Attacker.description:
Shiftry is a powerful mixed attacker and stallbreaker. Sucker Punch lets Shiftry pick off faster attackers that have been weakened, such as Rotom, Manectric, and Basculin. Leaf Storm acts as a powerful special nuke, heavily damaging physical walls such as Qwilfish, Gurdurr, and Cofagrigus. Swords Dance lets Shiftry act as a late-game cleaner by empowering its Sucker Punch and also lets it wallbreak more easily with Knock Off, OHKOing Altaria that have been weakened after a Swords Dance. Defog is an alternative if the team lacks a Defogger and takes advantage of Shiftry's good matchup against common entry hazard setters such as Rhydon and Uxie.

Shiftry is a good pick for any offensive team looking for a strong wallbreaker with a great stall matchup. Qwilfish is an amazing partners that punishes U-turn with Rocky Helmet; in return, Shiftry improves the effectiveness of its Spikes by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Rapidash with Knock Off. Other physical wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Sawk, and Kangaskhan appreciate Shiftry weakening physical walls such as Tangela with the combination of Knock Off and Leaf Storm. Shiftry also appreciate VoltTurn support from users such as Basculin, Uxie, and Rotom, which can safely bring it onto the field. Faster threats that resist Sucker Punch, like Sawk and Alolan Persian, are able to consistently force out Shiftry; therefore, checks to them like Rotom-S and Poliwrath are appreciated.

Sun Sweeper.description:
Shiftry is a powerhouse in sun, outspeeding the whole unboosted metagame and most Choice Scarf users. Shiftry's deadly STAB combination lets it OHKO most Pokemon it outspeeds, and it can easily break through defensive teams after a Swords Dance or Growth. Sucker Punch lets Shiftry revenge kill faster attackers when sun is not up. Sun-boosted Heat Wave lets Shiftry OHKO strong physical walls that can take its other moves, such as Shiinotic and Tangela, as well as OHKO Abomasnow.

Shiftry is a staple on sun teams due to it raw power and lack of offensive and defensive checks under sun. Sun setters such as Uxie, Liepard, and Exeggutor make for great partners that enables Shiftry to wallbreak or sweep. The former two can even safely bring Shiftry onto the field with U-turn. Other Chlorophyll users such as Exeggutor can also take advantage of sun and form a Grass spam core with Shiftry, weakening each other's checks. Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash can also utilize sun to boost their STAB moves and weaken Shiftry's checks like opposing Fire-types, Piloswine, and Gurdurr.

Ivysaur.comments:
Other Options

Giga Drain is an alternative Grass-type STAB move that can be used when sun isn't up. It also provides recovery, making Ivysaur harder to revenge kill with the likes of Sawk and Rotom. However, Ivysaur shouldn't be used when sun isn't up and the lack of power is pretty significant, missing some crucial OHKOs after a Growth such as Kangaskhan and Silvally. Sleep Powder can take advantage of a check, but standard Ivysaur can't fit it. Ivysaur can also run an utility set with a 252 HP / 160 Def / 96 Spe EV spread and a Bold nature, which can check common threats including Rhydon, Sawk, and Tangela.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like defensive Rapidash and Ninetales avoid the OHKO from +2 Sludge Bomb and can OHKO Ivysaur back with their powerful STAB moves.

Faster Choice Scarf and Priority Users: Even with Chlorophyll, Ivysaur gets outsped by common Choice Scarf users like Manectric, which can revenge kill it with Overheat. Powerful priority users likes Kangaskhan and Shiftry can take out a weakened Ivysaur.

Sun Sweeper.description:
Ivysaur is a very threatening sweeper and wallbreaker in sun. Thanks to its great Eviolite-boosted bulk, Toxic immunity, and resistances for common attackers such as Thwackey and Sawk, it can easily find opportunities to set up with Growth in sun. The listed attacks perfectly cover the whole metagame, with Weather Ball hitting Pokemon the likes of Klinklang, Skuntank, and Articuno that can take on Ivysaur's STAB moves. Chlorophyll with a Timid nature lets Ivysaur outspeed prominent Choice Scarf users like Rotom, Sawk, and Silvally in sun.

Ivysaur only fits on dedicated sun teams, so staples of this archetype make for great partners. For example Uxie and Liepard are two amazing sun setters. Other Chlorophyll users such as Shiftry, Leafeon, and Exeggutor appreciate Ivysaur weakening their common checks like Fire-types and Altaria, as well as beating Poison-types like Skuntank and Silvally-Poison thanks to Weather Ball, in order for them to clean late-game. Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash also enjoy sun support and help Ivysaur and the other Chlorophyll users with opposing Fire-types.

Butterfree.comments:
Other Options

Tinted Lens makes Butterfree very threatening but also much less reliable. If running Tinted Lens, Bug Buzz is far better than Hurricane, as Hurricane is likely to miss without Compound Eyes. Giga Drain provides Butterfree with recovery and lets it hit Rock-types, but it doesn't deal much damage and is less useful than Hurricane and Bug Buzz.

Checks and Counters

Priority: Butterfree's low Defense stat makes it very vulnerable to being heavily damaged by incoming priority moves like Shiftry's Sucker Punch and Kangaskhan's Fake Out.

Steel- and Rock-types: Steel-types like Klinklang and Galarian Stunfisk and Rock-types such as Coalossal and Rhydon wall Butterfree's Hurricane and OHKO it. However, they struggle against Leftovers sets setting up multiple times with the combination of Substitute + Sleep Powder and being put to sleep in general.

Electric-types: Choice Scarf Electric-types like Rotom formes easily revenge kill Butterfree at +1, putting an end to its sweeping attempt. Bulkier Electric-types like Rotom-S can take care of Butterfree in a pinch, easily living a boosted hit.

Choice Scarf Users: Choice Scarf users like Sawk, Rotom, and Silvally exploit Butterfree's mediocre Speed and revenge kill it.

Quiver Dance.description:
Compound Eyes Butterfree's accurate Sleep Powder complements Quiver Dance, making it quite the offensive threat. Compound Eyes makes Sleep Powder and Hurricane far more threatening with very low chances of missing. Substitute takes advantage of Sleep Powder to provide Butterfree with an extra layer of protection, allowing it to safely use Quiver Dance multiple times. While its 4x weakness to Stealth Rock makes Heavy-Duty Boots seem better, Leftovers makes Butterfree much more consistent if your team has reliable entry hazard removal and prevention.

Butterfree is most effective late-game when a lot of the opposing team is weakened, and it can come in and set up with Quiver Dance to win. However, it is also tremendously threatening in the early-game, especially with Leftovers before Stealth Rock is up. It can set up on and beat common leads such as Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk and open the way for teammates such as Rotom and Silvally-Flying. Using Butterfree early-game lets it cripple walls with Sleep Powder. Slow wallbreakers like Flapple, Exeggutor, and Alcremie appreciate Butterfree's Sleep Powder, allowing them to safely switch in. In return, Butterfree appreciates their damage making it much easier to KO bulky Pokemon such as Clefairy and Miltank. Butterfree is very frail, and it struggles with Choice Scarf users such as Rotom, Silvally, and Sawk without a Substitute set up. It appreciates bulky teammates like Tangela, Gurdurr, and Uxie, which can come in on opposing attacks, primarily priority attacks that Butterfree is very weak to. When using Leftovers, entry hazard removers like Altaria, Coalossal, and Articuno are needed in order to make sure Butterfree can get onto the field. Entry hazards set by Pokemon like Rhydon, Qwilfish, and Miltank wear down opposing Pokemon for Butterfree, making it easier to sweep.

Raichu.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots can be used over Life Orb, trading damage output for increased longevity. This is often not worth it, however, due to Raichu being reliant on Life Orb to deal any significant damage. Air Balloon also increases longevity somewhat and gives Raichu a Ground immunity. Volt Switch can be used to retain momentum, and Rising Voltage can be used on Electric Terrain teams.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Stunfisk, Piloswine, and Rhydon can switch into Thunderbolt and prevent Raichu from sweeping when healthy. However, Piloswine drops to +2 Surf, and Rhydon is OHKOed after minimal chip damage. Alolan Dugtrio Speed ties with Raichu and can OHKO it.

Grass-types: Gourgeist formes, Thwackey, and Exeggutor resist Raichu's attacks, taking little damage from it and OHKOing back in return.

Faster Threats: Choice Scarf users such as Sawk, Rotom, and Silvally can survive hits from Raichu and revenge kill it.

Priority Users: Although somewhat uncommon, Sucker Punch from Shiftry, Skuntank, and Kangaskhan can revenge kill Raichu after chip damage. In addition, Thwackey can OHKO Raichu with Grassy Glide and tank its boosted attacks.

Nasty Plot.description:
Thanks to Raichu's great Speed and Nasty Plot, it is a niche wallbreaker and cleaner in ZU. Raichu can set up with Nasty Plot against foes like Articuno, Qwilfish, and Miltank to sweep cores such as Tangela + Rapidash + Rhydon. Focus Blast is Raichu's strongest coverage move, hitting Pokemon like Miltank, Appletun, and Tangela. Surf threatens Ground-types such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Stunfisk. Life Orb allows +2 Raichu to secure OHKOs on Tangela, Articuno, and Piloswine. Lightning Rod gives it setup opportunities against Choice-locked Rotom and Manectric.

Raichu fits best on offense and balance teams, providing revenge killing and cleaning capabilities. Raichu is also able to function on teams that lack a Ground-type, as it can absorb Volt Switch. Pokemon that struggle to break through Ground-types such as Skunktank, Rapidash, and Rotom appreciate Raichu's presence, and they apply pressure Grass-types, which trouble Raichu, in return. Raichu is vulnerable to faster threats and require switch-ins to Thwackey's Grassy Glide and Choice Scarf Sawk and Rotom. Tangela and Altaria work well to cover Sawk and Thwackey, while bulky Ground-types such as Stunfisk and Rhydon help with Rotom.

Clefairy.comments:
Other Options

Clefairy has access to a lot of other utility options including Thunder Wave, Healing Wish, Wish, and Aromatherapy. However, they are often hard to justify running due to how good the moves listed on the main set are. Clefairy can try to run a Calm Mind set, but it is usually outclassed by Alcremie, Spiritomb, and Galarian Rapidash. Physically defensive sets are also outclassed by Alcremie due to the latter's ability to absorb Knock Off and thus check more physical attackers.

Checks and Counters

Poison- and Steel-types: Attackers like Silvally-Poison, Swords Dance Qwilfish, Klinklang, and Alolan Dugtrio can easily switch into Moonblast and Toxic and threaten Clefairy with their super effective STAB moves. However, most of them hate losing their item to Knock Off.

Physical Wallbreakers: Swords Dance users like Thwackey, Silvally-Dark, and Rapidash can easily break Clefairy after a boost, whereas Choice Band users like Silvally, Gourgeist-S and Lycanroc-N can outright 2HKO Clefairy.

Item Disruption: Clefairy relies on its Eviolite to switch into strong hits from wallbreakers like Thievul, Exeggutor, and Jynx, thus it should avoid losing its item to Knock Off users like Tangela, Sawk, Gurdurr, and Liepard. Similarly, Trick users like Rotom and Jynx lure Clefairy in and can cripple it with their Choice items.

Stallbreakers: Due to Moonblast's abysmal damage output, Clefairy can struggle against stallbreakers with a way to circumvent Toxic like Galarian Rapidash, Taunt Froslass, and Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom.

Specially Defensive.description:
Clefairy is an excellent special wall in ZU due to its awesome Eviolite-boosted bulk, coveted Fairy typing, and its wonderful ability in Magic Guard. Magic Guard makes it hard to weaken Clefairy through normal means like entry hazards and Toxic. Knock Off lets it cripple its switch-ins that rely on their item to check Clefairy in the long run like Klinklang, Skuntank, and Rapidash. Toxic is Clefairy's best way to wear down opposing walls, as its Moonblast is really weak but most opposing walls are heavily threatened by Toxic and cannot threaten Clefairy back. Teleport is an option to let Clefairy act as a defensive pivot and bring a partner on the field, however it is incompatible with Knock Off and Soft-Boiled, meaning Clefairy has to rely on the Moonlight, which has more limited PP and prevents Clefairy from checking Choice Specs Abomasnow. Clefairy can also run Stealth Rock if one of its partner isn't running it.

Clefairy works best on the more defensive teams like stall and balance. Ground-types like Alolan Dugtrio, Stunfisk, and Galarian Stunfisk make for amazing partners for Clefairy; they can check Steel- and Poison-types like Klinklang and Silvally-Poison for it, run Stealth Rock which frees up one of Clefairy's moveslot for Toxic, and also bring an Electric-immunity that prevents the likes of Rotom and Manectric from freely using Volt Switch on Clefairy. In return, Clefairy can check attackers like Jynx, Thievul, and Exeggutor. Physical walls such as Tangela and Miltank help Clefairy dealing with physical attackers like Silvally, Thwackey, and Kangaskhan; Knock Off absorbers like Alcremie, Sableye, and Poliwrath are also invaluable. Fast but frail attackers like Froslass, Liepard, and Accelgor appreciate Clefairy's ability to use Teleport to bring them safely.

Ninetales.comments:
Other Options

Flamethrower is an alternative to Fire Blast that provides more accuracy and consistency, but it is significantly weaker. Substitute can be used to avoid status from foes like Pyukumku and Altaria, while Agility helps Ninetales clean better late-game; however, Ninetales generally prefers retaining Scorching Sands.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Poliwrath and Cramorant can take Energy Ball and retaliate with a powerful Water-type STAB attack. However, they have difficulty checking Ninetales after Nasty Plot. Pyukumuku is notable, as it ignores Nasty Plot with Unaware and can stall Ninetales with Toxic + Recover.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Piloswine and Rhydon can threaten Ninetales with their STAB moves, but they should be wary of Energy Ball.

Revenge Killers: Foes such as Manectric and Choice Scarf Sawk can outspeed and revenge kill Ninetales. It is also susceptible to priority from Kangaskhan, Gurdurr, and Shiftry if it is weakened.

Status: Ninetales is vulnerable to being worn down by Toxic from foes like Pyukumuku and Miltank, while Thunder Wave from Qwilfish cripples its Speed and makes it much easier to revenge kill.

Dragon-types: Altaria and Appletun resist or are immune to Ninetales's moves and can threaten it with a strong attack or status.

Nasty Plot.description:
Ninetales is a notable sweeper thanks to its access to Nasty Plot, excellent coverage options, and good Speed tier. Nasty Plot lets Ninetales break through bulky walls such as Clefairy with its powerful Fire Blast and clean weakened teams. Energy Ball targets Water-types like Poliwrath and Cramorant and Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Stunfisk. Scorching Sands is Ninetales's best move against Qwilfish and opposing Fire-types like Rapidash and Coalossal.

Ninetales fits on balance and offense teams as a mid- and late-game wallbreaker and revenge killer. Wallbreaking partners such as Rotom and Thwackey complement Ninetales; Rotom is able to threaten Water-types and safely bring in Ninetales with Volt Switch, while Thwackey is able to handle specially defensive walls like Pyukumuku and Miltank that wall Ninetales. In return, they benefit from its ability to handle Tangela. Grass-types like Tangela and Gourgeist-S are also good partners, handling problematic foes like Stunfisk and Piloswine. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie, Cofagrigus, and Qwilfish are necessary to preserve Heavy-Duty Boots and prevent Ninetales from being worn down by entry hazards; Uxie and Cofagrigus can also take on revenge killers such as Kangaskhan and Choice Scarf Sawk, while Qwilfish can provide entry hazard support to wear down foes like Piloswine and Poliwrath. Cleaners such as Calm Mind Klinklang and Alcremie can take advantage of Ninetales's wallbreaking to set up and clean late-game.

Wigglytuff.overview: Wigglytuff's poor bulk for a defensive Pokemon means it is completely unviable within SS ZU. Wigglytuff is ultimately outclassed as a defensive Fairy-type by Alcremie, outclassed as a defensive Normal-type by Miltank, and outclassed both as a special wall and as a Wish pass user by Clefairy.

WishPort.description: Wigglytuff aims to wall special attackers and pass Wish through Wish + Teleport while dissuading switch-ins with Knock Off. However, despite its access to Knock Off, its lack of meaningful bulk means it isn't worth using in this role, as more often than not Wigglytuff needs to use Wish for itself; use Clefairy if you want a Wish pass user or special wall - otherwise use Alcremie or Miltank.

Golbat.comments:
Other Options

Despite Golbat's middling Special Attack, Nasty Plot sets are plausible thanks to its great bulk and typing providing setup opportunities. It has great coverage options in Giga Drain and Heat Wave for Rock-, Steel-, and Ice-types. Defog sets also find a place in Golbat's toolkit, seeing it perform as a defensive pivot with U-turn.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Steel-type Pokemon such as Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio are immune to Toxic and resist Brave Bird, walling Golbat without Super Fang and hitting back hard with their attacks.

Electric-types: Electric-type Pokemon such as Rotom, Manectric, and Morpeko resist Brave Bird and threaten Golbat with their STAB attacks.

Rock-types: Rock-type Pokemon like Rhydon, Lycanroc-N, and Kabutops resist Brave Bird and threaten Golbat with their STAB attacks.

Ice-types: Ice-type Pokemon such as Articuno, Jynx, and Piloswine threaten Golbat with their super effective STAB attacks. Jynx, however, cannot switch into Brave Bird without the risk of being OHKOed.

Stallbreaker.description:
Thanks to its fantastic Eviolite-boosted bulk, defensive typing, and utility moves, Golbat functions as a great stallbreaker. Toxic, Taunt, and a Toxic immunity allow Golbat to easily shut down common passive walls such as Miltank and Altaria. Super Fang hits Steel-types, which are immune to Toxic, such as Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio. Brave Bird instead allows Golbat to hit Thwackey and Sawk harder, in addition to being able to KO Poison-types such as Skuntank and Silvally-Poison. The EV spread enables Golbat to outspeed Qwilfish, Cramorant, and Sawk.

Golbat is best used on stall and bulky offense teams looking for a Pokemon to help check Fighting- and Grass-types. Stealth Rock setters like Miltank, Rhydon, and Stunfisk all benefit from Golbat's presence to handle these types, with Rhydon and Stunfisk handling Electric-types and Miltank providing Heal Bell support. Late-game cleaners such as Thwackey, Sawk, and Rotom appreciate Super Fang wearing down walls. Steel-types such as Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio make great partners, covering Golbat's Rock, Psychic, and Ice weaknesses. As Golbat is reliant on Eviolite for its bulk, Pokemon that can take a Knock Off such as Gourgeist-XL and Silvally formes are appreciated. Entry hazard removers such as Articuno, Altaria, and Kabutops compensate for Eviolite barring Golbat from running Heavy-Duty Boots.

Dugtrio-Alola.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb Alolan Dugtrio can run all four attacking moves if its team already has a Stealth Rock user, or use Memento, giving a setup opportunity to a teammate. Hone Claws is another option; however, the boost is rarely enough to allow Alolan Dugtrio to break or clean. Beat Up is another option to deal better with non-Choice Scarf Rotom, but it is usually not worth using, as it doesn't target anything else.

Checks and Counters

Physically Bulky Foes: Due to its average damage output, most walls including Poliwrath, Tangela, and Throh can take Alolan Dugtrio's Earthquake at full health and threaten it with huge damage.

Faster Attackers: Due to its abysmal bulk, faster threats like Choice Scarf Sawk and Alolan Persian don't have any problems OHKOing Alolan Dugtrio.

Priority Moves: Strong priorities like Thwackey's Grassy Glide, Gurdurr's Mach Punch, and Shiftry's Sucker Punch remove Alolan Dugtrio after minimal damage.

Flying-types and Levitate: Even if they have to watch out for Stone Edge and don't check it well if poisoned, most foes with a Ground immunity like Rotom and Cramorant can force Alolan Dugtrio out. Altaria is notable for being especially hard to deal with for Toxic sets due to Natural Cure.

Bulky Attackers: Alolan Dugtrio needs significant chip damage to knock out some attackers like Silvally-Dark and Rhydon, which can easily OHKO it with their STAB moves.

SubToxic.description:
Alolan Dugtrio is one of the fastest Pokemon in ZU, which allows it to easily set up a Substitute versus frailer foes it outspeeds and forces out like Rotom-S and Clefairy without Seismic Toss. The combination of Substitute and Toxic allows Alolan Dugtrio to progressively weaken its checks like Poliwrath, Tangela, and Altaria, putting them in range of one of its STAB moves. Protect is an alternative over Iron Head; while this makes it more passive versus Ground-resistant and immune foes like Tangela and Articuno, it lets Alolan Dugtrio recover more HP from Leftovers and, in conjunction with its incredible defensive typing, set more Substitutes. Protect also lets it rack up more Toxic damage and scout for faster attackers like Choice Scarf Sawk and Basculin. Tangling Hair can reduce the Speed of a threat and potentially let a teammate outspeed and revenge kill it.

This set fits well on bulky teams looking for a reliable revenge killer, as Alolan Dugtrio can revenge kill fast threats like Silvally formes and Rapidash. In return, bulky partners like Miltank, Altaria, and Tangela can sponge hits for Alolan Dugtrio, helping it rack up Toxic damage. Defensive pivots such as Uxie, Rotom-S, and Clefairy make for particularly great partners since they can bring Alolan Dugtrio in safely, which it normally cannot do without a slow pivot due to its abysmal bulk. Physical sweepers such as Malamar, Silvally formes, and Swords Dance Qwilfish also appreciate Alolan Dugtrio weakening and crippling physical walls, opening the way for them to sweep.

Offensive Stealth Rock.description:
With its blazing Speed, Alolan Dugtrio outspeeds most Pokemon, which lets it act as a threatening fast glass cannon. Due to the number of switches it can force, Alolan Dugtrio can easily set up Stealth Rock versus threats like Klinklang, Alcremie, and Articuno. Sucker Punch lets Alolan Dugtrio revenge kill weakened foes like Thwackey and Choice Scarf Rotom. On the other hand, Stone Edge lets Alolan Dugtrio nail defensive Flying-types like Cramorant, Rotom-S, and Altaria that can handle its STAB moves. Life Orb significantly bolsters Alolan Dugtrio's power, allowing it to 2HKO Rhydon with Earthquake and OHKO Choice Scarf Rotom with Sucker Punch. Tangling Hair lets Alolan Dugtrio act as an emergency check to other fast sweepers, potentially offering a teammate a revenge kill opportunity.

Due to its average damage output and blistering Speed, Alolan Dugtrio functions as a mid- to late-game breaker, able to switch moves to remove threats. Therefore, wallbreakers that can weaken and cripple walls early-game like Black Belt Sawk, Thwackey, and Silvally formes work well. Pivots pair well with Alolan Dugtrio, providing it with much needed switch-in opportunities. Offensive pivots like Rotom and Silvally formes keep offensive momentum, whereas defensive ones such as Clefairy and Articuno are able to take hits for Alolan Dugtrio. Fighting checks like Rotom-S and Qwilfish are appreciated to switch into the likes of Sawk and Gurdurr; Qwilfish can also form a nice entry hazard core with its Spikes support, while Alolan Dugtrio provides an Electric immunity in return.

Persian-Alola.comments:
Other Options

A Nasty Plot set can be used, but Alolan Persian lacks power even at +2, has mediocre coverage, and faces heavy competition from Liepard. U-turn is an option over Parting Shot to deal more damage to Dark-types like Morpeko, Shiftry, and Silvally-Dark, but the stat drops from Parting Shot are usually much more useful to let a teammate come in safely. U-turn making contact can also expose it to Rocky Helmet, Static, and Flame Body from Qwilfish, Miltank, Stunfisk, and Rapidash.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: While they dislike Knock Off and Toxic, Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and Gurdurr easily force Alolan Persian out. Choice Scarf Sawk outspeeds non-Choice Scarf Alolan Persian and prevents it from pivoting.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types easily come into Alolan Persian's Dark-type STAB attacks and force it out. Due to Sweet Veil, Alcremie can turn non-Toxic Alolan Persian into setup fodder; Rest Alcremie can even turn Toxic Alolan Persian into setup fodder. While Clefairy hates Knock Off, Alolan Persian cannot meaningfully damage it in any way and fears heavy damage from its Moonblast.

Residual Damage: Alolan Persian's lack of recovery makes it extremely susceptible to residual damage, especially after losing its Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Special Attackers: Special attackers such as Skunktank and Ninetales easily exploit Alolan Persian's low special bulk and reliance on Foul Play.

Bulky Pivot.description:
Parting Shot in combination with Alolan Persian's fantastic Speed and good Fur Coat-boosted bulk allows it to function as an effective bulky pivot. Foul Play threatens physical attackers, notably setup sweepers such as Rapidash and Silvally-Poison. Toxic wears down Pokemon that don't fear Alolan Persian's attacks such as Alcremie and Tangela, but Taunt can be used to prevent entry hazards from setters such as Qwilfish and Uxie and disrupt recovery attempts from walls such as Miltank and Articuno. Knock Off cripples almost every switch-in, notably strong counters such as Clefairy and Gurdurr.

Alolan Persian fits best on offensive teams as a way to generate momentum and setup opportunities, although defensive teams can also make use of its pivoting capabilities. Wallbreakers and setup sweepers such as Kangaskhan and Jynx make good partners due to their ability to muscle through walls Alolan Persian struggles with such as Clefairy and Altaria; in turn it provides them with safe entry. In particular, Rotom is an especially good partner due to the duo's type synergy and effective pivoting. Entry hazard setters such as Piloswine and Qwilfish also greatly appreciate Alolan Persian's ability to safely get them on the field. Other walls such as Altaria and Tangela benefit from Alolan Persian crippling targets such as Gurdurr and Sawk, which makes checking them easier, and bringing pivot support with Parting Shot, which also weakens opposing attackers. In return, these walls make up for Alolan Persian's lack of reliable recovery and mediocre bulk.

Choice Scarf.description:
Alolan Persian is an uncommon Choice Scarf user able to outspeed some of the fastest boosted threats like Klinklang after a Shift Gear, Silvally after a Flame Charge, and Shiftry under sun. Switcheroo lets Alolan Persian debilitate a foe with its Choice item, which can be quite helpful to break through some walls like Alcremie, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath. Also, unlike many other Choice Scarf + Trick / Switcheroo users like Rotom, Gourgeist-S, and Manectric, Alolan Persian still outspeeds the entire unboosted tier besides Accelgor without its Choice Scarf, meaning it can often afford to lose the Choice Scarf. Foul Play is the main STAB move, as it doesn't rely on Alolan Persian's low Attack and lets it nail threats like Swords Dance-boosted Silvally formes and Choice Scarf Gourgeist-. Knock Off is a far weaker STAB move, but it can remove useful items like Choice Scarf from Rotom, which normally doesn't expect to get outsped by Alolan Persian and tries to chip it with Volt Switch. However, note that Knock Off has bad synergy with Switcheroo, and it shouldn't be used on checks Alolan Persian has given a Choice Scarf to. Fur Coat with maximum HP investment allows Alolan Persian to switch into physical attackers like Rapidash and Thwackey.

Choice Scarf Alolan Persian fits mostly in offensive teams looking to improve their matchup against other offensive teams. Slow and strong wallbreakers like Lycanroc-N, Jynx, and Alolan Dugtrio appreciate safely coming through Parting Shot. Other defensive pivots like Clefairy, Articuno, and Uxie also make for great partners, defensively checking Alolan Persian's checks like Fighting-types and special attackers. Offensive pivots like Thwackey, Rotom, and Silvally formes can also form VoltTurn cores with Alolan Persian to slowly chip down the opposing team. This works especially well with the support of Spikes users such as Qwilfish and Froslass.

Golduck.overview: Choice Specs Golduck is listed as unviable because it struggles to break past some of the premier special walls like Articuno, Clefairy, and Cryogonal. It is outclassed as a special wallbreaker by Jynx and Skuntank due to their access to Nasty Plot, better coverage moves, and support moves such as Lovely Kiss in Jynx's case and Taunt and Corrosive Gas in Skuntank's case to help debilitate opposing walls. Golduck being forced to rely on an inaccurate move in Hydro Pump and having no secondary STAB move to break through targets is also less than ideal.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Golduck attempts to soften up special walls with its STAB Hydro Pump, pivot with Flip Turn, and target common Water-resistant and -immune foes with coverage. Even with this, when it comes to looking for a wallbreaker, Jynx and Skuntank are better at forcing progress and breaking down special walls without team support. They are also faster, making them tougher to revenge kill.

Poliwrath.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band or Choice Scarf sets are plausible due to Poliwrath's decent Attack and Speed when invested, though Sawk does these sets better thanks to its higher Speed and Attack. A Bulk Up set makes Poliwrath a bulky sweeper, though Gurdurr does this better thanks to its access to Guts, which makes status more helpful than crippling. Poliwrath also struggles to break through common defensive Pokemon like Altaria, Tangela, and Qwilfish, even with several boosts, if lacking the proper coverage move.

Checks and Counters

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Articuno, Clefairy, and Throh can stomach any of Poliwrath's attacks with ease and heal off any damage it inflicts with their recovery moves. The former two can status it with Toxic, and all of them can attack Poliwrath without much risk.

Grass-types: Grass-types like Thwackey, Gourgeist-S, and Flapple can outspeed and deal massive damage to Poliwrath with their STAB moves, though they take a lot of damage from Choice Specs-boosted attacks. While none of them take much damage from the RestTalk set, they all hate being burned by Scald and can get worn down switching into Circle Throw.

Super Effective Coverage: Electric-types like Rotom formes and Manectric can outspeed and threaten Poliwrath with their STAB moves. Similarly, Psychic- and Fairy-types like Uxie, Alcremie, and Jynx can threaten significant damage with their STAB moves. However, all of these Pokemon cannot switch into Poliwrath themselves.

Faster Attackers: Due to Poliwrath's mediocre Speed and lack of reliable recovery, numerous faster Pokemon can easily revenge kill it, such as Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Silvally-Poison, though defensive Poliwrath can usually stomach several strong hits in the process.

Qwilfish: Qwilfish can take advantage of RestTalk Poliwrath and use its low offensive presence to freely set Spikes, and it can block Rest with Taunt. However, Choice Specs Poliwrath easily overwhelms Qwilfish.

Flying-types: Cramorant, Rotom-S, and Altaria can easily wall RestTalk Poliwrath and either threaten it with their STAB moves or cripple it with Toxic, forcing it to use Rest earlier. However, Altaria loses to Choice Specs Poliwrath, while Rotom-S lacks recovery to deal with both sets.

Choice Specs.description:
Choice Specs Poliwrath is a great wallbreaker with solid power. The STAB combination of Hydro Pump and Focus Blast offers great neutral coverage against most of the tier, exploiting teams that rely on traditional Water- and Fighting-type checks, such as Tangela and Alcremie. Ice Beam targets Grass- and Dragon-types that would otherwise switch in safely, like Altaria, Gourgeist-S, and Appletun. Vacuum Wave bypasses Poliwrath’s mediocre Speed tier and picks off weakened attackers like Thievul and Shiftry. For when Hydro Pump's power isn't needed, Scald can be used as an accurate Water-type STAB move that can also fish for burns. Toxic allows Poliwrath to wear down special walls such as Articuno and Cramorant. Water Absorb gives Poliwrath switch-in opportunities against Pokemon reliant on Water-type moves, like Qwilfish and Kabutops.

Poliwrath works well on balance and offensive teams, using its typing and power to force out defensive staples like Stunfisk, Tangela, and Miltank. However, it dislikes taking status from these Pokemon, even if it has the coverage to hit them super effectively. Besides absorbing status for it, Pokemon like Clefairy and Altaria can also provide cleric support to allow statused Poliwrath to continue wallbreaking. Poliwrath's mediocre Speed gives it trouble entering the field and attacking safely; pivoting into Pokemon like Kabutops and defensive Qwilfish can help, but VoltTurn users such as Rotom, Silvally formes, Uxie, and Clefairy can provide additional support. Physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Silvally-Dark benefit from Poliwrath targeting physical walls, which not only helps them wallbreak or clean mid- or late-game, but also invites special walls in for them to take advantage of.

RestTalk.description:
Thanks to its solid defensive stats and typing, Poliwrath is a sturdy phazer able to comfortably switch into offensive Pokemon like Rhydon, Klinklang, and Silvally-Dark. Circle Throw prevents Pokemon like non-Thunderbolt Silvally-Poison and Gurdurr from using it as setup fodder. Leftovers gives Poliwrath better overall longevity, especially since RestTalk is not a reliable form of recovery. Rocky Helmet discourages Silvally formes from pivoting with U-turn and racks up chip damage against offensive Qwilfish. Water Absorb lets it safely switch into Pokemon reliant on Water-type moves like Kabutops. The Speed EVs enable it to outspeed Jolly Rhydon.

This defensive set fits well on bulkier teams. Although Poliwrath has great bulk, Pokemon that sport type advantage can easily overpower it, such as Thwackey, Rotom formes, and Uxie. Pokemon that can cover its weaknesses, such as Altaria, Stunfisk, and Silvally-Dark, can help by switching into them. Special walls like Miltank, Clefairy, and Articuno can switch into special wallbreakers like Jynx and Rotom that Poliwrath is also vulnerable to, as well as providing additional utility—the former two can provide Stealth Rock and cleric support, which works well with Circle Throw, while the latter can clear entry hazards and pivot. In return, Poliwrath can switch into and wall physical wallbreakers like Rhydon, Rapidash, and Alolan Dugtrio.

Rapidash.comments:
Other Options

Flame Charge allows Rapidash to boost its Speed and prevents it from being revenge killed by Choice Scarf users like Sawk, Kabutops, and Rotom. However, Rapidash can't really to forgo its other moves.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Although they dislike status and specific coverage moves, Water-types like Cramorant, Qwilfish, and Poliwrath are able to handle Rapidash with their Water-type STAB attacks. They can be inconsistent in sun, however.

Rock- and Ground-types: Rock- and Ground-types like Coalossal, Piloswine, and Rhydon threaten Rapidash and force it out. However, they must be wary of coverage moves like High Horsepower and Solar Blade. They also dislike status from Toxic and Will-O-Wisp.

Dragon-types: Dragon-types like Altaria and Thick Fat Appletun shrug off Rapidash's Flare Blitz and most coverage options. Although Appletun dislikes Toxic, Altaria can shrug off status thanks to Natural Cure. They must be wary of Play Rough in sun teams, however.

Miltank: With its excellent physical bulk and Thick Fat, Miltank is able to consistently switch into Rapidash and cripple it with Toxic. Miltank can also use Heal Bell to cure Toxic spread by Rapidash.

Utility.description:
Utility Rapidash is a solid check to prominent threats in ZU such as Froslass, Thwackey, and Articuno. High Horsepower targets Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal as well as Pokemon like Ninetales and Qwilfish. Toxic places checks such as Cramorant and Pyukumuku on a timer, while Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Piloswine, and Silvally formes. Morning Sun allows Rapidash to remain healthy throughout a match to continually soft check foes. Flame Body lets Rapidash punish physical attackers like Thwackey and Klinklang.

Utility Rapidash fits on bulky offense and balance teams as a check to many of ZU's prominent offensive threats. Tangela is an amazing partner, as it covers problematic Water- and Ground-types like Poliwrath and Rhydon. In return, Rapidash is able to take on opposing Fire- and Ice-types, which give Tangela trouble. This core is often paired with special walls like Clefairy and Articuno to handle foes like special Basculin and Rotom. Ice-types like Froslass and Articuno can threaten the aforementioned Ground-types while also dealing with the problematic Altaria. Knock Off absorbers like Uxie and Qwilfish are necessary to preserve Rapidash's Heavy-Duty Boots, which is crucial to letting it consistently switch in.

Swords Dance.description:
Swords Dance Rapidash is a wallbreaker and cleaner that faces competition with Ninetales as a Fire-type setup sweeper. High Horsepower targets foes like Rhydon, Coalossal, and Qwilfish. Morning Sun provides Rapidash with reliable recovery, mitigating some of the recoil from Flare Blitz and letting it switch into foes like Articuno and Ninetales. Wild Charge handles opposing Water-types like Poliwrath and Cramorant.

Swords Dance Rapidash functions best as a mid-game wallbreaker that can also double as a late-game cleaner. Grass-types like Tangela and Thwackey can help weaken Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types like Poliwrath, Rhydon, and Piloswine; in return, they appreciate Rapidash forcing out Skuntank and Silvally-Poison and handling Tangela. Ice-types like Froslass, Articuno, and Jynx threaten Dragon- and Water-types like Altaria, Appletun, and Poliwrath. Entry hazard support from Rhydon and Qwilfish is valuable, wearing down physically bulky foes like Qwilfish and Gurdurr into KO range. Likewise, special wallbreakers like Rotom, Basculin, and Skuntank can also pressure the aforementioned physical walls.

Sun Wallbreaker.description:
With its amazing offensive stats, access to Swords Dance, and Fire typing, Rapidash is a staple of sun teams. Solar Blade is an amazing move under sun, nuking usual checks like Rhydon and Poliwrath. High Horsepower targets Fire-types like opposing Rapidash and Ninetales, as well as Qwilfish, whereas Play Rough can nail Dragon-types like Altaria and Appletun, the former being a huge threat to sun teams. Flash Fire provides a useful Fire immunity, which is a blessing for sun teams, letting Rapidash absorb sun-boosted Fire-type attacks from the likes of Ninetales and opposing Rapidash.

Sun setters like Liepard, Uxie, and Exeggutor are mandatory partners for Rapidash, allowing for a powerful sun-boosted Flare Blitz and no charge Solar Blade. Other Pokemon that can take advantage of sun like Ivysaur, Shiftry, and Leafeon also make for great partners. Rapidash handles Grass-types such as Tangela, Shiinotic, and Gourgeist formes, as well as Articuno, while they can weaken the likes of Altaria and Appletun in return.

Rapidash-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb can be run on Swords Dance sets to guarantee an OHKO on Pokemon like Clefairy, but the power boost is usually not significant and hurts Galarian Rapidash's longevity. Megahorn can surprise and KO a chipped Tangela, but sacrificing Morning Sun significantly hurts its longevity.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: Due to its poor bulk, Galarian Rapidash gets easily revenge killed by many threats including Alolan Dugtrio, Thwackey, and Froslass. Choice Scarf Pokemon like Gourgeist-Small and Rotom also revenge kill it.

Bulky Attackers: Galarian Rapidash lacks immediate power, so it can get easily overwhelmed by strong, bulky like Rhydon and Piloswine. After enough boosts, though, these Pokemon will have trouble getting past it.

Steel-type Pokemon: Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio can both dish out super effective hits onto Galarian Rapidash, with Alolan Dugtrio also being faster than it. However, they must be wary of switching into Mystical Fire or High Horsepower.

Poison-type Pokemon: Although they can't switch into a boosted High Horsepower or Stored Power, Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison can switch into Galarian Rapidash's Fairy-type attacks and threaten it out.

Dark-type Pokemon: If Rapidash isn't running a Fairy-type attack, like on some Calm Mind sets, Dark-types like Alolan Persian and Silvally-Dark can completely blank it.

Stored Power Sweeper.description:
Galarian Rapidash is a scary setup sweeper thanks to its Speed, bulk, and STAB Stored Power. It is able to consistently set up in front of passive defensive Pokemon like Miltank, Altaria, and Clefairy. It can also switch into some wallbreakers, like Sawk and Poliwrath Choice-locked into a Fighting-type attack. Dazzling Gleam gives Galarian Rapidash an option for Dark-types like Silvally-Dark, Skuntank, and Alolan Persian. It can also run Mystical Fire, which lets it directly threaten the common Klinklang while also lowering the Special Attack of switch-ins such as Alcremie and Skuntank. Morning Sun provides recovery and longevity, making it even more threatening in the late game. Its recovery also complements its immunity to Toxic thanks to Pastel Veil. Galarian Rapidash works very well with Kee Berry, letting it take physical hits more easily alongside boosting Stored Power's damage. Electric Seed immediately provides the same boost, making Galarian Rapidash a great pick on the niche Electric Terrain teams.

Bulky offense and balance teams can benefit from Galarian Rapidash's role as a bulky sweeper. Galarian Rapidash is at its best when it doesn't have to worry about being revenge killed, so defensive partners like Miltank, Tangela, and Stunfisk can soak hits from revenge killers like Froslass, Kangaskhan, and Choice Scarf Rotom. Pokemon like Alolan Dugtrio, Throh, and Ninetales check Steel- and Dark-type Pokemon that give Galarian Rapidash a hard time. Galarian Rapidash is also a staple on Electric Terrain teams, which require the use of Pincurchin. Other setup Pokemon that can sweep alongside Galarian Rapidash include Swoobat, Drifblim, Unburden Thievul, and Rising Voltage Manectric.

Swords Dance.description:
In a tier with few Fairy-types, Galarian Rapidash holds a unique niche as the fastest and physically strongest one in ZU. This gives it a distinct purpose over other wallbreakers, as its rare typing lets it take on bulky staples like Appletun and Poliwrath. Its immunity to Toxic also allows it to use status-reliant walls like Altaria and Miltank as setup fodder. Unfortunately, its few resistances and low bulk make it difficult to consistently set up Swords Dance. High Horsepower is an extremely useful coverage tool that hits Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison, as well as Fire-types like Rapidash and Coalossal. Morning Sun provides valuable recovery to preserve Galarian Rapidash's longevity, as does holding Leftovers.

Swords Dance Galarian Rapidash is typically reserved for offensive teams that value its Speed and coverage. Galarian Rapidash's low bulk and relatively few resistances make it reliant on VoltTurn support to safely threaten the opponent. As a result, it favors offensive pivots like Thwackey, Manectric, and the Silvally formes as partners, which can lure in Pokemon like Clefairy and Altaria for Galarian Rapidash. Knock Off users like Throh, Alolan Persian, and Thwackey are also very helpful for Galarian Rapidash, letting it further threaten Eviolite users like Tangela and Gurdurr. Entry hazards are another important part of wearing down foes to facilitate Galarian Rapidash's breaking ability, so threatening entry hazard setters like Rhydon and Qwilfish are essential; entry hazard setters pair well with the VoltTurn and Knock Off partners that also benefit Galarian Rapidash.

Exeggutor.comments:
Other Options

Future Sight puts pressure on Exeggutor's checks with the delayed damage, which can be taken advantage of by its teammates. Eject Pack sets make Exeggutor a one-time pivot and let it wall Gourgeist-S after use, though Exeggutor becomes much weaker without the boost from Choice Specs. Exeggutor can also be used on Sun teams as a Sunny Day setter and user, though it lacks the Speed and coverage to make full use of Chlorophyll. Harvest sets with either a Colbur Berry or Sitrus Berry give Exeggutor a cushion against Dark-type attacks or extra longevity, though they also miss out on the power of Choice Specs.

Checks and Counters

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Barring Psyshock, specially bulky Pokemon like Articuno, Type: Null, and Clefairy avoid the 2HKO from any of Exeggutor’s moves and can stall it out with their recovery and STAB moves.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can switch into a predicted Psychic-type attack and stomach at least one of Exeggutor's attacks before retaliating with their STAB moves, though none of them can switch into it safely.

Klinklang: Klinklang resists both of Exeggutor's STAB moves, can revenge kill it with Gear Grind, and can stomach at least one of its attacks. However, Klinklang doesn't appreciate switching into Exeggutor.

Faster Offensive Threats: Because Exeggutor is so slow and has a bad defensive typing, it is easily revenge killed by faster threats such as Sawk, Jynx, and Gourgeist-S, though they cannot switch into any of its attacks.

U-turn Users: Due to its 4x weakness to Bug, Exeggutor takes massive damage from U-turn users like Thwackey, Flapple, and Articuno.

Shedinja: Thanks to Wonder Guard, Shedinja completely walls Exeggutor and can freely status or attack it.

Choice Specs.description:
Thanks to its huge Special Attack, decent offensive typing, and powerful STAB moves, Exeggutor is a fearsome wallbreaker with Choice Specs. Leaf Storm massively threatens bulky and even Grass-resistant targets like Alcremie, Skuntank, and Klinklang. Psychic offers a non-drawback move against targets like Appletun, Throh, and Silvally-Poison. Psyshock targets special walls like Articuno, Clefairy, and Miltank. Giga Drain is a non-drawback Grass-type move that gives Exeggutor a form of recovery. While Chlorophyll is situational, it allows Exeggutor to outspeed Rapidash and Ninetales under sun.

Exeggutor appreciates VoltTurn support from Pokemon like Silvally formes, Rotom, and Alolan Persian, as it has difficulty switching into attacks and can only switch into weak walls like Stunfisk, defensive Poliwrath, and non-Poison Jab Qwilfish. Physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan, Sawk, and Rhydon synergize well, wearing down specially bulky Pokemon like Articuno, Altaria, and Coalossal that Exeggutor struggles with; in return, Exeggutor can take on physical walls that they struggle with, such as Qwilfish, Tangela, and defensive Poliwrath. Silvally-Fighting offensively checks to Dark-types and Klinklang and can also bring in Exeggutor against foes like Alcremie and Stunfisk. Electric- and Poison-types like Rotom, Skuntank, and Silvally-Poison greatly benefit from Exeggutor taking advantage of common Ground-types.

Marowak.overview: Even with Marowak's huge Attack stat when bolstered by Thick Club and near-unresisted coverage, Marowak is too slow and defensively vulnerable to function well as a wallbreaker. Marowak's dependence on its item makes it quite weak once it is removed, and when combined with its many weaknesses, it makes Marowak demand too much support to be a viable choice. Other Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine, while weaker, have far more bulk along with secondary typings that allow them to function more consistently as offensive tanks, and wallbreakers like Choice Band Sawk and Thwackey can perform better thanks to their far higher Speed.

Swords Dance.description: With this set, Marowak aims to be a threatening wallbreaker with its imposing Attack and coverage. However, Marowak is outclassed by wallbreakers like Choice Band Sawk and Thwackey, whose higher Speed and comparable power allow for more chances to attack, and Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine, which have more defensive utility through their secondary typings. Marowak's low Speed also makes it quite difficult to break through bulky Grass-types like Tangela and Lurantis and avoid Knock Off.

Rhydon.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb and Adamant can be used on the offensive set to break past physically defensive Tangela, as Megahorn boosted by Swords Dance has an 81.3% chance to OHKO; however, the loss of bulk causes Rhydon to fare worse against most other matchups, and Life Orb sets alone are outclassed by Lycanroc-M due to Rhydon's lack of speed. Physically defensive sets are also a viable option if a team is in desperate need of a physical wall. However, opting for Special Defense investment tends to be preferable so that Rhydon can take on neutral special attacks decently well. High Horsepower should be used over Earthquake if Rhydon is paired with Thwackey.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Tangela, Gourgeist-S, and Thwackey threaten Rhydon out, although they dislike switching into Toxic, and Tangela must be wary of offensive sets if it loses its Eviolite. Thwackey's Grassy Glide can always revenge kill Rhydon even after it has used Rock Polish.

Water-types: Poliwrath can reliably switch into Rhydon and threaten it out with its STAB moves. Other Water-types like Basculin and Cramorant easily outspeed and can OHKO Rhydon, but cannot risk switching into Rhydon's attacks. All of these Pokemon must also be wary of Toxic.

Faster Special Attackers: Due to Rhydon's common weaknesses and naturally low Special Defense, Pokemon with a high Special Attack stat such as Ninetales and Jynx can all reliably revenge kill Rhydon, although they require a free turn to safely switch in.

Passive Damage: Residual damage from status and entry hazards punishes Rhydon heavily due to its lack of recovery. Burns in particular are problematic, as they make it nearly impossible for offensive sets to wallbreak, while defensive sets cannot reliably threaten out hazard removal.

Fighting-types: Throh and Gurdurr have no issues switching into Rhydon's attacks, and Sawk can easily revenge kill Rhydon.

Stealth Rock.description:
Rhydon is one of the premier Stealth Rock users, as its solid typing allows it to easily threaten out most common hazard control foes such as Altaria, Rotom-S, and Coalossal. Rhydon can also opt for Rock Blast over Stone Edge for a move with better accuracy and the ability to break past Substitutes of Rotom, Articuno, and Uxie. Swords Dance lets Rhydon set up on passive walls and force out Altaria more reliably as it would attempt to Roost stall Rhydon after landing a Toxic. Alternatively, Roar synergizes well with Stealth Rock and phazes foes like Alcremie and Uxie, thereby preventing Rhydon from becoming setup fodder. Toxic cripples physical walls such as Tangela and Gourgeist-S that often switch into Rhydon. 84 Speed allows Rhydon to outspeed Pokemon with base 50 Speed, such as Piloswine. 16 Attack EVs and an Adamant nature greatly increase Rhydon's power while also allowing for enough Special Defense investment to reliably check Rotom and Skuntank.

Rhydon's 4x weakness to Water- and Grass-type attacks means it must rely on teammates such as Tangela, Thwackey, and Altaria to switch in to such attacks. Qwilfish can form great hazard stacking cores with Rhydon, Qwilfish also having access to Taunt to shut down Defoggers. Gourgeist also serves as a good partner for Rhydon, as it can cover for Rhydon's Fighting-type weakness, while Rhydon can switch into Fire-type attacks. Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash appreciate Rhydon's abilities to lure in Grass-types and to counter Altaria.

Swords Dance.description:
With a monstrous base 130 Attack stat and access to Swords Dance, Rhydon makes for a solid wallbreaker. The combination of Earthquake and Stone Edge covers the majority of ZU for at least neutral damage. Stealth Rock is a solid option if your team is in need of a Stealth Rock setter, while Rock Polish boosts Rhydon's Speed and turns it into a late-game win condition as well. Megahorn can also be used, as it allows Rhydon to hit Tangela, one of its most common switch-ins, for super effective damage, even threatening to OHKO Tangela after a Swords Dance boost. Megahorn also threatens the likes of Uxie, Lurantis, and Appletun.

Rhydon pairs very well with physical attackers that have access to Knock Off such as Sawk and Thwackey, as they can lure in Tangela and remove its Eviolite, so that Rhydon can threaten it with Stone Edge or Megahorn. Qwilfish makes for good partners, as it forms a solid hazard core with Rhydon, which also aids its wallbreaking attempts. Rhydon should be paired with pivots such as Rotom, Alolan Persian, and Uxie to provide safe setup opportunities. Rhydon will require teammates that can handle its 4x weakness to Grass- and Water-type attacks; some good options for this role include Altaria, Articuno, and Tangela.

Tangela.comments:
Other Options

Tangela can run an offensive spread with a Modest nature, which makes it less passive while still being able to check most physical attackers. However, Tangela's coverage is narrow and can be easily walled; it's also forced to use Synthesis more often to maintain its HP. Stun Spore is an alternative over Sleep Powder or Toxic to paralyze foes, but crippling a foe with sleep or poison is usually preferred.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Tangela has an abysmal special bulk and can be 2HKOed by almost any unresisted special attack. In particular, special attackers like Rotom-S and Skuntank have a great matchup against Tangela and can easily OHKO it.

Item Removal: Without its Eviolite, Tangela is unable to reliably counter some physical attackers like Sawk. This is troublesome, as Tangela is often the preferred switch-in for common Knock Off users such as Sawk, Shiftry, and Thwackey.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales can break through Tangela's huge physical bulk with their super effective STAB moves. However, they dislike losing their Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Ice-types: Articuno and Jynx threaten Tangela with their super effective STAB moves. They have to be wary of getting their item removed by Knock Off, though.

Physical Wall.description:
Tangela is an amazing physical wall thanks to its immense Eviolite-boosted physical bulk backed by Regenerator. This combination allows it to consistently absorb the hits of physical attackers such as Rhydon, Sawk, and Kangaskhan and regain the lost health by switching out. Giga Drain is the preferred STAB move for its additional recovery. Leaf Storm can be used instead for a powerful nuke, especially against Knock Off users like Sawk and Alolan Persian; the Special Attack drop isn't that crippling, as Tangela enjoys pivoting to regain HP with Regenerator. Knock Off lets Tangela cripple its checks such as Rapidash, Rotom-S, and Articuno. Sludge Bomb lets Tangela threaten Grass-types such as Shiftry and Flapple, which take little from Tangela's other moves and are immune to Sleep Powder and Leech Seed. Synthesis is Tangela's most reliable recovery move, letting it more comfortably check Choice Band Sawk and Kangaskhan, but Leech Seed can be used as an alternative, providing recovery to Tangela and chipping down its checks. Sleep Powder lets Tangela neutralize a foe to make pivoting easier, whereas Toxic puts walls that can otherwise take advantage of Tangela, such as Miltank and Uxie, on a timer.

Tangela is a great choice for many teams, ranging from stall to bulky offense, and it appreciates being paired with special walls such as Stunfisk, Throh, and Clefairy. Partners such as Qwilfish, Cramorant, and Altaria can handle Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales for Tangela, while it can take on the likes of Kangaskhan and Rhydon for them. Knock Off absorbers such as Silvally-Poison and Miltank are appreciated to preserve Tangela's Eviolite. Entry hazard supports from the likes of Uxie, Piloswine, and Clefairy is appreciated by Tangela, as it can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from checks like Altaria, Froslass, and Rotom-S, which are pressured by Stealth Rock without their item. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Sawk, and Jynx value Tangela's ability to sponge hits for them when they are forced out.

Kangaskhan.comments:
Other Options

Body Slam is considerably weaker than Double-Edge, but Kangaskhan can use it instead for the paralysis chance and lack of recoil. Choice Band offers more immediate power and coverage, although the lack of reliable priority limits this set's potential. Substitute is an option to takes advantage of the switches Kangaskhan forces, and Power-Up Punch is another option for Kangaskhan to become a situational setup sweeper.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Poliwrath, Tangela, and Alolan Persian are able to take hits from Kangaskhan and threaten back with Fighting-type coverage, status, or pivoting. Tanks like Rhydon and Gurdurr also pose a threat to Kangaskhan. However, those that can't directly remove Kangaskhan or pivot out such as Miltank, Altaria, and Tangela have to be warry of Whirlpool sets.

Residual Damage: Kangaskhan's Fake Out is often punished by Rocky Helmet users like Miltank and Qwilfish as well as Flame Body and Static users like Coalossal, Rapidash, and Stunfisk, even though they cannot afford to switch into Earthquake. Furthermore, Kangaskhan's entry hazard vulnerability and induced recoil from Double-Edge causes it to lose valuable chunks of HP and limits its turns on the field.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers, especially ones able to take a Sucker Punch like Gourgeist-S, Silvally-Dark, and Choice Scarf Sawk are able to force out Kangaskhan. If Kangaskhan has an Adamant nature, more attackers like Rotom-S and Cramorant may also outspeed and deal with it.

Wallbreakers: Kangaskhan's trapper set is quite passive, relying on Rest to heal and not dealing much damage, thus powerful wallbreakers like Sawk, Galarian Rapidash, and Crustle can take advantage of it.

Priority Attacker.description:
Kangaskhan is a dangerous priority attacker with wallbreaking potential when chaining together its STAB Fake Out and Double-Edge. It is thus equally prepared to check faster attackers like Manectric and Rotom and break special walls like Articuno and Clefairy. Sucker Punch combines with Fake Out for additional priority damage, and it is especially warranted to check setup sweepers like Silvally formes. Earthquake hits Steel- and Rock-types like Galarian Stunfisk, Coalossal, and Rhydon, and it avoids adverse contact effects from Rocky Helmet Qwilfish. Scrappy is essential to prevent frail Ghost-types from switching in and blocking Qwilfish's Intimidate. Silk Scarf improves Kangaskhan's main attacks. Heavy-Duty Boots instead combats Kangaskhan's residual damage vulnerability on teams with unreliable entry hazard control. A Jolly nature allows Kangaskhan to revenge kill Rotom-S and Choice Band Sawk more reliably, while Adamant picks up more KOs, like against Clefairy.

Entry hazards from Qwilfish, Coalossal, and Rhydon are invaluable to Kangaskhan, as it relies on the additional chip damage to stack with Fake Out and pressure more threats; Toxic Spikes from the first two is particularly potent. Another way to facilitate Fake Out is using defensive pivots such as Uxie and Alolan Persian; these teammates are also valuable switch-ins when Kangaskhan is targeted by Sawk, Silvally formes, and Basculin. In return, these pivots rely on Kangaskhan to break walls that they are outstalled by and to punish threats like Skuntank. Special wallbreakers like Jynx, Skuntank, and Rotom break walls like Tangela and Rhydon that Kangaskhan struggles with. Fake Out and Sucker Punch won't deal with every faster threat, so a Choice Scarf user like Sawk or Rotom should clean and revenge kill alongside Kangaskhan. Knock Off support from Clefairy, Gurdurr, and Shiftry removes Heavy-Duty Boots, Eviolite, and Leftovers from walls, making Kangaskhan more effective at wallbreaking Altaria, Tangela, and Poliwrath.

Trapper.description:
This set aims to lure in counters to Kangaskhan's offensive sets such as Tangela, Rhydon, and Miltank and trap them with Whirlpool. Seismic Toss in conjunction with the residual damage from Whirlpool and Toxic dishes out enough damage to remove these physical walls. Rest is a decent recovery move when paired with Early Bird, letting Kangaskhan recover damage taken from attackers like Alcremie and Rhydon while removing status such as Altaria and Articuno's Toxic. The given EV spread allows Kangaskhan to outspeed Modest Alcremie and Timid Exeggutor while maximizing its special bulk. Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item, since it allows Kangaskhan to bluff its offensive sets.

This set should absolutely be run in conjunction with other physical attackers for two main reasons. First, physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Silvally formes, Galarian Rapidash, and Thwackey love Kangaskhan luring in physical walls like Tangela, Rhydon, and Altaria and removing them. Second, regular Kangaskhan sets are also paired with these type of attackers in physical spam teams, and this can bait the opponent into thinking it is not the Trapper set. VoltTurn cores with the likes of Alolan Persian, Uxie, and Rotom that can bring Kangaskhan safely without revealing its EV spread by taking a hit make for great options to keep the surprise effect.

Seaking.overview: Seaking is unviable due to its middling bulk, Speed, and lacking of reliable recovery. Offensive sets are outclassed by Kabutops, which carries the same moves that Seaking does, while defensively it is outclassed by the likes of Silvally-Water, Articuno, and Clefairy.

Defensive Pivot.description: Defense pivot Seaking can help facilitate offensive threats through Flip Turn, as well as cripple opposing passive threats with Knock Off. Although it is outclassed, Lightning Rod lets it gain momentum against the likes of Rotom and Manectric. Seaking isn't worth using because its stats are too bad to properly function as both an Electric check and a defensive pivot since majority of the tier can 3HKO it and only having RestTalk is not reliable.

Jynx.comments:
Other Options

Substitute with Nasty Plot over Lovely Kiss is an option to avoid possible misses or status moves from passive Pokemon. However, it's not as powerful as putting an opposing Pokemon to sleep, and it still leaves Jynx vulnerable to Klinklang's Gear Grind. Choice Scarf can be run over Choice Specs to get surprise KOs on faster Pokemon like Morpeko and Alolan Persian, however the difference in power is noticeable, and Jynx's entry hazard weakness gives it limited opportunities to revenge kill.

Checks and Counters

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Articuno, Clefairy, and Uxie can survive hits from Jynx and threaten it with Knock Off or U-turn. However, they need to be careful of Psyshock and Trick or they can eventually get in range of a KO during the course of a game if they lack reliable recovery.

Priority Users: Kangaskhan, Thwackey, Shiftry, and Gurdurr can exploit Jynx's physical frailty to KO or heavily damage it.

Steel-types: Klinklang can switch into Jynx safely if it locks itself into either of its STAB attacks, but it must be wary of Focus Blast. Alolan Dugtrio cannot switch in directly, but is capable of revenge killing Jynx.

Faster Pokemon: Alolan Persian, Rapidash, and Morpeko outspeed Jynx and OHKO it; they can also switch in against it on a good prediction. Gourgeist-S and Manectric can always revenge kill Jynx, but they can never switch into it. Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom can always revenge kill Jynx, although Rotom can't KO it from full HP.

Choice Specs.description:
Jynx's good Speed tier and phenomenal STAB combination make it one of the most powerful special attackers in ZU. Choice Specs enables Jynx to OHKO common metagame picks like Tangela, Qwilfish, and Rotom and 2HKO Skuntank and physically defensive Alcremie. Psyshock can be used over Psychic to help against specially defensive foes such as Articuno and Cryogonal. Focus Blast can OHKO Steel-types like Klinklang while also threatening Ice-resistant foes like Piloswine and Miltank. Trick cripples special walls like Clefairy and Articuno and make them ineffective. Dry Skin gives Jynx switch-in opportunities against Water-types such as Poliwrath and Qwilfish, although it must be wary of switching into the occasional Poison Jab from the latter.

Jynx appreciates teammates such as Thwackey and Silvally-Poison, which can bring it in safely and lure foes like Qwilfish, Altaria, and Tangela for it to take advantage of. Slow bulky pivots like Clefairy and Uxie also allow it to switch in safely. Entry hazard control is key to Jynx's longevity, so Altaria, Articuno, Rotom, Morpeko, and Kabutops are good partners; most of the aforementioned Pokemon can also use a pivot move to bring Jynx in. Jynx's abysmal physical bulk and common weaknesses mean it requires bulky teammates, especially Knock Off and U-turn absorbers such as Alcremie, Clefairy, Silvally-Poison, and Tangela, to sponge physical hits.

Lovely Kiss.description:
Lovely Kiss and a good Speed tier allow Jynx to put an opposing Pokemon to sleep, possibly a defensive wall like Clefairy or Articuno that is expecting Choice Specs Jynx, in the early-game. Once its counter has been put to sleep, Jynx can threaten the rest of the team with its very good coverage. Moreover, Heavy-Duty Boots improves its longevity, allowing it to keep threatening KOs or put a foe to sleep. Nasty Plot is an option to improve Jynx's damage output, exploiting the free turns gained by putting a foe to sleep; however, it is not easy for Jynx to sweep the opposing team even with Nasty Plot, especially considering that Pokemon like Rapidash, Morpeko, and Alolan Persian can switch in on a predicted Nasty Plot and force it out.

Pivots like Thwackey, Silvally-Poison, and Alolan Persian allow Jynx to safely get on the field in a favorable position and give it opportunities to use Lovely Kiss or to fire off a strong STAB move. The same applies to bulky pivots like Clefairy and Articuno. Jynx's sleep support is beneficial for teammates like Klinklang, Alolan Dugtrio, and Rapidash, which can take advantage of the free turns and force out common sleep fodder like Clefairy or Articuno. Jynx needs teammates that cover its weaknesses and can switch into fast Dark-types, so Alcremie and Gurdurr are good partners. Defensive Pokemon like Tangela and Qwilfish stop many priority users and fast physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Rapidash.

Pinsir.overview: Pinsir is a rather poor choice in SS ZU despite its great Attack stat, good coverage, and decent Speed, mainly due to the fact that it lacks a strong STAB option to make use of the former. Pinsir has to make do with X-Scissor, a rather weak move, and as a result its power is severely undercut. It's outperformed as a physical wallbreaker by Sawk, which has a far stronger STAB move in Close Combat and similar coverage, and as a Bug-type attacker by Crustle, which has access to Shell Smash and a strong secondary STAB move.

All-out Attacker.description: This set attempts to make use of Pinsir's solid coverage to wallbreak. However, Pinsir often fails to break the walls it wants to thanks to having to rely on a rather pitiful STAB X-Scissor. Sawk is a much better wallbreaker overall due to having much more powerful STAB options, while Crustle is a better Bug-type attacker due to Shell Smash access and a strong secondary STAB move.

Ditto.comments:
Other Options

Due to Ditto only learning Transform, there are no other options for it.

Checks and Counters

Choice Scarf Users: All Choice Scarf users Speed tie a transformed Ditto; this forces an awkward situation, since Ditto will almost always have the lower HP stat.

Substitute: Ditto cannot transform into a foe behind a Substitute, making it helpless against users such as Nasty Plot Rotom formes and Klinklang.

Knock Off: Ditto usually cannot afford to lose its Choice Scarf to Knock Off users such as Sawk, Tangela, and Thwackey against offensive teams. Ditto is almost always forced to switch out on an incoming Knock Off.

Revenge Killer.description:
Thanks to its ability Imposter, Ditto serves as a niche revenge killer in ZU. Choice Scarf allows Ditto to be faster than the foe it transforms into, deterring setup sweepers such as Lunatone, Lilligant, and Rapidash due to fear of a reverse sweep. Unfortunately, Ditto struggles against most setup sweepers, particularly bulkier ones such as Alcremie, Cofagrigus, and Uxie, and other Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom are generally better revenge killers due to not having to rely on the opposing Pokemon to setup to revenge kill. Against stall teams, Ditto is an excellent switch-in to Knock Off, as it allows Ditto to have practically infinite PP and constant recovery from healing moves and Regenerator from Tangela. Due to its ability, maximizing HP is the only important part of Ditto's spread. The remaining EVs are put in Special Attack to maximize the power of Future Sight when transforming into Psychic-types like Uxie and Beheeyem.

Ditto fits on most types of teams, ranging from offensive teams looking for a solid revenge killer to stall teams that want to stop setup sweepers. Ditto can't afford to lose its Choice Scarf to Knock Off users such as Sawk, Thwackey, and Alolan Persian, so Knock Off absorbers such as Qwilfish, Silvally-Poison, and Alcremie are greatly appreciated. Ditto Speed ties with other Choice Scarf users such as Sawk, Rotom, and Gourgeist-S, so answers to them such as Tangela, Rhydon, and Miltank help mitigate those Speed ties.

Flareon.overview: Flareon is an unviable choice as a wallbreaker in SS ZU due to its poor bulk and Speed, weakness to Stealth Rock, and tendency to get chipped down by poison from Toxic Orb and recoil from Flare Blitz. Its cleric set is also bad because of similar reasons— bad bulk and Flare Blitz recoil. It is entirely outclassed by Rapidash, which is able to boost its Attack with Swords Dance, equip itself with Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid Stealth Rock, and has the bulk to be able to take attacks well.

Wallbreaker.description: Flareon attempts to act as a wallbreaker with its very high Attack stat. However, it falls very short due to its lackluster bulk and Speed, its weakness to entry hazards, the recoil from Flare Blitz, and having to run Toxic Orb to activate its Guts ability. It has horrible longevity and thus is entirely outclassed by the much faster Rapidash, which has the ability to heal itself, take hits with its solid bulk, and avoid hazards with Heavy-Duty Boots.

Kabutops.comments:
Other Options

A Swords Dance set can be used, trading Speed and utility for more wallbreaking potential. However, this set is heavily outclassed by other Swords Dance wallbreakers such as Qwilfish, Thwackey, and Silvally formes. Choice Band is also useable, although this set faces tough competition from Lycanroc-N. More immediately, these sets disregard the main reason to use Kabutops in the first place: compressing revenge killing with utility. Suicide lead sets do offer an additional niche option, as Kabutops has access to both Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin. They use Weak Armor and Focus Sash, allowing Kabutops to survive any attack whilst potentially getting a Speed boost.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Tangela and Appletun can both switch into Kabutops and OHKO it with their STAB attacks. However, they can struggle against boosted Stone Edge from the rare Swords Dance set. Thwackey can also revenge kill Kabutops thanks to its priority Grassy Glide.

Fighting-types: Sawk, Gurdurr, and Silvally-Fighting resist Stone Edge and can threaten Kabutops with their STAB attacks. Choice Scarf Sawk is faster than Kabutops, allowing it to revenge kill Kabutops reliably.

Electric-types: Choice Scarf Rotom and Manectric outspeed Kabutops and can OHKO with their STAB attacks.

Water-types: Poliwrath and Qwilfish are either immune or resistant to Kabutops's Water-type moves and Stone Edge doesn't 2HKO them. They can both have some form of recovery and can fish for Scald burns. Qwilfish can also cripple Kabutops with Thunder Wave. Poliwrath is especially notable, threatening Kabutops with its Fighting-type STAB attacks, denying its Flip Turn pivots with Water Absorb, and resisting Stone Edge.

Choice Scarf.description:
Kabutops is an effective Choice Scarf user in the ZU metagame, compressing revenge killing with utility. Flip Turn retains momentum against checks like Tangela and Appletun whilst chipping down Throh and Gurdurr. Rapid Spin can be used to make Kabutops an emergency entry hazard remover, often as a second form of hazard removal. However, it means not running Liquidation, so the weaker Flip Turn becomes Kabutops's sole Water-type attack. Knock Off cripples checks like the aforementioned Tangela, which relies on Eviolite, as well as other Pokemon such as Gurdurr, Poliwrath, and Qwillfish. Battle Armor is marginally useful, but it's preferred to Weak Armor because Kabutops is already very fast, and faster physical attackers like Choice Scarf Sawk can just OHKO it. Swift Swim lacks use with rain's non-existent presence.

Kabutops is best used as an offensive pivot, with its typing providing useful resistances in Fire, Ice, and Flying. Thus, it can switch into Pokemon such as Rapidash, Articuno, and Altaria, pivoting out on the forced switch. This pivoting benefits offensive VoltTurn users such as Thwackey, and Rotom in addition to defensive pivots such as Uxie, Rotom-S, and Articuno. Furthermore, special wallbreakers such as Jynx, Skuntank, and Thievul appreciate Kabutops luring in Pokemon such as Tangela and Qwilfish. However, Kabutops is vulnerable to priority moves and other Choice Scarf users such as Thwackey, Rotom, and Sawk. Grass-types work as defensive teammates, dealing with Grass-, Fighting-, Electric-, and Water-types that handle Kabutops.

Articuno.comments:
Other Options

Articuno can opt for a physically offensive set with options like Triple Axel, Brave Bird, and Ice Shard, but physical walls are more common, which makes special Articuno more effective at breaking through defensive cores.

Checks and Counters

Rock-type Pokemon and Coverage: Due to its 4x weakness to Rock, any Rock-type move will at least 2HKO Articuno. This makes Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal extremely annoying for Articuno, as they can easily set up entry hazards against it.

Item Removal: Retaining Heavy-Duty Boots is key to maintaining Articuno's defensive capabilities, and it should avoid switching into Knock Off and Trick users like Shiftry, Gurdurr, Thwackey, and Rotom. However, if Articuno is the team's entry hazard remover and is able to consistently use Defog against the opposing Stealth Rock setter, it can afford to lose its item.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash force out Articuno with their super effective STAB move. However, they take great damage from Articuno's Flying-type STAB moves, and they dislike being crippled by Toxic.

Electric-types: Morpeko, Manectric, and Rotom formes threaten Articuno with their super effective STAB moves and generate momentum with Volt Switch. However, weaker Electric-types like Choice Scarf Rotom and defensive Rotom-S can't break through specially defensive Articuno.

Steel-types: Klinklang, Mawile, and Pawniard are immune to Toxic, resist Articuno's STAB moves, and take on Articuno with their super effective STAB moves.

Specially Defensive.description:
Articuno is an amazing special wall and one of the best form of entry hazard control in ZU thanks to Pressure + Defog keeping entry hazards off the field against numerous setters such as Qwilfish, Uxie, and Clefairy, its amazing bulk, and reliable recovery in Roost. Freeze-Dry lets Articuno threaten entry hazard setters like Qwilfish and Stunfisk, as well as Pokemon that can freely switch into its other moves like Tangela and Altaria. Toxic wears down opposing walls such as Cramorant and entry hazard setters such as Coalossal and Rhydon, which forces Articuno out, while U-turn turns Articuno into a pivot. Articuno can also run Haze to stop Stored Power users like Alcremie and Uxie or Heal Bell to act as a cleric. The given EV spread lets Articuno outspeed Modest Abomasnow and Adamant Trevenant. Alternatively, Articuno can run 136 Speed EVs with a Jolly nature to outspeed Flapple and Adamant Shiftry.
