Specially defensive Articuno fits on almost any kind of team, ranging from stall to bulky offense. On offensive teams, it forms a VoltTurn core with partners like Silvally formes, Uxie, and Alolan Persian. Frail attackers such as Jynx and Shiftry enjoy safely coming on the field through these VoltTurn cores and benefit from slower pivots like Articuno sponging attacks for them. Knock Off absorbers like Qwilfish, Pyukumuku, and Silvally formes are great partners that can preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots and sponge physical hits, while it handles special attackers for them. Ground-types like Rhydon and Stunfisk make for excellent partners for their ability to handle Articuno's weaknesses, while they appreciate Articuno checking Jynx and Exeggutor.

SubRoost.description:
The combination of Substitute, Roost, and Pressure lets Articuno stall out moves with low PP such as Ninetales's Fire Blast, Kabutop's Stone Edge, and Gourgeist-S's Poltergeist. Thanks to its great Speed and bulk, Articuno is able to easily set up a Substitute against passive Pokemon such as Tangela, Cramorant, and Qwilfish. Toxic works well with the combination of Roost + Substitute, racking up damage on foes like Coalossal, Uxie, and Kangaskhan. Freeze-Dry is the preferred STAB move to cover Qwilfish and Altaria, which can sponge Toxic.

SubRoost Articuno fits well on balance and bulky offense teams looking for a Pokemon that does well against balance teams. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Alolan Persian are appreciated to preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots. VoltTurn users like Rotom, Manectric, and Uxie safely bring Articuno onto the field, letting it avoid Knock Off from the likes of Tangela and Uxie. Ground-types such as Alolan Dugtrio, Rhydon, and Stunfisk make for great partners, checking Steel-, Fire-, Rock-, and Ground-types such as opposing Alolan Dugtrio, Coalossal, and Rhydon. In return, Articuno checks Water- and Grass-types such as Qwilfish, Appletun, and Flapple for them. Checks to Steel-types like Sawk, Rapidash, and Manectric are especially important, since Klinklang completely shuts down SubRoost Articuno.

Roost + 3 Attacks.description:
Articuno is a great offensive pivot that is able to dish out powerful Hurricanes and Freeze-Drys. The given EV investment in conjunction with its coverage allows Articuno to outspeed and nail threats such as Thwackey, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr. Thanks to U-turn, Articuno is able to pivot from bad matchups and safely bring in partners.

Roost + 3 Attacks Articuno fits on offensive teams with VoltTurn cores, which makes Uxie, Rotom, and Alolan Persian great partners. Articuno also excels on entry hazard stacking teams, since it preys on common Defoggers such as Cramorant and Altaria and is able to generate momentum with U-turn. Physical wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Silvally formes can take advantage of Articuno inviting in and pivoting against special walls such as Coalossal, Clefairy, and Miltank. In return, Articuno can threaten physical walls such as Qwilfish, Rhydon, and Tangela for them. Ground-types like Alolan Dugtrio and Rhydon are great partners, checking Rock-, Fire-, Steel-, and Electric-types such as Coalossal, Klinklang, and Stunfisk. Knock Off absorbers like Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Qwilfish let Articuno keep its Heavy-Duty Boots.

Wobbuffet.overview: Without Shadow Tag, Wobbuffet's barren and predictable movepool makes it completely useless in ZU. Because it does not learn any attacking moves, switching prevents it from doing anything, not to mention how vulnerable it is to all residual damage. Walls like Tangela and Palossand offer way more utility with options like Sleep Powder and Stealth Rock and can actually attack the foe.

Death Fodder.description: This set aims to capitalize on Wobbuffet's bulk to retaliate against attackers like Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Choice Band Thwackey. However, Wobbuffet will be unable to do anything in a match if the opponent simply switches out. Alcremie and Stunfisk are examples of much better walls that sport better utility movepools and can actually attack the foe.

Qwilfish.comments:
Other Options

Defensive sets can opt for Destiny Bond in conjunction with 252 EV in Speed in order to get surprise KOs on slower attackers like Modest Thievul and Rotom-S. Scald can be an alternative to Qwilfish's other offensive moves for the burn chance, however it is much weaker and unable to reliably threaten Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales. Defensive Qwilfish can also run Toxic to cripple foes like Rotom and Articuno, however it is overall less effective than Taunt and Thunder Wave. Swords Dance set can run Spikes to improve the matchup against more defensive teams and take advantage of Shedinja and Pyukumuku, however Aqua Jet is generally more useful. Life Orb is also an option over Black Sludge, trading the defensive utility for some important rolls, like having a chance to OHKO Rotom after Stealth Rock with a Swords Dance-boosted Aqua Jet.

Checks and Counters

Psychic-types: Wallbreakers like Jynx and Exeggutor do not fear Qwilfish's Water-type attacks and can OHKO it with their powerful STAB moves; however, they can't switch freely into Poison Jab. Uxie takes nothing from Qwilfish's attacks and Spikes and can directly threaten it with Psychic or use Future Sight to prevent Qwilfish from checking threats like Sawk and Lycanroc-N.

Electric-types: The likes of Rotom, Rotom-S, Morpeko, and Manectric outspeed Qwilfish and can threaten it with their super effective attacks. They can even take momentum back with Volt Switch and some of them can remove Spikes with Defog or Rapid Spin. They have to be careful to not be put in range of Swords Dance boosted Aqua Jet.

Special Attackers: Qwilfish's special bulk is underwhelming, meaning that special attackers such as Thievul, Ninetales, and Articuno can easily break through it. However, they have to worry about Aqua Jet, especially after a Swords Dance.

Ground-types: Qwilfish is weak to Ground-types and cannot handle crucial physical attackers such as Rhydon and Piloswine, even if they are 2HKOed by Qwilfish's Water-type STAB moves. Qwilfish also takes heavy damage from common Ground-type coverage from wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; the latter is noteworthy due to Inner Focus ignoring Intimidate.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Even with Intimidate, Qwilfish's bulk isn't amazing and, without any reliable recovery moves, it is quickly put in range of powerful wallbreakers like Kangaskhan, Rapidash formes, and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

Stall staples While the Spikes set can easily take advantage of stall staples like Pyukumuku, the Swords Dance set is unable to break through Pyukumuku and Shedinja due to Unaware and Wonder Guard, respectively.

Defensive Spikes.description:
Qwilfish is a premier physical wall on bulky offense teams that is able to set Spikes and check powerful physical attackers such as Silvally-Dark, Rapidash, and Sawk. Liquidation is the preferred STAB move, as it prevents Ground-types like Rhydon, Alolan Dugtrio, and Piloswine from freely switch into it. Poison Jab is an alternative to hit Grass-types like Thwackey, Exeggutor, and Flapple, as well as threaten foes immune to Water like Jynx and Poliwrath and spread poison on checks like Articuno and Cramorant; however, it leaves Qwilfish more vulnerable to multiple attackers like Klinklang, Lycanroc-N, Silvally-Poison, and Rotom. Pain Split improves Qwilfish's longevity versus bulkier teams. Thanks to Taunt, Qwilfish can disrupt slower Pokemon such as Pyukumuku, Miltank, and Gurdurr and stop Defog users such as Articuno and Altaria, even though it doesn't enjoy taking their strong special STAB moves. Thunder Wave cripples faster attackers such as Gourgeist-S, Jynx, and Thievul that can otherwise freely switch into Qwilfish. Rocky Helmet lets Qwilfish wear down physical attackers, punishing resisted moves like Gurdurr's Mach Punch, Sawk's Close Combat, and Klinklang's Gear Grind. The given EV spread lets Qwilfish outspeed Adamant Lycanroc-N, Thwackey, and Shiftry and maximizes its physical bulk.

Qwilfish fits well on bulky offense teams that appreciate its defensive utility and ability to set entry hazards. Specially bulky Pokemon like Articuno, Rhydon, and Clefairy make for great partners, as they are able to handle special attackers like Jynx, Rotom, and Manectric; in return, Qwilfish handles physical attackers such as Sawk and Rapidash and absorbs Knock Off, as well as forms a nice entry hazard stack core with the latter two. Pokemon that are immune to or resist Ground such as Rotom, Uxie, and Tangela cover Qwilfish's Ground weakness. VoltTurn cores pair well with Spikes, as they force a lot of switches. Therefore, Pokemon such as Thwackey, Silvally formes, and Alolan Persian make for great partners. Spikes are appreciated by wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; Kangaskhan is a noteworthy example, as it can force switches thanks to Fake Out. Knock Off users such as Shiftry, Liepard, and Gurdurr can remove opposing Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Alolan Persian and Sableye, bolstering the effectiveness of Qwilfish's entry hazards.

Swords Dance.description:
Swords Dance turns Qwilfish into a threatening wallbreaker. Its typing is great both offensively and defensively; its STAB combination is only resisted by Shedinja and itself and hits physically defensive behemoths such as Tangela and Rhydon super effectively. Its immunity to Toxic and resistances to common attacks let it set up on defensive staples like Miltank, Clefairy, and Flamethrower Altaria. Aqua Jet is a STAB priority move that allows Qwilfish to threaten faster attackers like Rotom, Silvally-Poison, and Choice Scarf Sawk. The combination of Intimidate and Black Sludge allows Qwilfish to keep some of its defensive utility, notably against Sawk and Rapidash.

Qwilfish is best used as a cleaner on offensive teams. Other physical attackers like Swords Dance Silvally formes, Swords Dance Galarian Rapidash, and Kangaskhan can force damage on physical walls and force faster threats to take damage, hence putting them in range of Qwilfish later. Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine are great partners that can check Electric-types for Qwilfish and weaken the opposing team with Stealth Rock. Articuno and Clefairy are great special walls that can absorb hits from the likes of Thievul, Jynx, and Rotom that force Qwilfish out and pivot into Qwilfish to give it setup opportunities.

Shuckle.comments:
Other Options

Knock Off and Toxic give Shuckle additional utility and can disrupt hazard removers, though these moves are harder to fit given the utility of Encore and Final Gambit.

Checks and Counters

Entry Hazard Counterplay: Defog and Rapid Spin users like Articuno, Cramorant, Coalossal, and Morpeko can switch into Shuckle without too much trouble and remove its entry hazards, though none of them appreciate Encore. Hattrem's Magic Bounce prevents Shuckle from doing anything until it is removed from the battle. Furthermore, while Shuckle is nearly guaranteed to set up one hazard, Taunt and Encore from Pokemon like Skuntank, Froslass, Sableye, and Uxie prevent it from laying down a second one.

Strong Attackers: A lot of offensive Pokemon can 2HKO Shuckle and limit it to one entry hazard: examples include Klinklang, Rhydon, and Choice Specs Poliwrath. However, Red Card can disrupt them and can send a less powerful foe out, giving Shuckle room to get up both entry hazards.

Sticky Web Lead.description:
With unique access to both Sticky Web and Stealth Rock and greater bulk over its competition, Shuckle is a decent dedicated lead in hyper offense builds. After ideally getting up both Sticky Web and Stealth Rock, Shuckle can use Final Gambit to prevent Defog and Rapid Spin at the cost of sacrificing itself. Encore deters setup sweepers like Klinklang, Gurdurr, and Silvally formes from boosting in front of it, as well as punishing Defog and Rapid Spin attempts from Pokemon like Articuno, Coalossal, and Morpeko. Sturdy ensures Shuckle will survive at least one hit to set up a hazard. Mental Herb ensures Shuckle can set up at least one entry hazard in front of Taunt users like Froslass and Alolan Persian, while Red Card can disrupt attackers like Sawk, Rhydon, and Poliwrath seeking to limit it to one hazard, as well as setup attackers, thanks to Sturdy.

Shuckle best fits on hyper offense builds, where teammates can best capitalize on Sticky Web's Speed drop. Setup sweepers like Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Klinklang fit well with it, working together to overwhelm the opposition. Ghost-types like Rotom and Froslass can prevent Rapid Spin while maintaining pressure in their own right; the former can set up with Nasty Plot, while the latter can set Spikes while stopping Defog users with Taunt. Powerful wallbreakers like Sawk and Jynx enjoy Sticky Web and can immediately pressure the opposing team without need for setup. Offensive threats that can threaten Levitate and Defog users, like the aforementioned Rotom, Silvally-Dark, Klinklang, and Lycanroc-N, work well to maintain entry hazard pressure.

Piloswine.comments:
Other Options

Toxic allows Piloswine to wear down foes like Tangela, Poliwrath, and Pyukumuku. Rock Slide provides coverage against Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Poliwrath, Pyukumuku, and Cramorant are able to switch into Piloswine and force it out, with Cramorant also removing Stealth Rock. Although they cannot directly switch into Piloswine, offensive Water-types like Ludicolo and Carracosta can threaten to KO it.

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath pressure Piloswine immensely.

Grass-types: Even though they cannot switch into Piloswine and fear being revenge killed by Ice Shard if weakened, Shiftry and Tangela are able to threaten Piloswine. Tangela is able to tank hits from Piloswine and cripple it with Toxic and Knock Off or KO it with Leaf Storm or Giga Drain.

Residual Damage: Given Piloswine's lack of recovery, residual damage from entry hazards and status can wear it down over the course of the battle.

Stealth Rock.description:
Piloswine's typing, huge bulk, and Thick Fat let it serve as a Stealth Rock setter that has good matchups against some Stealth Rock setters such as Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk. Earthquake and Icicle Crash form a formidable STAB combination, hitting relevant targets such as Skuntank, Silvally formes, and Rotom-S. Ice Shard allows Piloswine to revenge kill weakened foes such as Shiftry and Rotom. Thick Fat lets Piloswine switch into the likes of Rapidash.

Piloswine fits best on bulky offensive teams that appreciate its ability to take hits and consistently set Stealth Rock. Water-types such as Poliwrath and Cramorant are problematic for Piloswine; checks to them such as Articuno, Thwackey, and Manectric are appreciated. Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and the aforementioned Poliwrath greatly pressure Piloswine. Partners such as Rotom-S and Qwilfish can alleviate this weakness; the former can provide VoltTurn support, while the latter can wear down problematic foes such as Tangela and Miltank with Spikes and Toxic Spikes.

Miltank.comments:
Other Options

With its great Speed tier, useable Attack stat, and decent coverage, Miltank can also run offensive sets, while keeping defensive utilities with its abilities. However, it faces heavy competition from other Normal-type wallbreakers like Silvally and Kangaskhan, and it heavily struggles due to its inability to threaten Rotom.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Thanks to their super effective STAB moves, the likes of Sawk, Poliwrath, and Throh can easily defeat Miltank. Pokemon like Abomasnow and Jynx also carry Fighting-type coverage, allowing them to break through Miltank.

Toxic: Toxic heavily cripples Miltank, tremendously limiting its ability to handle most threats in the long run. However, it can combat this weakness with Heal Bell.

Toxic Counterplay: Miltank mostly relies on Toxic to deal damage. However, Pokemon like Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom, Nasty Plot Skuntank, and Rest Alcremie can set up on Miltank without fearing Toxic much, proceeding to break through its team. Altaria and Clefairy aren't much bothered by Toxic, reliably heal off Seismic Toss damage, and take advantage of Miltank with their own status moves. Rest users like Throh can also absorb Toxic and avoid the 3HKO from Seismic Toss, threatening Miltank with their powerful moves.

Trick: Rotom, Manectric, and Jynx can cripple Miltank and limit its walling capabilities with Trick. However, the latter may struggle to switch directly in against Body Slam variants.

Mixed Wall.description:
With a mixed defensive EV spread, Miltank can take on most unboosted attackers in the tier, whether special or even physical like Rhydon lacking Swords Dance, Alolan Dugtrio, and Liepard. Seismic Toss's fixed damage is very reliable, while Body Slam, if often weaker, can spread paralysis while keeping enough power for frail attackers. Toxic lets Miltank put foes with recovery like Tangela and Articuno on a timer, allowing it to win one-on-one. Toxic can also force Pokemon like Throh and Alcremie to use Rest later on. Heal Bell is the preferred option, helping its team against bulkier teams using a lot of status moves. Heavy-Duty Boots maximizes Miltank's longevity, giving it more switch-in opportunities; however, Rocky Helmet is an option to punish physical attackers, especially U-turn users like Thwackey and Silvally formes. Thick Fat is the preferred ability, letting Miltank handle Rapidash. The given spread allows Miltank to outspeed Timid Abomasnow and avoid the 2HKO from Nasty Plot-boosted Ninetales, as well as checking physical attackers like Swords Dance Thwackey, Kangaskhan, and Silvally-Dark.

This set fits well in balance teams looking for a blanket wall. It pairs especially well with Fighting-type checks such as Alcremie, Altaria, Cramorant, and Gourgeist-S able to answer Poliwrath and Sawk. Specially defensive Ground-types such as Rhydon and Stunfisk are great to answer Rotom and Skuntank for Miltank, while Miltank takes care of Ice-types like Jynx and Abomasnow. Status absorbers like Throh and Clefairy can take on Toxic users like Altaria, Alolan Persian, and Stunfisk for Miltank.

Nascar Cow.description:
With its great bulk, even with only HP investment, and excellent Speed, outpacing major threats like Silvally formes, Sawk, and Thievul, Miltank can double up as a wall and revenge killer for bulkier teams. Seismic Toss is the prefered offensive move thanks to its fixed damage; Body Slam's paralysis chance is not very valuable due to Miltank already outspeeding most foes. Toxic puts threats with reliable recovery like Alcremie, Articuno, and Cramorant on a timer. This set can notably hit Rotom with Toxic before it sets up a Substitute. Rocky Helmet is the preferred item, as, paired with Miltank's fast Seismic Toss and Toxic damage, it enables huge damage on physical attackers. Sap Sipper turns Miltank into one of the most reliable Grass-type checks in the tier, absorbing Sleep Powder from Tangela, not carrying that much about losing its item from Thwackey's and Tangela's Knock Off, and being immune to both of Gourgeist-S's STAB moves. Thick Fat is another option, but due to this set's lack of Special Defense investment, it can't reliably switch into the likes of Jynx and Ninetales.

This fast Miltank set fits extremely well in bulkier teams with few other fast Pokemon. Its partner in crime is Stunfisk, as it can handle special attackers, especially Rotom and Skuntank, for Miltank. In return, Miltank provides Heal Bell support, helping Stunfisk combat Defoggers like Altaria, Rotom, and Articuno. It also hard walls Grass-types, which are the main counters to Stunfisk. Fighting-type checks such as Alcremie and Cramorant are also much appreciated to handle the likes of Poliwrath, Sawk, and Gurdurr. Even with Heal Bell, Miltank struggles in the long term versus Toxic, so Toxic absorbers like Klinklang, Clefairy, and Throh make for good partners.

Special Wall.description:
Specially defensive Miltank can take advantage of most special attackers like Articuno, Tangela, and Alcremie. Seismic Toss is its most consistent attack, ignoring stat boosts and bothering even defensive behemoths like Tangela and Articuno. While often weaker, Body Slam is alternative that can spread paralysis. Toxic allows Miltank to cripple foes like Stunfisk and Tangela, forcing certain walls such as Throh and Altaria to use Rest or switch out to activate Natural Cure, respectively. Thick Fat allows Miltank to take on threatening special wallbreakers like Ninetales and Abomasnow. The given EV spread lets Miltank outspeed Timid Abomasnow and Ivysaur while maximizing its special bulk.

Specially defensive Miltank is a great pick for balance teams. It has great synergy with Grass-types like Tangela and Gourgeist formes, being able to handle most of their checks, while they help with physical attackers like Thwackey and Sawk. Offensive Ground-types such as Alolan Dugtrio, Rhydon, and Piloswine help Miltank take on special attackers like Skuntank and prevent Electric-types such as Manectric and Rotom from freely pivoting. Gourgeist formes, Alcremie, and Altaria are also appreciated to answer Fighting-types like Sawk and Gurdurr, and in exchange they appreciate Miltank's Ice resistance and ability to handle special attackers. Due to Miltank's susceptibility to status, status absorbers like Altaria make for great partners.

Ludicolo.comments:
Other Options

Both sets can use Leaf Storm or Energy Ball to replace Giga Drain; however, Ludicolo does not appreciate Leaf Storm’s Special Attack drops and Energy Ball's lack of passive recovery, the latter either exacerbating Life Orb recoil or limiting Ludicolo's longevity as a tank.

Checks and Counters

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Some Pokemon such as Articuno and Type: Null can stomach a rain-boosted Hydro Pump and fire back with a super effective move like Freeze-Dry or U-turn, although neither appreciates losing its held item to Assault Vest Ludicolo.

Super Effective Attacks and Coverage: Sweeper Ludicolo's subpar defenses and base Speed leave it exposed to super effective attacks from foes such as Qwilfish and Silvally-Flying when rain is not active. Setting up Rain Dance is difficult against walls with super effective coverage like Altaria and Tangela, with Life Orb recoil being a huge factor as well. Pokemon like Thwackey and Silvally-Dark sporting super effective coverage like U-turn can also hamper setup opportunities.

Priority Moves: Priority move users such as Thwackey, Flapple, and Gurdurr can revenge kill a weakened Ludicolo, with the former two forcing Ludicolo to use Ice Beam—and take Life Orb recoil without Giga Drain healing, if applicable—should they not cleanly take it out. Kangaskhan not only has the fearsome Fake Out + Sucker Punch combination, but it can strategically use Fake Out to waste Ludicolo's remaining turns of rain.

Shedinja: Shedinja is immune to all of rain sweeper Ludicolo's attacks. Using Protect, it can even scout for Knock Off from Assault Vest variants of Ludicolo on non-rain teams.

Rain Sweeper.description:
Ludicolo often sees use as a deadly late-game wincon that uses Rain Dance to boost its Hydro Pumps and outspeed the entire metagame with Swift Swim. Ice Beam nails opposing Grass- and Dragon-types such as Exeggutor, Appletun, and Altaria that resist Ludicolo's dual STAB combination. Life Orb increases Ludicolo's damage output while still letting it switch moves; it also works well in tandem with Giga Drain's HP recovery. 29 HP IVs help minimalize Life Orb recoil, while a Modest nature ameliorates Ludicolo's somewhat underwhelming Special Attack.

Skuntank's Corrosive Gas and Sawk's Knock Off help Ludicolo tremendously by permanently crippling its most commonplace checks, such as Articuno and Clefairy. A physically defensive wall such as Palossand provides Ludicolo a switch-in to threatening priority move users that may try to capitalize on its below-average Defense, such as Gurdurr and Swords Dance Galarian Rapidash. Other strong special attackers such as Choice Specs Rotom can force special walls into taking a hit, weakening them for Ludicolo to clean up later. Rain Dance is easier to set up with pivots like Alolan Persian, Silvally-Poison, and Morpeko bringing Ludicolo in against passive foes.

Special Tank.description:
Ludicolo is a decent special tank thanks its wide coverage, offensive movepool, and unique set of resistances. Scald and Giga Drain both synergize with Assault Vest: Scald dishes out burns, helping Ludicolo take physical attacks better, while Giga Drain provides extra longevity. Ice Beam targets Grass- and Dragon-types that resist Ludicolo's STAB moves like Altaria, Exeggutor, and Ivysaur. Knock Off cripples entry hazard removers like Articuno and Cryogonal, as well as walls like Clefairy and Alcremie. Crippling walls, alongside checking offensive Stealth Rock users like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Alolan Dugtrio with its typing and bulk, lets Ludicolo provide some early-game utility. Assault Vest allows Ludicolo to check special attackers like Rotom, Jynx, and Poliwrath.

Ludicolo appreciates walls like Cofagrigus and Tangela switching into physical attackers like Sawk, Lycanroc-N, and Gourgeist-S; in return, they appreciate it blanket checking special attackers. Once Ludicolo has crippled Defog and Rapid Spin users with Knock Off, partners like Rhydon and Alolan Dugtrio can more easily keep Stealth Rock up. This helps all sorts of offensive partners wallbreak and sweep. Notably, physical attackers like Sawk and Klinklang can take advantage of special walls that wall Ludicolo, using the momentum to have an easier time cleaning late-game.

Shedinja.comments:
Other Options

Spite can be used to win versus threats that can't touch Shedinja but that Shedinja can't also remove without resorting to PP stall, such as Electric Seed Galarian Rapidash and Uxie. Shedinja can run other offensive moves like Shadow Claw and Shadow Ball that have more PP than Poltergeist, but it is hard justifying running them since they are significantly weaker and the former even makes contact.

Checks and Counters

Passive Damage: Most walls like Articuno, Miltank, and Appletun carry a status move like Toxic, Will-O-Wisp, or Leech Seed that can instantly remove Shedinja. Abomasnow's Snow Warning is also noteworthy for preventing Shedinja from staying on the field as long as hail is active.

Super Effective Coverage: Most Pokemon in the tier carry a super effective move that can remove Shedinja in one hit, like Rhydon with Stone Edge, Tangela with Knock Off, and Rapidash with Flare Blitz. Some Pokemon also run uncommon coverage moves that can also remove Shedinja like Galarian Rapidash with Mystical Fire and Piloswine with Stone Edge or Toxic.

Wonder Guard Pivot.description:
Thanks to Wonder Guard, Shedinja is able to wall specific threats like Jynx, Nasty Plot Uxie, and Klinklang lacking Toxic. With Protect, Shedinja is able to scout for specific coverage moves like Silvally-Poison's Flamethrower and Alcremie's Mystical Fire, as well as scout Choice-locked attackers like Sawk, Rotom, and Thwackey. Toxic allows Shedinja to cripple switch-ins like Miltank, Articuno, Rapidash, and Tangela and pairs well with Protect to rack up chip damages. Will-O-Wisp is less effective at weakening threats, but it lets Shedinja's partners take on physical attackers like Silvally-Dark and Lycanroc-N that would switch into Shedinja while also punishing Poison- and Steel-types like Qwilfish, Skuntank, and Klinklang. Alternatively, Shedinja can run Swords Dance to work as a late-game wincon with Shadow Sneak. Poltergeist is the preferred STAB move due to being its strongest attacking move. Shadow Sneak is a viable alternative that can pick off weakened foes like Rotom and Froslass and hit Electric Terrain sweepers after they have consumed their Electric Seed. However, it is much weaker and makes contact, which can be troublesome when facing Rocky Helmet users like Miltank and Qwilfish and Flame Body users like Coalossal and Rapidash. Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item since it allows Shedinja to switch into entry hazards.

Shedinja works best on stall teams that appreciate its ability to handle specific threats, notable Stored Power attackers. These teams carry walls such as Pyukumuku, Sableye, and Altaria that can take advantage of the threats that force Shedinja out like Silvally-Dark, Gurdurr, and Tangela. Entry hazard control such Altaria, Articuno, and Hattrem is appreciated in these teams due to hazards being one of the best way to force damage on Shedinja's teammates. Defensive sweepers like Alcremie and Spiritomb make also for great partners that can clean late-game once the opposing team has been crippled and weakened enough by Shedinja and its teammates.

Sableye.comments:
Other Options

Foul Play can be used as an alternative to Knock Off, helping against Dark-type foes such as Silvally-Dark; however, Knock Off provides much more value. Leftovers and Rocky Helmet can be used as well instead of Heavy-Duty Boots.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Alcremie, Clefairy, and Shiinotic can all threaten Sableye with their STAB attacks. Alcremie in particular can set up on Sableye thanks to Aroma Veil.

Dark-types: Silvally-Dark and Skuntank are immune to Prankster-boosted moves, so they can switch into Sableye and proceed to set up on it without worry; however, the former must be wary of Foul Play lets it gets heavily chipped.

Strong Special Attackers: Ninetales, Appletun, and Jynx can overpower Sableye due to its low special bulk.

Physical Wall.description:
Thanks to its great typing and Prankster-boosted utility moves, Sableye finds a niche in ZU as a physical wall, notably countering the top-tier threat Sawk despite its lackluster defensive stats. Will-O-Wisp cripples most physical attackers like Sawk and Rhydon. Encore allows Sableye to counter setup sweepers like Klinklang and Qwilfish, while Taunt shuts down walls like Miltank and Uxie, preventing their Toxic and Stealth Rock.

Sableye fits best on balance teams looking for a Pokemon to help deal with physical attackers like Sawk, Klinklang, and Qwilfish. Stealth Rock setters like Miltank and Rhydon benefit from Sableye's Fighting immunity and spinblocking. Sableye is vulnerable to Fairy-types, especially Alcremie, which can set up on it, so Steel- and Fire-type Pokemon like Klinklang, Rapidash, and Ninetales make great partners. Strong special attackers such as Ninetales, Appletun, and Jynx are also troublesome, so their switch-ins like Type: Null, Coalossal, and Articuno are appreciated. Switch-ins to Dark- and Fire-type Pokemon are also needed, as Sableye cannot cripple them with Will-O-Wisp, so physical walls such as Poliwrath and Altaria work well.

Manectric.comments:
Other Options

Using Protect over Flamethrower or Thunderbolt lets Manectric more easily whittle down Ground-types and gain more Leftovers recovery; however, it is hard to fit over either attacking move. Manectric can run Heavy-Duty Boots over a Choice item, with Toxic over Switcheroo; however, Manectric's merely decent power it hard to justify.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types like Stunfisk, Rhydon, and Piloswine are immune to Manectric's STAB moves and can OHKO it in return. However, Galarian Stunfisk has to watch out for Choice Specs-boosted Fire-type coverage, while the other Ground-types get crippled by Switcheroo or Toxic.

Special Walls: Special walls like Throh and Clefairy can sponge Manectric's hits and don't mind being hit with Toxic. Appletun, in particular, resists every move from Manectric and mitigates damage with Recover. However, they dislike Switcheroo and getting pivoted on with Volt Switch.

Priority Moves: Due to Manectric's low bulk, priority move users such as Thwackey, Kangaskhan, and Shiftry can easily remove it with minimal prior chip damage.

Choice Scarf.description:
Manectric is a potent Choice Scarf user thanks to its high Speed letting it outspeed sweepers like +1 Silvally formes and Choice Scarf Sawk, great Electric + Fire coverage, and Volt Switch. Additionally, it brings a valuable Electric immunity thanks to Lightning Rod letting it absorb Volt Switch from Rotom formes. Overheat provides coverage for Electric-resistant foes like Thwackey, Galarian Stunfisk, and Tangela. If Manectric's high Speed tier isn't needed anymore, it can use Switcheroo to cripple special walls such as Stunfisk, Clefairy, and Rhydon.

Manectric is a great choice for VoltTurn teams looking for a revenge killer and Electric immunity. Additional VoltTurn users such as Uxie, Articuno, and Alolan Persian are appreciated. The aforementioned ones are especially great, as they can sponge hits for Manectric, making up for its lackluster bulk, and wear down Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine. Physical wallbreakers like Thwackey, Kangaskhan, and Sawk can take advantage of special walls that Manectric forces in and pivots against with Volt Switch. Entry hazard support from partners like Rhydon, Coalossal, and Qwilfish benefits Manectric by letting it take more advantage of Volt Switch and guaranteeing OHKOs against Tangela.

Choice Specs.description:
Manectric is a powerful Choice Specs user thanks to its great offensive stats and Electric + Fire coverage, which let it threaten common defensive cores like Articuno + Qwilfish + Galarian Stunfisk. Choice Specs-boosted Volt Switch whittles down special walls like Clefairy, Throh, and Appletun while retaining momentum. Overheat allows Manectric to OHKO threats like Flapple and Rotom and break down Ground-types such as Galarian Stunfisk. Flamethrower is an alternative that doesn't drop Manectric's Special Attack, which makes it more spammable, but it does not break down Volt Switch switch-ins as effectively as Overheat. Switcheroo lets Manectric cripple checks like Piloswine, Rhydon, and Coalossal which it is unable to break through, at the cost giving up Choice Specs.

Manectric fits at best on VoltTurn cores with partners like Thwackey, Articuno, and Uxie, chipping down the opposing team through constant pivoting. Spikes support from Qwilfish or Coalossal helps this process by further weakening the foes, putting foes like Sawk and Flapple into OHKO range. Physical wallbreakers like Sawk, Thwackey, and Shiftry can take advantange of special walls and Ground-types that Manectric forces in and benefit from its ability to safely bring them in. Special cleaners like Calm Mind Galarian Rapidash, Nasty Plot Liepard, and Skuntank enjoy Manectric weakening special walls, making it easier for them to clean late-game.

SubTox.description:
With the combination of Substitute and Toxic, Manectric is a good lure for Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine, both of which safely switch into Choice item sets. While it faces competition with Will-O-Wisp Rotom, Manectric's higher Speed, Electric immunity, and Fire-type coverage allow it to stand out. Flamethrower targets Grass-types like Tangela, Exeggutor, and Lurantis, as well as Ground-types immune to Toxic such as Alolan Dugtrio and Galarian Stunfisk.

Balance and bulky teams enjoy Manectric revenge killing foes like Klinklang, Jynx, and Qwilfish without being Choice locked. To help it defensively, physically bulky Pokemon like Poliwrath, Tangela, and Miltank can better stomach hits from Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine, faster Pokemon like Alolan Dugtrio and Froslass, and Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Gourgeist-S. Slow VoltTurn pivots such as Clefairy, Uxie, and Articuno can help bring Manectric in safely; outside of predicted Electric-type attacks, Manectric cannot switch in safely due to its low bulk. Late-game sweepers such as Klinklang, Lunatone, and Silvally formes can capitalize on Manectric whittling down their checks and counters with Toxic, like Stunfisk, Silvally-Dark, and Rhydon, to help them break through.

Roselia.comments:
Other Options

Sleep Powder can be used to cripple switch-ins such as Rapidash and Klinklang, however it is difficult to fit thanks to Roselia needing both of its STAB moves to avoid being easily walled and Synthesis to keep it healthy throughout the game. Natural Cure can be used to cure status, however is already immune to Sleep Powder and poison, and fishing for poison with Poison Point against Sawk and Thwackey is often preferred.

Checks and Counters

Entry Hazard Removal: Articuno, Altaria, and Coalossal can switch in and remove Spikes. All three can also threaten Roselia with their STAB attacks.

Fire-types: Rapidash and Ninetales can switch into Roselia and then precede to outspeed and OHKO it with their STAB attacks. They do fear switching into Sludge Bomb, as the poison chance can prevent them from consistently checking Roselia.

Ice-types: Froslass and Jynx can switch into Roselia and then precede to outspeed and OHKO it with their STAB attacks.

Psychic-types: Galarian Rapidash, Silvally-Psychic, and Beheeyem can all threaten Roselia with their STAB attacks. Galarian Rapidash needs to be cautious of switching into Sludge Bomb, however.

Flying-types: Unfezant and Silvally-Flying can safely switch into Roselia thanks to their resistance to Giga Drain and immunity to Spikes, and OHKO Roselia with their STAB attacks. Golbat is particularly notable as it resist both of Roselia's STAB attacks and cannot be poisoned.

Steel-types: Klinklang can easily switch into Roselia's STAB attacks. It can then setup a Substitute and Shift Gear. Pawniard and Mawile can also safely switch into Roselia, setting up a Swords Dance and threatening it out with their STAB attacks.

Defensive Spikes.description:
Roselia is a niche defensive entry hazard setter thanks to having Spikes, Toxic Spikes, reliable recovery, and a good defensive typing that allows it to check common attacker in Sawk and Thwackey. Spikes is Roselia's main method of dealing consistent damage to wear down the opposing team; however, Toxic Spikes is more powerful against bulkier builds or in conjunction with Pokemon that use Hex such as Rotom. Poison Point is used over Natural Cure to punish Pokemon such as Thwackey and Sawk. The EV spread avoids getting 2HKOed by Sawk while outspeeding Adamant Rhydon and Carracosta.

Roselia fits well on balance teams, providing Spikes support to wear down the opposing team and checking common Pokemon such as Thwackey and Sawk. Coalossal and Poliwrath make excellent teammates for Roselia, forming a Fire / Water / Grass core. Coalossal provides Stealth Rock and entry hazard removal with Rapid Spin, while Poliwrath can phaze foes out with Circle Throw, racking up Spikes damage. Both partners also resist Fire and Ice, which Roselia is vulnerable too. Psychic- and Flying-types are still problematic, however, so teammates such as Alolan Persian and Klinklang work well to help cover them. Kangaskhan works great as a teammate, reaping the benefits from entry hazard support by making Fake Out more threatening and taking advantage of the additional chip damage needed to 2HKO bulky foes such as Miltank and Tangela once its Eviolite is removed. Pawniard can help by using Knock Off to remove opponents Heavy-Duty Boots, in addition to threatening entry hazard removers such as Articuno and Altaria thanks to Defiant.

Altaria.comments:
Other Options

The combination of Fire Spin and Perish Song lets Altaria trap and take out walls such as Musharna and Pyukumuku; however, this set lacks the utility of Defog and only traps a limited number of Pokemon. Draco Meteor is Altaria's strongest move, but it is less consistent than Hurricane and Dual Wingbeat due to the Special Attack drop. Heal Bell can be used on stall teams lacking a cleric.

Checks and Counters

Ice-types and Ice-type Coverage: Altaria's 4x weakness to Ice makes it extremely vulnerable to any Ice-type attacks. Altaria is threatened by Ice-types such as Abomasnow, Froslass, and Jynx, but it also has to watch out for Ice coverage from Poliwrath.

Rock-types: Rock-types such as Kabutops and Rhydon threaten Altaria with Stone Edge and can safely set up Stealth Rock versus Altaria.

Dragon-types: Due to its weakness to Dragon, powerful Dragon-type wallbreakers like Flapple and Appletun can break through Altaria with their STAB moves, even if they can't switch into Altaria's Hurricane.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Clefairy and Alcremie pressure Altaria with their super effective STAB move, and they aren't pressured by Toxic thanks to Magic Guard and Aromatherapy, respectively. They can even take advantage of Altaria to set up with Calm Mind.

Setup Sweepers: While Altaria's bulk is great, it gets easily overwhelmed by strong attackers that can set up such as Silvally-Dark, Rotom-S, and Shiftry.

Physical Wall.description:
Altaria is a premier wall in ZU thanks to its ability to reliably answer powerful physical and special attackers such as Thwackey, Ninetales, Tangela, and Sawk. Toxic allows Altaria to put foes on a timer, letting it comfortably use Defog against entry hazard setters such as Piloswine and Miltank. Hurricane is Altaria's strongest STAB move, letting it threaten foes such as Qwilfish, Gurdurr, and Thwackey. Earthquake is an alternative that targets Toxic-immune foes such as Skuntank and Klinklang, while allowing Altaria to take on Fire-types more easily. The given EV spread allows Altaria to outspeed Adamant Piloswine and Jolly Rhydon and avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Thievul while maximizing its physical bulk.

Altaria is an excellent pick for balance and stall teams looking for a Defogger and a check to Fire-types. Offensive Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales can take advantage of Altaria's checks such as Clefairy, Rhydon, and Froslass while benefitting from Altaria walling opposing Fire- and Water-types. These two are also checks to Ice-types, and additional checks such as Piloswine, Poliwrath, and Miltank make for great partners, handling Altaria's biggest weakness. Other walls such as Pyukumuku, Rhydon, and Miltank appreciate Altaria's ability to absorb status for them; in return, they can handle threats that Altaria struggles with such as Jynx and Flapple. Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Rotom can revenge kill the threats that can muscle through Altaria.

Lunatone.comments:
Other Options

Lunatone has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Skuntank, Thievul, and Morpeko outspeed an unboosted Lunatone and threaten it with their STAB attacks.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio can switch into Lunatone's STAB attacks and threaten it out with their own. They need to be careful of Earth Power, however.

Priority users: Priority users such as Thwackey, Shiftry, and Qwilfish can revenge kill Lunatone with Grassy Glide, Sucker Punch, and Aqua Jet, respectively.

Choice Scarf users. Fast Choice Scarf users such as Gourgest-S and Alolan Persian can outspeed and revenge kill Lunatone even after a Rock Polish.

Meteor Beam.description:
Thanks to STAB Meteor Beam, Lunatone shines in ZU as a niche wallbreaker, boosting its Special Attack and muscling past any neutral foe in a single turn. Psyshock hits Pokemon such as Sawk and Qwilfish, and is its main STAB move once Power Herb has been used. Earth Power is the coverage move of choice, hitting Steel-types Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio, as well as Dark-types in Skuntank and Morpeko. Rock Polish allows Lunatone to outspeed common Choice Scarf users Sawk and Rotom and perform as a late-game cleaner. Stealth Rock is an option since Lunatone forces out common Defoggers like Articuno and Altaria.

Lunatone fits well on offense builds, benefiting teams that are centered around stacking entry hazards by threatening common Defog users such as Articuno and Altaria. Pokemon that appreciate Klinklang and Rapidash being weakened such as Alcremie, Jynx, and Thwackey benefit from Lunatone's presence. As Lunatone relies on Rock Polish to outpace offensive threats and is weak to common attacking types in the meta, pivots such as Thwackey, Articuno, and Type: Null are appreciated to bring it in safety and provide setup opportunities. Checks to Grass- and Water-types are much needed, so Pokemon such as Tangela, Appletun, and Articuno, respectively, work well. Dark-types such as Skuntank and Silvally-Dark are also great partners, resisting opposing Dark- and Ghost-type attacks that threaten Lunatone.

Solrock.overview: Solrock fails to be an effective physical wall and Stealth Rock setter due to its terrible stats and weakness-laden typing, meaning that even with full HP and Defense investment it often can't switch into common physically offensive threats like Sawk, Klinklang, and Qwilfish; as a result it is outclassed by the myriad of other excellent options like Palossand, Rhydon, and Miltank.

Physical Wall.description: Physically defensive Solrock aims to spread burn and set Stealth Rock while staying healthy with Morning Sun, chipping already statused switchins with Rock Slide, and punishing contact moves with Rocky Helmet. It ultimately isn't effective at this due to it being weak to common coverage and prone to getting 2HKOed, making it a liability for its team. Use Palossand, Rhydon, or Miltank instead.

Glalie.overview: Glalie is not viable in SS ZU due to it being entirely outclassed by Froslass, which performs the same role of a suicide lead but has better Speed, superior support moves, and a typing to deny Rapid Spin. Glalie is easier to take advantage of with its mediocre Speed and being forced to use Explosion to remove itself after setting Spikes.

Suicide Lead.description: Glalie attempts to act as a suicide lead with access to Spikes while using Taunt and Explosion to keep its entry hazards from being removed. However, it is entirely outclassed by Froslass, which performs this role much better with its faster Speed stat, access to Destiny Bond, and Ghost typing to thwart Rapid Spin users like Crygonal.

Walrein.overview: Walrein is not a very good Pokemon in SS ZU. Its seemingly decent bulk is undercut by its poor defensive typing, mediocre damage output, and lack of reliable recovery options. It could make use out of Swords Dance, but the aforementioned defensive issues combined with rather poor Speed make setting up rather difficult. Plus, Qwilfish does such a set way better thanks to its better defensive typing and Aqua Jet, and Froslass is a better physically attacking Ice-type due to its much greater Speed and being more immediately threatening.

Swords Dance.description: This set attempts to make use out of Walrein's decent coverage and Swords Dance, but setting up is made rather difficult with Walrein's bad defensive typing and poor Speed. Qwilfish is a much better user of Swords Dance thanks to its much better typing, great defensive ability in Intimidate to aid in setting up, and Aqua Jet for priority, while Froslass is better as a physically offensive Ice-type due to its much better Speed tier and much more immediate power.

Cherrim.overview: Cherrim is an awful Pokemon that has nothing going for it; it has mediocre stats, an extremely niche ability, a lackluster movepool, and an underwhelming mono-Grass typing. While Flower Gift could give the impression it might be decent in Sun teams, Chlorophyll users like Ivysaur and Shiftry, and Fire-types like Rapidash are more consistent attackers in this archetype due to their superior Speed and offenses.

Sun Wallbreaker.description: With Flower Gift, Life Orb, and Growth, Cherrim can deal great damage under sun, threatening a wide range of foes with its coverage. However, there are many better sun wallbreakers, including Ivysaur, Shiftry, and Rapidash, which have superior offenses and Speed.

Drifblim.comments:
Other Options

Destiny Bond allows Drifblim to sacrifice itself to eliminate checks such as Skuntank and Rhydon in the event they stop its sweep, but it is difficult to justify over any of Drifblim's other moves.

Checks and Counters

Special Walls: Without Substitute or multiple boosts, special walls such as Clefairy and Stunfisk easily tank Shadow Ball and cripple Drifblim with status. Drifblim particularly struggles with bulky Normal-types such as Miltank, as they can easily take a boosted Thunderbolt and Toxic it in return, while Substitute sets are completely unable to damage them.

Dark-types: Physical Dark-types that can get past Strength Sap, such as Silvally-Dark, Shiftry, and Morpeko, can easily overwhelm Drifblim. Specially offensive Dark-types, such as Skuntank and Thievul, have no trouble breaking through Drifblim.

Strong Wallbreakers: Wallbreakers that can hit Drifblim super effectively such as Manectric and Rhydon easily break through Drifblim even after a boost. However, these Pokemon must be kept healthy to check Drifblim.

Setup Sweepers: Setup sweepers that can boost their Special Defense, such as Alcremie, can easily turn Drifblim into setup fodder. Other setup sweepers, such as Ninetales and Rapidash, can't reliably defeat Drifblim, but can usually trade with it.

Terrain Sweeper.description:
Drifblim's access to Unburden and Calm Mind makes it an effective Electric Terrain sweeper when equipped with an Electric Seed. Strength Sap lets Drifblim use physical attackers such as Thwackey and Gurdurr as setup fodder and provides it with reliable recovery. Thunderbolt is used to hit Pokemon that resist or are immune to Ghost, such as Kangaskhan and Alolan Persian, neutrally, while Substitute can be used to avoid status from walls such as Tangela and Pyukumuku and to ease Drifblim's setup. However, not using Thunderbolt leads to Drifblim being completely walled by Normal-types. This Speed investment allows Drifblim to outspeed Choice Scarf Manectric after Unburden. Electric Seed allows Drifblim to easily trigger Unburden when Electric Terrain is up, and its Defense boost pairs well with Calm Mind and mitigates Drifblim's weakness to Knock Off.

Pincurchin is mandatory as a teammate due to Drifblim needing Electric Terrain to trigger Unburden. Due to special walls often being able to take Drifblim's boosted attacks and retaliate with status, Drifblim prefers being paired with Pokemon that share checks with it, such as special sweepers like Thievul and Swoobat and wallbreakers like Manectric and Raichu, to break through specially bulky Pokemon. In particular, Rising Voltage from the aforementioned wallbreakers is invaluable for facilitating a Drifblim sweep, as they can overpower checks such as Miltank and Spiritomb, while Drifblim can clean up any remaining threats. Pokemon that can force out Dark- and Normal-types such as Sawk and Alolan Persian are also appreciated teammates. Finally, pivots such as Uxie make good partners, as they can create setup opportunities for Drifblim by giving it a free switch into a favorable matchup.

Skuntank.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb provides additional damage output, but the recoil damage limits Skuntank's longevity and makes it prone to entry hazards. Defog and Heavy-Duty Boots turn Skuntank into an offensive entry hazard remover, but this makes it inconsistent in its stallbreaking role.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to take a boosted hit from Skuntank and OHKO it back with their STAB moves.

Faster Offensive Threats: Skuntank's mediocre Speed leaves it susceptible to faster attackers such as Rapidash, Kangaskhan, and Froslass. Special wallbreakers and pivots like Rotom can also threaten to revenge kill Skuntank, preventing it from consistently performing its role. However, physical attackers should be wary of residual damage from Aftermath.

Special Walls: Although they do not appreciate Taunt, Corrosive Gas, and being poisoned by Sludge Bomb, special walls such as Articuno and Type: Null are able to take boosted hits from Skuntank and pivot with U-turn, safely bringing in revenge killers to threaten it. Galarian Stunfisk is able to wear down Skuntank if it lacks Fire Blast.

Stallbreaker.description:
Skuntank is a great stallbreaker in ZU; its Poison / Dark typing gives it various opportunities to set up against foes such as Uxie and Tangela. While initially weak, Skuntank can pummel passive walls like Clefairy and Altaria with Nasty Plot and its STAB coverage. Taunt can be used to prevent foes like Miltank and Pyukumuku from recovering HP. Alternatively, Corrosive Gas cripples common checks like Rhydon, Articuno, and Stunfisk.

Skuntank fits best on offense and balance teams that appreciate its Toxic and Psychic immunities, stallbreaking, and ability to pressure Ghost-, Psychic-, and Fairy-types like Cofagrigus, Uxie, and Clefairy. Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to heavily pressure Skuntank; checks to them such as Cramorant and Poliwrath are appreciated. The aforementioned Water-types can also lure in Grass-types like Thwackey and Tangela for Skuntank to take advantage of. Partners like Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes benefit from Skuntank weakening foes such as Tangela, Qwilfish, and Alcremie to clean late-game.

Spiritomb.comments:
Other Options

Spiritomb can run a physical wallbreaker set with Choice Band thanks to powerful moves in Poltergeist and Sucker Punch. Choice Band also pairs well with Trick, as it lets Spiritomb cripple the few Pokemon that can safely switch into Poltergeist such as Miltank and Tangela. However, Spiritomb is too slow to be a real offensive threat and being Choice-locked into Sucker Punch makes it very exploitable.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Shiftry, Skuntank, and Silvally-Dark resist Spiritomb's Dark Pulse and use it as setup fodder or, in Alolan Persian's case, beat it with the combination of Taunt + Toxic.

Wallbreakers: With no way of boosting its average physical bulk and Rest as its only form of recovery, Spiritomb gets overpowered by strong physical wallbreakers such as Flapple and Silvally formes. Spiritomb's special bulk is also lackluster before setting up a Calm Mind, and it can be forced out by special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Rotom and Jynx.

Alcremie: Alcremie is able to use Spiritomb as setup fodder for its Calm Mind sets and defeat it with Dazzling Gleam, while it is unable to do much in return. It should, however, be noted that mono-attacking variants of Alcremie running Stored Power get PP stalled by Spiritomb.

Calm Mind.description:
Spiritomb is a fearsome defensive Calm Mind sweeper that is able to find setup opportunities against some threats like Sawk locked into Close Combat, Swoobat, and Cofagrigus. Dark Pulse is the preferred STAB move, as, unlike Shadow Ball, it has no immunities. Rest is Spiritomb's most reliable recovery move and lets it get rid of status. Sleep Talk prevents Spritomb from being completely passive during Rest. Pressure lets Spiritomb PP stall defensive walls like Throh and Clefairy.

Spiritomb fits best on stall teams where its initial passivity isn't as crippling, and its unique defensive utility and PP stalling capabilities are appreciated. On these teams, Spiritomb's teammates whittle down and remove its counters over the course of a match, so it can be used as a late-game wincon. Physical walls like Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria handle powerful wallbreakers such as Rhydon and Silvally formes. Special walls like Clefairy and Articuno are necessary to handle special wallbreakers such as Ninetales and Exeggutor, which can force out an unboosted Spiritomb. Some of them even provide Heal Bell support to wake up Spiritomb after it uses Rest. Checks to Dark-types like Alcremie and Throh are appreciated for their ability to take on foes such as Skuntank and Shiftry, which use Spiritomb as setup fodder. Checks to Alcremie such as Pyukumuku and Haze Articuno are also necessary, as it is a major threat to stall teams and can freely come in on Spiritomb.

Abomasnow.comments:
Other Options

Mixed attacking sets can give Abomasnow offensive versatility, being able to hit both special walls like Altaria and physical walls like Tangela. However, without Choice Specs or a Swords Dance boost, Abomasnow's power can be a bit lacking. Abomasnow can use Aurora Veil to help facilitate sweepers, especially the Silvally formes, but with Light Clay banned, its usefulness has mostly diminished. It can also run a Choice Band set to become a physical attacker with immediate power, but it is generally outclassed by other physical Grass-types like Thwackey and Gourgeist-S.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: Although they can't directly switch into it, and they must be wary of Ice Shard if their health is low, many wallbreakers can easily revenge kill Abomasnow. These include Sawk, Rapidash, and the Silvally formes.

Fire-type Pokemon and Coverage: While they fear Abomasnow's Ground-type coverage, Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash resist both of its STAB attacks. Other notable Pokemon, like the Silvally formes, run Flamethrower or Flame Charge, which end Abomasnow's sweeping attempts.

Steel-type Pokemon: While Abomasnow's Ground-type coverage is threatening, Steel-types force it out with the threat of a super effective hit. Klinklang resists both of its STAB attacks, and while Alolan Dugtrio doesn't, it can outspeed and OHKO it.

Poison-type Pokemon: Pokemon like Silvally-Poison and Skuntank resist Abomasnow's Grass-type STAB attacks and deal super effective damage in return. Be careful of Abomasnow's Ice-type STAB moves, though.

Fighting-type Pokemon: Abomasnow's weakness to Fighting-types makes it vulnerable to super effective attacks from Sawk, Silvally-Fighting, and Gurdurr. However, it can also hit them hard on the switch, so most Fighting-types only serve as offensive checks.

Choice Specs.description:
While its poor Speed and reliance on prediction make it inconsistent, Abomasnow is a powerful wallbreaker with Choice Specs equipped. Its perfectly accurate Blizzard shreds through walls like Altaria, Tangela, and Rhydon, while its STAB Leaf Storm crushes switch-ins to Ice-type attacks like Poliwrath and Piloswine. Earth Power allows Abomasnow to break through Fire- and Steel-types like Rapidash and Klinklang. Focus Blast nails Miltank, who can switch into Blizzard with Thick Fat or Leaf Storm with Sap Sipper.

The read-heavy nature of Abomasnow's playstyle makes it very appreciative of VoltTurn support. Offensive pivots like Rotom, Kabutops, and the Silvally formes can chip down foes and provide as many safe opportunities for Abomasnow to attack as possible. This chip damage is further accentuated by entry hazard support from Rhydon, Uxie, and Qwilfish. To prevent Abomasnow itself from being worn down by entry hazards, teammates that can remove them like Silvally-Poison, Altaria, and Cramorant prove to be extremely helpful. Morpeko is an offensive entry hazard remover that can also use Parting Shot to get Abomasnow onto the field after entry hazards have been cleared. Because of its long list of weaknesses, a strong defensive backbone is necessary. Checks to notable Fire-, Steel-, and Poison-types include Miltank, Stunfisk, and Throh, respectively.

Swords Dance.description:
Abomasnow becomes a threatening physical wallbreaker after a Swords Dance boost, thanks to its fierce STAB combination and good coverage. A boosted Wood Hammer completely demolishes common walls, like Poliwrath, Rhydon, and Clefairy. That said, its poor Speed and defensive profile make it hard to consistently set up. It usually is only able to reliably switch into extremely passive walls, like Miltank and Clefairy, and Choice-locked attackers like Thwackey and Rotom; otherwise, faster threats like Sawk and Rapidash prevent it from setting up. Ice Shard catches revenge killers like Rotom and Thwackey after a boost and, despite its low power, is still good enough coverage against Altaria and Gourgeist-S. Earthquake is a necessary coverage move, hitting Steel- and Fire-type Pokemon on the switch.

Vital parts of facilitating Abomasnow's breaking ability are keeping hazards up and chipping down foes. Because of that, Spikes-stacking offense teams are very capable of supporting Abomasnow's capabilities. Qwilfish, Coalossal, and Froslass are some key Spikers, with Qwilfish resisting many of Abomasnow's biggest weaknesses. VoltTurn users like Manectric, Rotom, Kabutops, and the Silvally formes similarly bring down foes' health while keeping up momentum. These Pokemon can also revenge kill faster threats that may threaten Abomasnow, including Sawk and Rapidash. There also are some defensive teammates that can handle revenge killers, like Rapidash and Froslass, including Stealth Rock setters such as Miltank and Rhydon. Walls like Clefairy and Stunfisk can spread paralysis, which lets Abomasnow sweep more easily against Alolan Persian and the Silvally formes.

Lickilicky.overview: Lickilicky, despite its unique traits like Wish and Knock Off, is often outclassed by other clerics like Miltank and Clefairy, due to their lesser passivity and their better abilities and typing, respectively.

Cleric.description: Lickilicky acts as a bulky cleric thanks to its access to Heal Bell and other utility options like Wish and Knock Off, and its fairly good special bulk lets it take on some common attackers like Rotom and offensive Spikes Froslass. However, its passivity in the face of many setup sweepers like Skuntank, Alcremie, and Silvally-Dark means that to properly function it needs support from teammates able to take on these threats. Lickilicky is also outclassed by other clerics such as Miltank, Alcremie, and Clefairy, mainly due to these Pokemon's better matchups versus common threats and access to instant recovery in a metagame where Wish is not that valuable.

Electivire.overview: Electivire might seem appealing on paper due to its high attacking stats and good coverage movepool, but this is offset by the lack of a good physical STAB move and setup options, making its damage output often underwhelming. Electivire is outclassed as an offensive Electric-type by Rotom, Rotom-S, and even Manectric, and as a general mixed attacker by the likes of Silvally-Poison and Silvally-Fighting.

Mixed Attacker.description: This set attempts to make use of Electivire's decent attacking stats and movepool. However, it falls short because of the fact that Electivire has to make do with a rather weak STAB Thunderbolt, and its attacking stats are such that Electivire can often fail to get the KOs it really wants. Pokemon such as Silvally-Poison and Silvally-Fighting work better as mixed attackers due to either stronger STAB moves or a reliable boosting option, both of which Electivire lacks. As an offensive Electric-type in general, Rotom, Rotom-S, and Manectric are better choices due to having more reliable damage options.

Leafeon.comments:
Other Options

Weather Ball targets physically defensive Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S, but they already do not appreciate taking a Knock Off or Double-Edge. Synthesis provides Leafeon with sun-boosted recovery and counteracts the residual damage from Life Orb.

Checks and Counters

Grass-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon such as Altaria, Gourgeist-XL, and Tangela resist Solar Blade and are able to pressure Leafeon with status. However, they dislike being crippled by Knock Off and weakened by Double-Edge.

Poison-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off or Double-Edge, Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison and Skuntank are able to take unboosted hits from Leafeon and retaliate with their STAB moves.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Leafeon, although they must be wary of Knock Off and Double-Edge.

Residual Damage and Priority: Recoil from Life Orb and Double-Edge, as well as residual damage from entry hazards, limits Leafeon's survivability and makes it susceptible to being revenge killed by foes such as Kangaskhan and Piloswine.

Sun Sweeper.description:
Leafeon finds a niche on sun teams as a physical sweeper, utilizing its bulk to set up with Swords Dance and threaten foes with a Life Orb-boosted Solar Blade. Leaf Blade is a notable alternative over Solar Blade that, despite its lower damage output, provides a reliable STAB attack when sun is not up. Knock Off allows Leafeon to weaken Grass-resistant foes such as Ninetales, Tangela, and Silvally-Poison. Double-Edge gives Leafeon coverage against problematic foes like Skuntank, Altaria, and the aforementioned Ninetales and Silvally-Poison.

Sun setters such as Uxie, Liepard, and Exeggutor are mandatory, as they enable Leafeon to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and let it utilize Solar Blade. Leafeon can form an attacking core with other sun sweepers such as Shiftry and Ivysaur, with all weakening each other's shared checks in Pokemon such as Skuntank. Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash can also take advantage of sun to boost their STAB moves and threaten foes such as Tangela and Thwackey. Ground-types such as Piloswine and Rhydon can take advantage of Poison- and Fire-types that Leafeon invites in and use that opportunity to fire off a strong hit or set Stealth Rock; in return, they appreciate Leafeon threatening opposing Water-types like Poliwrath and Basculin.

Froslass.comments:
Other Options

Froslass's Spikes set can take advantage of a variety of options, thanks to its utility movepool. Toxic and Will-O-Wisp cripple switch-ins and physical attackers alike. However, having to give up Taunt or an attacking option makes it difficult to fit. Physical attacks can be ran on its Spikes set, but it has bad synergy with Knock Off, which you want to use to remove Heavy-Duty Boots.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: Froslass's poor bulk and weakness-laden typing leaves it vulnerable to opposing revenge killers. Choice Scarf users like Rotom, Sawk, and Gourgeist-Small have super effective coverage for it. Outside of that, priority users like Kangaskhan and Thwackey do a good job of handling Froslass. While Alolan Persian doesn't use priority, it's one of the few Pokemon faster than Froslass.

Water-type Pokemon: Though repeated Ghost-type attacks can threaten it, Poliwrath's physical bulk and typing lets it serve as a great check to Froslass, actively punishing its Triple Axel with Rocky Helmet. For similar reasons on top of having Intimidate, Qwilfish is a great switch-in to Triple Axel, but is more vulnerable to Poltergeist and special attacking sets. While it is relegated to stall teams, Pyukumuku can completely blank Froslass if it doesn't get afflicted by Taunt or Trick.

Steel-type Pokemon: While it can struggle to take multiple Ghost-type attacks, Klinklang has the bulk and typing to handle Froslass's Ice-type attacks, while using Gear Grind to KO it. Despite its frailty, Alolan Dugtrio is as fast as Froslass and has Sucker Punch.

Dark-type Pokemon: Dark-types like Alolan Persian and Silvally-Dark resist Froslass's Ghost-type attacks and immediately threaten it with their own STAB moves. However, they must be wary to not switch into its powerful Ice-type attacks.

Miltank: With its immunity to Ghost, and with Thick Fat variants resisting its Ice-type STAB, Miltank can completely blank Froslass and wear it down via Toxic. However, if Froslass uses Taunt, Miltank is unable to touch it.

Choice Band.description:
Possessing a blistering Speed stat and a ruthless dual STAB combination, Froslass is a strong Choice Band wallbreaker. With both of its powerful STAB attacks, Froslass has amazing neutral coverage that defensive cores can have trouble handling. Switcheroo cripples the few defensive counters to Froslass, which include Miltank and defensive Poliwrath. Ice Shard is great against offensive teams, revenge killing faster threats like Thwackey, Lilligant, and Alolan Dugtrio after some chip. Either of the latter two moves can be replaced by Spikes, as Froslass can easily set multiple layers thanks to the free turns it generates forcing switches.

Choice Band Froslass generally fits well on offensive builds, but it must be noted that Poltergeist has negative synergy with Knock Off users. Due to its poor defenses, Froslass appreciates VoltTurn users who can safely bring it onto the field. Offensive pivots like Morpeko and Silvally formes can lure in Pokemon like Palossand and Altaria, respectively, bringing Froslass in safely to immediately threaten them. Defensive pivots including Articuno and Clefairy, which are able to take a hit and pivot out, so Froslass comes in unharmed. With its amazing ability to weaken walls and revenge kill wallbreakers, Froslass leaves ample opportunity for sweepers like Klinklang, Galarian Rapidash, and Silvally-Dark to set up. If bulkier teams intend on using Froslass, keeping it healthy through entry hazard removers like Morpeko and Coalossal is essential. Knock Off absorbers like Alcremie and Miltank also play important roles in giving Froslass backup when it's in danger.

Offensive Spikes Setter.description:
Froslass is a premier Spikes setter thanks to having one of the fastest Taunts in the metagame alongside a great STAB combination. It threatens common entry hazard removers like Altaria and Rotom and can use Taunt to block removal from other Pokemon like Articuno and Silvally-Poison. This also shuts down passive Pokemon like Miltank and Pyukumuku, which makes Froslass a solid stallbreaker. Froslass is also a capable revenge killer, as it outpaces the majority of the unboosted metagame, including threats like Jynx, Thievul, and Sawk.

Spikes Froslass's combination of Speed and offensive utility makes it a great fit for offensive builds. Offensive Knock Off users like Thwackey, Sawk, and Kabutops make opposing Pokemon vulnerable to Froslass's Spikes. These wallbreakers also directly benefit from Spikes, as it can put foes in greater range of KOs. Other wallbreakers that love Spikes include Galarian Rapidash and the Silvally formes. These Pokemon also threaten Froslass checks like Alolan Persian and Miltank. Morpeko is a particularly nice partner, removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin and threatening Froslass checks like Poliwrath and Choice Scarf Rotom. Pivots love the extra chip damage from Spikes, so VoltTurn users like Silvally-Fighting, Manectric, and Flapple can both safely bring in Froslass and further damage walls like Qwilfish and Palossand.

Suicide Lead.description:
With just about every great utility move needed and a great Speed tier, Froslass is a great suicide lead that facilitates setup sweepers. Froslass runs Focus Sash to guarantee at least one layer of Spikes. Froslass's Ghost typing and access to Taunt lets it easily shut Defog and Rapid Spin users alike. Destiny Bond lets it take down a foe with it, making it especially useful for bringing down wallbreakers like Klinklang and Silvally-Dark. It also pairs well with Taunt, forcing foes to attack it. Avalanche is its preferred attacking move, as its negative priority gives it a greater opportunity to take advantage of Destiny Bond. However, Icy Wind is also a solid option, as its ability to lower Speed makes taking advantage of the foe easier for its teammates. If Icy Wind is used, Froslass needs to instead run a Timid Nature with Special Attack investment.

Froslass's suicide lead set will exclusively be seen on hyper offense teams looking for a reliable Spikes setter who can quickly provide momentum. The pressure put on from Spikes makes it easier for setup sweepers to secure KOs, so partners like Klinklang, Silvally-Poison, and Crustle love Froslass. Knock Off users like Thwackey, Gurdurr, and Uxie are able to remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the opposing side, making Spikes even more dangerous. Because entry hazard removers like Altaria and Articuno are inclined to enter the field with Spikes up, wallbreakers like Lycanroc-Midnight and Sawk immediately threaten these Defog users.

Rotom.comments:
Other Options

Toxic can be used over Will-O-Wisp to better cripple defensive walls like Miltank and Coalossal at the expense of not punishing physical attackers as hard. Discharge is an alternative to Thunderbolt on sets with Hex. Rotom can forgo Special Attack investment and run a more bulky set with maximum HP investment to better check physical Ground- and Fighting-types like Piloswine and Sawk.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Silvally-Dark and Alolan Persian are faster than non-Choice Scarf Rotom and can revenge kill it easily. Skuntank can use Rotom as setup fodder if it has locked itself into Shadow Ball. Shiftry and Morpeko resist Rotom's STAB attacks but must be wary of switching into Will-O-Wisp or being pivoted upon, as they are quite frail.

Electric-immune Pokemon: Rhydon, Piloswine, Stunfisk, and Manectric can safely switch into Rotom's Electric-type attacks, especially if it has a Choice item. However, Rhydon and Piloswine dislike Will-O-Wisp and Trick, and all of the aforementioned Pokemon do not enjoy switching into Choice Specs Shadow Ball.

Specially Bulky Pokemon: Despite Rotom having a decent Special Attack stat, it struggles to break past Pokemon with solid special bulk, as they can take a hit and retaliate. Throh can threaten Rotom immediately with Knock Off. Specially defensive walls such as Clefairy, Appletun, and Cryogonal are great long-term checks, as they have reliable recovery; Clefairy can also pivot into a revenge killer, while the latter two threaten Rotom immediately.

Faster Threats: Non-Choice Scarf Rotom is very susceptible to being revenge killed by Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Gourgeist-S. Faster Pokemon such as Rapidash and Froslass threaten Rotom. Pokemon with priority moves such as Thwackey and Kangaskhan can also threaten to revenge kill Rotom after some prior chip damage.

Choice Scarf.description:
Choice Scarf improves Rotom's revenge killing capabilities at the cost of some wallbreaking power; it outpaces foes like Froslass, Silvally-Poison, and Choice Scarf Sawk. Volt Switch can be used to pick off weakened foes while also keeping momentum against potential switch-ins. Trick can be used once there isn't a need for Rotom's revenge killing purposes and punishes passive walls like Galarian Stunfisk and Articuno. Thunderbolt makes for a great cleaning move, as it is a stronger Electric-type STAB move that doesn't force Rotom out. Alternatively, Will-O-Wisp cripples opposing targets, namely physical Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Galarian Stunfisk, while Defog is useful on teams that cannot fit entry hazard removal elsewhere.

Rotom enjoys the luxury of being able to use Volt Switch as often as possible, so having a entry hazard remover such as Articuno, Altaria, or Coalossal is a good idea. Pairing Rotom with Pokemon that can deal with Ground-types like Poliwrath and Gourgeist-S is also recommended to achieve this goal. Rotom also benefits greatly from entry hazard support, as it wants to use Volt Switch often to force out common Pokemon like Qwilfish and Articuno and wear down common switch-ins such as Throh and Clefairy. Good examples of entry hazard setters include Miltank, Qwilfish, and Rhydon. Physically offensive threats such as Sawk, Rapidash, and Silvally-Dark benefit from Rotom's ability to bring them in safely after forcing out their checks. Rotom is great on VoltTurn cores and works well with other pivots such as Articuno, Silvally formes, and Thwackey.

Utility.description:
With great status moves and Volt Switch, Rotom is a great offensive pivot that offers solid utility. Defog is great on teams that need entry hazard control, while Pain Split provides Rotom with a form of recovery. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers and Ground-types such as Rhydon, Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Piloswine, and it also boosts the power of Hex. Colbur Berry prevents Rotom from being KOed by Sawk's Knock Off, which gives Rotom a chance to cripple it with a burn, while Heavy-Duty Boots allows Rotom to avoid taking Stealth Rock damage when pivoting. Sitrus Berry can be used for more general increased longevity and is preferred over Leftovers due to the constant pivoting.

Rotom is best used on bulky offense and balance teams that benefit from its ability to disrupt opposing teams and offer support with Defog. Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Thwackey, and Sawk that appreciate Rotom's ability to bring them in safely; and in return, they can make up for Rotom's lack of immediate power, as it is reliant on spreading burns in order to maximize its power. Offensive threats such as Rapidash, Ninetales, and Skuntank appreciate Rotom's ability to lure in Ground-types and cripple them with burns. Rapidash and Ninetales also benefit from Defog and Rotom forcing out Water-types like Poliwrath and Cramorant. Skuntank helps Rotom by checking faster Ghost-types such as Gourgeist-S and Choice Scarf Rotom and Dark-types like Shiftry and Thievul. Other status inducers like Thunder Wave Qwilfish and utility Rapidash pair well with Hex.

Choice Specs.description:
Rotom is one of the most threatening special attackers in ZU due to the lack of Pokemon that resist its STAB combination. Choice Specs further facilitates Rotom's wallbreaking power by letting it nab 2HKOs on most walls, while its solid Speed allows it to revenge kill a weakened Skuntank or Klinklang. Volt Switch lets Rotom gain momentum on Water- and Flying-types and get out of bad matchups against threats such as Throh and Appletun. Trick can be used not only to immediately cripple the aforementioned specially defensive walls but also to punish Ground-types that may attempt to block its Volt Switch attempts, such as Stunfisk and Piloswine.

Rotom is susceptible to being revenge killed by faster Dark-types like Alolan Persian and Silvally-Dark if it is locked into Shadow Ball; therefore, it is imperative to pair Rotom with Fighting- or Fairy-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, Alcremie, and Clefairy. The aforementioned Fighting-types also benefit from Rotom's ability to break past physical walls such as Tangela and Uxie and can deal with Normal-types like Kangaskhan and Miltank so Rotom can use Shadow Ball more freely. Pivots such as Thwackey and Silvally formes make for great partners, as they can bring Rotom in safely and form a solid VoltTurn core. Tangela and Appletun can switch into Ground-types like Stunfisk and Rhydon should Rotom lock into an Electric-type move.

Nasty Plot.description:
Nasty Plot Rotom is a great wallbreaker on offensive teams. With a single boost, Rotom OHKOes physical walls such as Tangela and Poliwrath and has a chance to 2HKO specially defensive walls such as Clefairy and Articuno. Substitute lets Rotom block status attempts from Altaria and Miltank and set up on them freely.

Thwackey can lure in Flying-types and bring in Rotom safely so it can freely set up with Nasty Plot. In return, Rotom can break past physical walls such as Tangela, Poliwrath, and Altaria, which Thwackey struggles with. Late-game cleaners such Alcremie benefit greatly from Rotom's ability to weaken special walls such as Galarian Stunfisk and Articuno. Teleport Clefairy is a great defensive pivot that can absorb Dark-type attacks from revenge killers like Silvally-Dark and Choice Scarf Sawk. Rotom also appreciates having Knock Off users like Shiftry and Alolan Persian to weaken special walls such as Throh and Clefairy.

Rotom-Fan.comments:
Other Options
