Thunder Wave and Toxic are valid replacements for Will-O-Wisp, but the former is punished by switching into Ground-types, which already don’t fear Rotom-S's other moves, and the latter allows switch-ins such as Galarian Stunfisk to come in more easily. Discharge can used as Rotom-S's Electric-type STAB move to paralyze offensive switch-ins but leaves it worse off versus bulkier Pokemon. Rotom-S can be a team's Choice Scarf user, but its weakness to Stealth Rock, vulnerability to common priority moves such as Ice Shard, and direct competition with Rotom make it suboptimal for that role.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Ground-types: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Galarian Stunfisk, and Rhydon block Rotom-S's Volt Switch and Thunderbolt and take little from Air Slash. All of them, however, don’t appreciate taking a Will-O-Wisp on the switch.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers with moves to hit Rotom-S hard such as Froslass, Kangaskhan, and Silvally formes are able to pressure it out with ease.

Toxic: Taking Toxic from users such as Altaria, Alolan Persian, and Miltank cripples Rotom-S due to its unreliable recovery.

Knock Off: Knock Off users like Sawk, Thwackey, and Gurdurr are difficult for Rotom-S to consistently switch into. Entry hazard setters with access to Knock Off such as Uxie and Clefairy also make it hard for Rotom-S to consistently remove entry hazards throughout a game.

Defog.description:
Rotom-S is a good entry hazard remover in the metagame due to its ability to pivot with Volt Switch and excellent defensive typing that lets it wall and threaten common Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Sawk. Will-O-Wisp allows Rotom-S to cripple physical attackers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rhydon on the switch, while Pain Split gives greater but unreliable longevity. 252 Speed EVs let Rotom-S outspeed relevant Pokemon such as Cramorant, Qwilfish, and non-Choice Scarf Sawk. Investing in Special Attack over HP allows it to pressure common walls like Altaria and Piloswine, which is also viable.

Rotom-S fits on balance and offense teams as an entry hazard remover and pivot. Common VoltTurn teammates like Silvally-Dark, Alolan Persian, and Uxie can form a pivot core with Rotom-S to safely bring in wallbreakers such as Jynx and Shiftry. Toxic cripples Rotom-S, so Toxic-immune partners such as Qwilfish and Clefairy are greatly appreciated; Rotom-S in turn provides them with a switch-in to Ground-type attacks. Knock Off hinders Rotom-S's ability to remove entry hazards, so Knock Off absorbers such as Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Skuntank help immensely. Rotom-S is unable to deal with hard-hitting wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rapidash, so strong revenge killers such as Froslass, Alolan Persian, and Choice Scarf Sawk are all great teammates.

Nasty Plot.description:
Rotom-S's decent Speed along with an excellent offensive typing give it a niche as a stallbreaker and cleaner with Nasty Plot. Substitute allows Rotom-S to avoid crippling status from passive Pokemon such as Clefairy and Altaria, which, in conjunction with its STAB Thunderbolt, lets it beat the only Unaware user in the tier in Pyukumuku. Pain Split, on the other hand, gives Rotom-S more longevity against weak attackers without status such as Galarian Stunfisk and Uxie.

Rotom-S fits on offensive teams for its stallbreaking and cleaning capabilities. Teammates such as Silvally formes, Kangaskhan, and Basculin appreciate Rotom-S dealing with bulky Pokemon such as Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria. Faster offensive Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Rapidash, and Silvally formes are able to threaten Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Tangela, Poliwrath, and Galarian Stunfisk and fast attackers like Alolan Persian, Basculin, and Choice Scarf Sawk are vital for it. Ground-type Pokemon such as Piloswine and Rhydon are able to stomach an unboosted attack from Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Tangela and Miltank are appreciated.

Uxie.comments:
Other Options

Uxie can run an Assault Vest set to handle special attackers such as Jynx, Exeggutor, and Manectric at the expense of switching into Sawk, Rhydon, and Gurdurr. Its lack of reliable recovery and bad matchup against common special attackers like Rotom and Skuntank mean it struggles to fit into most teams. Leftovers is an alternative to Colbur Berry on Uxie's defensive set, improving its longevity. However, this makes Uxie vulnerable to Knock Off. Thunder Wave is a viable alternative to Knock Off on defensive Uxie that debilitates faster attackers such as Thievul and Silvally formes, letting Uxie's teammates take them on more easily. Defensive Uxie can also run Choice Scarf with Trick and 64 Speed EVs, letting it outspeed up to Alolan Persian and debilitate a potential entry hazard remover like Articuno or Coalossal. However, Uxie can get a harmful item like Skuntank's Black Sludge or Rotom's Choice Specs, or even become setup fodder for Silvally formes due to their Trick immunity. Memento is an alternative for the defensive pivot set, blocking Defog and bringing in a teammate more safely than U-turn, but Uxie often can't fit it. Encore can be used to punish Pokemon that otherwise freely set up on Uxie like Galarian Rapidash and Ninetales.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Uxie is threatened by attackers such as Rotom and Gourgeist-S. However, most of them take great damage from Knock Off and STAB moves, meaning Uxie can pressure them on the switch.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Thievul, Silvally-Dark, and Skuntank threaten Uxie with their super effective STAB moves, block Future Sight, and can sponge boosted Draining Kiss. However, several of them, including Liepard and Morpeko, take heavy damage from U-turn, and Colbur Berry Uxie can afford to take a hit.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Defensive sweepers such as Alcremie and Spiritomb easily set up on the weak Uxie. Most of them can also beat Uxie in a setup war.

Wallbreakers and Stallbreakers: Wallbreakers such as Thwackey and Froslass can use Uxie's passivity to threaten its whole team with their powerful moves. However, they dislike losing their items to Knock Off. Faster Taunt users such as Alolan Persian can shut down Uxie's utility and take advantage of it with Toxic.

Steel-types: Setup Uxie has a very hard time breaking through Steel-types such as Klinklang due to its low damage output. They can easily break Uxie's Substitute and remove Uxie before it is boosted enough.

Haze Articuno and Unaware Pyukumuku: Haze Articuno and Unaware Pyukumuku can wall most setup Uxie. However, Pyukumuku has to be wary of Stored Power's increased Base Power.

Nasty Plot.description:
Uxie can act as a terrifying late-game cleaner with its Nasty Plot set. Substitute lets it avoid status such as Toxic from Articuno and Altaria, dodge Knock Off from Tangela and Clefairy, and sponge hits from weak attackers like Clefairy lacking Seismic Toss and Stunfisk. Psyshock is preferred over Psychic as a STAB move to get around special walls like Articuno and Clefairy more easily. Draining Kiss lets Uxie break through Dark-types like Thievul and Morpeko after a boost and provides coveted recovery.

Uxie is a great late-game cleaner for bulkier teams that can weaken its checks over time. Therefore, entry hazard support, especially Spikes from setters such as Coalossal and Qwilfish, is invaluable. Knock Off support is similarly valuable for removing Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, the latter being the only form of recovery of Steel-types that check Uxie like Klinklang. Toxic users such as Altaria and Rapidash cripple the likes of Haze Articuno, Alcremie, and Musharna to help Uxie break through them. Uxie can also fit well with other defensive sweepers like Spiritomb and Alcremie, weakening each other’s checks and forcing Trick uses to ensure one of them can sweep.

Defensive Pivot.description:
Uxie is a premier defensive pivot in VoltTurn teams due to its incredible role compression as the only viable Pokemon with both U-turn and Stealth Rock. Additionally, Uxie's incredible bulk lets it reliably check threats like Sawk and Silvally-Poison. Levitate also helps in that regard, avoiding chip damage from Spikes and giving it switch-in opportunities on Rhydon and Piloswine. Yawn allows Uxie to avoid being setup fodder and force out entry hazard removers like Altaria, Articuno, and Coalossal and therefore keep Stealth Rock up. Knock Off lets Uxie remove important items like Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno, Cramorant, and Altaria and Eviolite from Piloswine, Rhydon, and Tangela. Future Sight lets Uxie's partners threaten their checks with the extra, delayed damage. Colbur Berry allows Uxie to counter Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr by weakening their Knock Off; it also lets Uxie take a hit from strong Dark-type wallbreakers such as Thievul, Silvally-Dark, and Shiftry and pivot out with a super effective U-turn.

Uxie can form a VoltTurn core with other pivots such as Alolan Persian, Rotom, and Silvally formes. Such cores are beneficial to wallbreakers that prefer safe switches like Silvally formes, Thievul, and Sawk. Dark-types like Silvally-Dark and Skuntank value Uxie's ability to wall Fighting-types like Sawk and can, in return, threaten Ghost-types like Gourgeist-S and Rotom. Physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan and Silvally formes appreciate Future Sight threatening physical walls such as Miltank, Qwilfish, and Tangela. Uxie lacks recovery and gets quickly worn down by Toxic; other walls like Clefairy and Qwilfish can absorb status and take attacks that Uxie can't afford to take. Clefairy also has Aromatherapy to cure Uxie of any status. Pokemon like Poliwrath and Jynx pressure hazard removers like Coalossal, Articuno, and Altaria, helping keep up Uxie's Stealth Rock.

Calm Mind.description:
Uxie finds a spot in Electric Terrain teams as a Calm Mind sweeper. Stored Power has insane power after Calm Mind and Electric Seed, letting Uxie break through bulkier foes like Articuno and Pyukumuku. Draining Kiss lets Uxie threaten Dark-types like Thievul and Silvally-Dark. Rest is Uxie's best form of recovery, also letting it deal with status from special walls like Articuno lacking Haze and Clefairy. The given spread allows Uxie to outspeed Timid Exeggutor.

Pincurchin is a necessary partner for Electric Surge. Other Electric Seed sweepers like Musharna, Swoobat, Drifblim, and Galarian Rapidash can weaken shared checks, forming a Calm Mind spam core. Electric-types like Raichu and Manectric also appreciate Electric Terrain and can break through special walls, making it easier for Uxie and the other Calm Mind users. In return, Uxie can set up on Ground-types that wall Raichu and Manectric thanks to Levitate.

Offense Lead.description:
Uxie's great Speed and amazing bulk make it a great supporter for offensive teams, being able to set Stealth Rock and then cripple the opposing Pokemon with Memento, Encore, or Yawn, giving switching and setup opportunities to teammates. Since this set isn't running any offensive move, Mental Herb is the preferred item to not get completely invalidated by Taunt users like Skuntank, Golbat, and Alolan Persian.

Setup spam offense teams really enjoy Uxie's role compression, creating setup opportunities and providing Stealth Rock. Therefore, offensive setup users like Crustle, Klinklang, and Silvally formes make for great partners. Pokemon that can advantage of Taunt users that Uxie invites in, such as Alcremie, Double Dance Rhydon, and Rotom-S, are appreciated. Gourgeist-S can prevent Rapid Spin attempts, while Taunt users like Skuntank and Qwilfish deny Defog.

Sun Setter.description:
Thanks to its great bulk and higher Speed than common Taunt users such as Skuntank, Qwilfish, and Sawk, Uxie is capable of reliably setting sun and Stealth Rock several times. U-turn brings sun attackers safely onto the field. Yawn forces out foes that would attempt to set up on Uxie such as Skuntank and Ninetales, which works well with Uxie's fast U-turn. Memento can alternatively be used to provide similar opportunities to Yawn and U-turn in one turn at the cost of sacrificing Uxie.

Sun sweepers such as Shiftry, Leafeon, Ivysaur, and Rapidash love Uxie's ability to reliably set sun. Prankster Liepard is a reliable secondary weather setter to support the team. An offensive sun setter such as Exeggutor creates more opportunities to set it up.

Trick Room Lead.description:
With its great bulk and access to both Trick Room and Stealth Rock, Uxie makes an ideal lead for Trick Room teams that can get both moves off, most of the time. Memento lets a teammate safely come in and take advantage of the remaining Trick Room turns. Knock Off gives Uxie an offensive move and breaks the Substitute of Rotom, which can be a huge threat to Trick Room teams. Magic Coat is an option to improve the matchup against Taunt and Encore users like Alolan Persian, Qwilfish, and Liepard, which can disrupt Uxie. Mental Herb is the preferred item, offering the same utility as Magic Coat without requiring using a move, while Red Card can force out attackers that would 2HKO Uxie like Silvally-Dark and Rotom.

This set only fits on full Trick room teams, so other Trick Room setters like Gourgeist-XL, Exeggutor, and Beheeyem make for great partners. Likewise, slow and powerful attackers such as Bouffalant, Pincurchin, and Rhydon make for great partners that take advantage of Trick Room, outspeeding the opposing team.

Regigigas.overview: Regigigas's appealing stats, movepool, and utility options are completely ruined by its ability, Slow Start, which halves its Attack and Speed for 5 turns every time it switches in. It is fully outclassed as an offensive Normal-type by Kangaskhan and Silvally and as a defensive Normal-type by Miltank.

RestTalk.description: This set aims to remove items with Knock Off, use Rest + Sleep Talk to get rid of Slow Start, and deal damage with STAB Body Slam while spreading paralysis. However, it gets outpaced by most of the metagame, often getting forced out before Slow Start is removed, and has no immediate offensive presence; furthermore, even after it gets going, Regigigas remains too weak to break through walls. Use Kangaskhan or Silvally, which do have a more immediate offensive presence and better abilities, or Miltank which is a significantly better defensive Pokemon.

Liepard.comments:
Other Options

Liepard has other useful support options like Taunt and Thunder Wave; however, it lacks room for them.

Checks and Counters

Fighting- and Fairy-types: Sawk, Poliwrath, and Alcremie take little from Liepard's moves and OHKO it back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr easily tanks Dark Pulse and OHKOes Liepard with Mach Punch after slight chip damage.

Special Walls: Nasty Plot sets need several boosts to break through special walls such as Articuno and Alcremie, which can stall Liepard with Toxic or outright OHKO it, respectively. However, they need to watch out for physical attacking sets.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Shiftry, Silvally-Dark, and Skuntank are immune to Prankster moves, resist Liepard's STAB moves, and defeat it with their secondary STAB or coverage moves. However, they have to watch out for U-turn.

Strong Attackers: Because of its poor bulk, Liepard gets OHKOed by strong attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Jynx. They force Liepard out unless it manages to lock them into unfavorable moves with Encore.

Sun Setter.description:
The combination of Prankster and Sunny Day lets Liepard act as an excellent mid-game sun setter. U-turn lets it pivot into a teammate that benefits from sun, such as Shiftry and Ivysaur. Knock Off helps Liepard further support its teammates by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno and Altaria. Encore locks foes such as Silvally-Poison and Uxie into unfavorable moves like Work Up and Stealth Rock, giving Liepard free turns to set up sun and pivot with U-turn. Heat Rock is necessary to provide as many sun turns as possible to Liepard's partners.

Liepard is a must-have on sun teams and is appreciated by sun sweepers such as Shiftry, Ivysaur, and Rapidash. Uxie's sun setter set also fits well on sun teams for its capacity to reliably set Stealth Rock and sun for its team. Furthermore, a third sun setter such as Exeggutor provides more possibilities to set up sun.

Nasty Plot.description:
Thanks to its high Speed tier and access to Nasty Plot and a pseudo-priority move in Prankster Copycat, Liepard separates itself from other Nasty Plot sweepers such as Skuntank and Alolan Persian. Copycat is mainly used to call Dark Pulse and prevent faster foes like Froslass, Choice Scarf Rotom, and Alolan Dugtrio from revenge killing a Nasty Plot-boosted Liepard. Encore provides Liepard setup opportunities by locking foes such as Piloswine and Articuno into undesirable moves. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on VoltTurn teams to help Liepard avoid entry hazards and potentially pivot. Black Glasses are an alternative that makes up for Liepard's average Special Attack, making it require less chip damage to clean.

VoltTurn support from pivots such as Uxie, Articuno, and Rotom helps Liepard come on the field in spite of its lackluster bulk. Special wallbreakers such as Exeggutor, Rotom, and Jynx can soften opposing special walls in order to let Liepard clean late game. Checks to Fighting-types such as Uxie, Qwilfish, and Altaria take on Sawk and Gurdurr, which force Liepard out. Likewise, checks to Fairy-types like Klinklang, Silvally-Poison, and Rapidash are great partners that handle Alcremie and Clefairy. Checks to Dark-types such as Alcremie, Gurdurr, and Sawk are also appreciated, as Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can take on Liepard. Kangaskhan is a threat because of Fake Out outprioritizing Copycat, letting it easily revenge kill a weakened Liepard; therefore, checks like Uxie, Tangela, and Cofagrigus are appreciated.

All-out Attacker.description:
With excellent Speed, STAB Knock Off, and great coverage choices, Liepard makes for a potent all-out attacker. U-turn pivots from switch-ins like Poliwrath, Tangela, and Alolan Persian. Prankster Copycat revenge kills naturally faster Pokemon and Choice Scarf Pokemon locked into certain moves, like Froslass, Alolan Dugtrio, and Choice Scarf Sawk and Rotom. Sucker Punch alongside Life Orb provides more consistent priority. Gunk Shot targets Alcremie and Tangela, while Play Rough hits incoming Fighting-types like Sawk, Throh, and Gurdurr. If Liepard chooses not to run Copycat, then Limber should be chosen to avoid paralysis from Stunfisk.

Liepard fits well on VoltTurn teams, being able to use Prankster Copycat to copy slow Volt Switches and U-turns. Pivots like Articuno, Thwackey, and Choice Scarf Rotom can work with it to wear down the opposition. Liepard's Knock Off helps cripple entry hazard removers like Articuno and Cryogonal, allowing Stealth Rock setters like Palossand and Rhydon to keep up hazards more consistently. While some of Liepard's checks, like Gurdurr and Tangela, hate losing their items to Knock Off and getting pivoted on by U-turn, Liepard can still struggle to break through them by itself. Special attackers, like Jynx and mixed Silvally-Poison, can ease its need for prediction and give it switch-ins to fall back on. Spikes setters like Qwilfish and Froslass can make Liepard increasingly difficult to switch into.

Unfezant.comments:
Other Options

A utility set with Heavy-Duty Boots, Roost, and Defog is feasible, as this set gives Unfezant reliable recovery and allows it to be an offensive entry hazard remover. However, the listed sets more naturally play to Unfezant's strengths, and this set struggles even more against hazard setters like Coalossal, Rhydon, and Qwilfish due to its reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots.

Checks and Counters

Rock- and Steel-types: Rhydon, Coalossal, and Klinklang resist Unfezant's STAB moves, fear none of its coverage, and threaten OHKOs or significant damage with their STAB moves. Rhydon and Coalossal can also set or remove entry hazards, and Coalossal's Flame Body deters Unfezant from pivoting or attacking. However, Perrserker and Klinklang can be worn down by the Choice Band set and fail to reliably switch in later on.

Stealth Rock: Unfezant’s weakness to Stealth Rock and recoil from Brave Bird quickly wear it down, causing it to faint rather quickly.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Rotom formes and Stunfisk can stomach a hit from both Unfezant sets and threaten to OHKO in return with their super effective STAB moves. Stunfisk also has Static to discourage Unfezant from pivoting with U-turn. However, Rotom must be aware of Night Slash from the Choice Band set.

Faster Offensive Threats: While none of them can safely switch in, Pokemon like Jynx, Rapidash, and Choice Scarf Sawk and Rotom can KO Choice Band Unfezant with minimal to no prior chip damage due to its mediocre bulk. However, they must also be aware of Choice Scarf sets, which they can't check.

Choice Band.description:
Unfezant is a powerful wallbreaker, able to devastate teams without sturdy Flying-resistant Pokemon such as Rhydon or Coalossal with Choice Band-boosted STAB Brave Bird. U-turn enables Unfezant to pivot out against Stunfisk, Piloswine, and Klinklang, keeping momentum and chipping them. Quick Attack finishes off weakened faster foes like Jynx and Accelgor. Night Slash lets Unfezant OHKO Rotom. Facade instead becomes a very powerful STAB move if Unfezant gets statused. Super Luck gives it better chances to break through Double Dance Alcremie if it has gained a Defense boost prior.

Unfezant fits well in offensive teams due to its great power, good Speed tier, and mediocre bulk. It struggles to break past sturdy Flying-resistant Pokemon like Klinklang and Coalossal and could potentially lose momentum against them. Water- and Electric-types pair particularly well, as Pokemon like Silvally-Water, Rotom, and Raichu can force them out with their STAB or coverage moves and bring Unfezant in safely with their pivot moves. In return, Unfezant can form a VoltTurn core with them and force out Grass-types such as Tangela and Gourgeist-S, which pressure them. Spikes users, such as Qwilfish and Coalossal, wear down its checks, many of which lack reliable recovery. Entry hazard control from the likes of Coalossal, Rotom, and Hattrem can ameliorate its Stealth Rock weakness. Special wallbreakers like Rotom, Exeggutor, and Jynx can overwhelm physical walls like Rhydon, Pyukumuku, and Miltank that Unfezant has difficulty breaking through. Other Flying-type wallbreakers, like Silvally-Flying and Rotom-S, can overwhelm their checks with repeated STAB Flying-type moves and coverage options.

Choice Scarf.description:
Unfezant also carves itself a niche on offensive teams as a fantastic revenge killer. It notably outspeeds and OHKOes two of the most prominent opposing Choice Scarf users, Rotom and Sawk, with Night Slash and Brave Bird, respectively. While Unfezant's main attack is its powerful STAB Brave Bird, it can also use U-turn to pivot out of unfavorable matchups such as Klinklang, Miltank, Rhydon, and Galarian Stunfisk. Facade provides Unfezant with a strong secondary STAB option once it becomes inflicted by status, as tends to happen, usually by a stray Toxic or Static paralyzation. Super Luck synergizes well with Night Slash and is useful for breaking through certain bulky setup sweepers like Acid Armor Alcremie and Kee Berry Uxie.

Choice Scarf Unfezant fits best on bulky offense teams that can wear down the opposing team so it can clean up. Unfezant can create a VoltTurn core with teammates such as Kabutops and Rotom that collectively weakens its checks. Unfezant could also create a Flying-type spam core with Silvally-Flying, which notably nails Rhydon and Coalossal with Surf. Unfezant also appreciates offensive teammates such as Rapidash and Poliwrath that can help combat Flying-resistant foes. Hattrem is a common sight on Flying-type spam teams, bouncing back Stealth Rock and nailing Rock-types or Steel-types with either Giga Drain or Mystical Fire. Because of Brave Bird recoil and Stealth Rock, as well as Unfezant's tendency to switch in multiple times per game, entry hazard removal from teammates such as Defog Rotom and Gurdurr is much appreciated.

Swoobat.comments:
Other Options

Taunt can be used over Roost to prevent Swoobat from getting hit with status, Haze, or forced out by Roar. Articuno and Rhydon are the most common users of these moves. Substitute can also be used to dodge status and makes Swoobat harder to revenge kill.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Silvally-Dark, Skunktank, and Morpeko can threaten Swoobat with their STAB attacks and are immune to Stored Power. Sableye and Liepard are notable threats, as they can Encore Swoobat into Calm Mind thanks to Prankster.

Haze and Phazers: Articuno and Cyogonal can Haze Swoobat, eliminating all of Swoobat's stat boosts. Rhydon and Articuno can also phaze out Swoobat with Roar.

Faster Threats: Choice Scarf Rotom, Manectric, and Kabutops outspeed Swoobat and can threaten Swoobat with their STAB attacks. Rotom and Manectric can also cripple Swoobat with Trick and Switcheroo respectively.

Terrain Sweeper.description:
Swoobat is a devastating sweeper in Terrain thanks to its great Speed tier and fantastic ability in Simple. Electric Seed boosts Swoobat's Defense significantly on switch-in, giving it much more physical bulk to ease setup, lessening its weakness to Knock Off, and providing it with an immunity to Poltergeist. Calm Mind boosts Swoobat's Special Attack and Special Defense, turning Stored Power into a destructive 140 Base Power move after a single use and Electric Seed's activation. Air Slash hits foes that resist or are immune to Psychic such as Uxie, Skuntank, and Silvally-Dark, while Heat Wave targets Klinklang, which resists both of Swoobat's STAB moves. Roost keeps Swoobat healthy, making it harder to revenge kill and giving it opportunities to set up multiple Calm Minds. The EV spread maximizes Swoobat's bulk and Speed, allowing it to always live Thunderbolt from Choice Scarf Rotom at +2 Special Defense after Stealth Rock damage.

Pincurchin is a mandatory teammate, as it provides Electric Terrain to trigger Swoobat's Electric Seed. It can also assist with Spikes support and provides a free turn of setup with Memento. Other beneficiaries of Electric Terrain such as Drifblim, Uxie, and Thievul make great partners, helping in wearing down shared checks, making it easier for Swoobat to sweep. Raichu and Manectric can also assist Swoobat by wallbreaking with boosted Rising Voltage and providing an immunity to Electric for the team. Pokemon that can pressure Dark- and Steel-types for Swoobat such as Sawk and Gurdurr also work well as teammates.

Gurdurr.comments:
Other Options

Defog is an option to turn Gurdurr into an entry hazard remover that poses good matchups against common entry hazard setters like Piloswine and Rhydon, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Stone Edge targets foes like Rotom-S, Altaria, and Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off removing their Heavy-Duty Boots, Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Cramorant can threaten to KO Gurdurr.

Physical Walls: Physical walls such as Altaria and Tangela are able to take hits from Gurdurr and pressure it with their STAB attacks. However, they should be wary of Knock Off. Alcremie is a notable foe that is able to take Gurdurr's STAB options and Knock Off and pressure it with its Fairy-type moves.

Chip Damage and Knock Off: It is easy to cripple and wear down Gurdurr, as it is reliant on Drain Punch recovery and Eviolite to check its foes.

Bulk Up.description:
Gurdurr is a notable tank in ZU thanks to its good bulk and access to decent recovery through Drain Punch. This recovery lets Gurdurr more consistently set up, letting it accumulate multiple boosts. Gurdurr can utilize Bulk Up mid- or late-game against passive foes like Stunfisk and Coalossal. Knock Off cripples switch-ins such as Tangela, Altaria, and Rotom-S. Mach Punch allows Gurdurr to revenge kill foes such as Shiftry and Kangaskhan. 252 HP and 60 Defense EVs ensure that Gurdurr will only be 3HKOed by Kangaskhan's Double-Edge. Guts lets Gurdurr absorb Will-O-Wisp from Rapidash and Toxic from Pyukumuku to empower its attacks.

Gurdurr fits on both bulky offense and balance teams due to its solid bulk and ability to generate pressure with both Bulk Up and Mach Punch. Gurdurr appreciates strong offensive support from its teammates to keep initiative throughout the battle, as it is otherwise prone to being worn down by common VoltTurn cores. Wallbreakers such as Rapidash, Silvally formes, and Thievul can threaten physical walls such as Tangela, Gourgeist-XL, and Qwilfish, enabling Gurdurr to better threaten them late-game. Pokemon such as Rotom and Exeggutor benefit from Gurdurr revenge killing foes such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry with Mach Punch; in return, they can threaten Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Cramorant that trouble it.

Throh.comments:
Other Options

Throh can run a wallbreaker set with Flame Orb and Facade; however, it lacks a spammable powerful STAB move, since it is limited to Superpower and Storm Throw. Additionally, Sawk and Silvally-Fighting are usually preferred for their higher Speed tiers and better wallbreaking capabilities. Throh can also attempt to use a Bulk Up set with either Mold Breaker or Guts, with the former giving it the ability to ignore Pyukumuku's Unaware; however, Gurdurr is better at this role due to having Drain Punch for recovery and Mach Punch for priority. A physically defensive set is more effective at checking the likes of Silvally formes, Sawk, and Kangaskhan, but Throh struggles to absorb status without a specially defensive spread.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Pokemon like Spiritomb, Rotom, and Gourgeist-XL are immune to Throh's STAB moves and can sponge Knock Off. Spiritomb can set up on Throh, while Rotom and Gourgeist-XL annoy it with status. However, Rotom should be careful switching into Knock Off.

Flying-types: Flying-types like Altaria, Rotom-S, and Cramorant resist Throh's STAB moves and can retaliate back with their super effective STAB moves. However, they despise losing their valuable Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types like Alcremie, Galarian Rapidash, and Shiinotic resist Throh's moves and can threaten it with their super effective STAB moves. Although Clefairy cannot break through Throh, it can cripple Throh with Knock Off or pivot with Teleport into a check.

Physical Wallbreakers: Even if Throh's physical bulk is far from lacking, its reliance on Rest lets it often get overwhelmed by physical wallbreakers like Froslass, Silvally formes, and Sawk.

Psychic-types: Psychic-types like Uxie, Swoobat, and Musharna resist Throh's STAB moves, don't take much from Knock Off, and threaten it with their STAB moves or Future Sight. Jynx can also break past Throh, but it cannot safely switch into Throh's attacks.

Special Wall.description:
Throh is a very bulky special wall that works especially well on Spikes-stacking teams. Circle Throw lets it phaze switch-ins, which pairs well with entry hazard support. Knock Off cripples checks like Altaria, Alcremie, and Tangela, hits Ghost-types like Rotom and Gourgeist-S, and removes Heavy-Duty Boots, which is appreciated on entry hazard-stacking teams. Rest is Throh's only form of recovery; thanks to Sleep Talk and Guts, Throh acts as a status absorber and lacks passivity while asleep. The given EV spread lets Throh outspeed uninvested base 50 Speed Pokemon such as Piloswine.

Throh appreciates entry hazard support a lot, especially Spikes from setters such as Qwilfish and Coalossal. Spinblockers like Rotom and Gourgeist formes and fast Taunt users like Alolan Persian, Golbat, and Qwilfish can keep up these entry hazards. Rapid Spin users such as Kabutops and Morpeko also make for great partners. Additionally, most of them help handle physical attackers Throh struggles to beat such as Sawk and Silvally-Poison. Despite being a good special wall, Throh appreciates being paired with Pokemon that can handle Volt Switch like Stunfisk and Manectric; they prevent it from getting chipped by Electric-types like Rotom, Manectric, and Raichu and losing momentum.

Sawk.comments:
Other Options

An Adamant nature can be run on its non-Choice Scarf sets to have a better chance to 2HKO Tangela lacking its Eviolite, however a Jolly nature is usually preferred to outspeed the likes of Timid Skuntank and Modest Thievul.

Poison Jab lets Sawk 2HKO Alcremie and Clefairy, but this requires giving up one of its other coverage moves, which generally isn't preferred because they target more Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Spiritomb, Gourgeist-XL, and Sableye can switch into any of Sawk's attacks with ease. Spiritomb can also set up on Sawk with Calm Mind.

Physical Walls: Tangela, Uxie, and Altaria can switch into Sawk and either cripple it with status or deal significant damage. However, Tangela and Altaria must be careful of switching into Knock Off and Stone Edge, respectively, as Choice Band and Black Belt Sawk can 2HKO Tangela lacking Eviolite and can KO Altaria with some prior chip damage. While Qwilfish must be wary of switching into Earthquake, it can easily switch into Close Combat and wear Sawk down with its Rocky Helmet.

Faster Threats: Rotom, Jynx, and Froslass can revenge kill Sawk once it's slightly worn down; however, none of them can directly switch into Sawk's attacks.

Choice Scarf.description:
With a solid Speed tier and its incredibly high attacking power, Sawk makes for an excellent revenge killer that fits well on offense and balance teams. Choice Scarf allows Sawk to threaten foes such as Alolan Persian, Kangaskhan, and Froslass. Knock Off targets Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Rotom, Gourgeist-S, and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Alcremie, Clefairy, and Tangela. Earthquake hits Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Skuntank. Stone Edge lets Sawk deal with Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Golbat. Mold Breaker allows Sawk to hit Levitate users such as Uxie and Rotom with Earthquake. Alternatively, Inner Focus allows Sawk to beat Qwilfish with Earthquake, as Inner Focus nullifies its Intimidate, and not flinch from Kangaskhan's Fake Out. However, don't expect to get free turns from Kangaskhan trying to flinch you, as the opponent should notice the absent Mold Breaker activation message.

While Sawk has super effective coverage for Pokemon that resist or are immune to Close Combat, it still needs physical walls such as Uxie, Tangela, and Altaria to be weakened in order to KO them and successfully clean. Therefore, special attackers such as Skuntank, Rotom, and Basculin that can deal with them make for great partners. Entry hazard setters such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Qwilfish help to wear down Sawk's common switch-ins, as most do not have access to reliable recovery. Pivots such as Uxie, Rotom-S, and Alolan Persian circumvent Sawk's mediocre bulk by safely bringing it onto the field, with the former also having access to Future Sight, which dissuades Poison-types from switching in.

Choice Band.description:
Choice Band Sawk forgoes Choice Scarf's increase in Speed for more wallbreaking power, letting Close Combat net 2HKOs on neutral physical walls like Pyukumuku and Gurdurr. Knock Off pressures Ghost- and Psychic-types like Rotom and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Tangela; Close Combat threatens a 2HKO on Tangela once its Eviolite has been removed. Earthquake punishes Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison, while Stone Edge nails Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Altaria.

Choice Band Sawk is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster Flying- and Psychic-types such as Rotom-S and Jynx, so switch-ins such as Rhydon and Articuno are appreciated. These Pokemon also have the added benefit of providing entry hazards to help wear down its switch-ins. Special setup sweepers such as Ninetales and Alcremie benefit greatly from Sawk's ability to break past specially defensive walls such as Coalossal and Miltank. Sawk also appreciates the removal of Ghost-types, so pairing it with Dark-types like Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian is a good idea. Future Sight Uxie is a great partner, as it punishes the physical walls such as Tangela and Altaria that switch in on Sawk and can also pivot Sawk in safely with U-turn. Sawk can also weaken the aforementioned walls into the KO range of physical cleaners like Rapidash and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

All-Out Attacker.description:
With its all-out attacker set, Sawk can bluff a Choice item and surprise its foe with a powerful Black Belt-boosted Close Combat or a super effective coverage move. Knock Off targets Ghost- and Psychic-types like Rotom, Froslass, and Exeggutor, while also crippling checks like Altaria and Tangela. Stone Edge handles Flying-types like Altaria, Rotom-S, and Articuno, whereas Poison Jab deals significant damage to Fairy-types like Alcremie, Clefairy, and Galarian Rapidash. Earthquake lets Sawk break Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison. Black Belt 2HKOes Tangela lacking Eviolite with Close Combat after Stealth Rock. Mold Breaker lets Sawk use Earthquake on Levitate users like Rotom and Uxie, while Inner Focus makes it immune to Qwilfish's Intimidate and prevents Kangaskhan from chipping it down with Fake Out.

All-out attacking Sawk can cripple and weaken physical walls like Tangela, Poliwrath, and Altaria to open a way for physical sweepers like Swords Dance Lycanroc-N, Shift Gear Klinklang, and Thwackey. Pivots like Rotom, Clefairy, and Alolan Persian can bring Sawk safely on to the field. Entry hazard setters like Froslass, Piloswine, and Rhydon can force out Sawk's checks like Altaria, Alcremie, and Silvally-Poison and help Sawk wallbreak, while Sawk can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from its checks with Knock Off to make entry hazards more effective against them.

Lilligant.comments:
Other Options

Lilligant can utilize Choice Specs to dish out strong Petal Dances without the fear of confusion due to Own Tempo. Choice Specs Lilligant also has a free moveslot for Healing Wish, one of the best support moves in the game. However, Lilligant still struggles to break through the same Grass-resistant Pokemon it did before and cannot incapacitate them with sleep.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Articuno and Altaria counter Lilligant due to their superb special bulk and, in Altaria’s case, its 4x resistance to Grass and Natural Cure. Other Flying-types such as Silvally-Flying and Rotom-S still fair quite well, although they are more prone to being overwhelmed by Lilligant due to their lack of longevity and, in the case of Silvally-Flying, its lack of Heavy-Duty Boots.

Fire- and Poison-types: Fire- and Poison-types such as Rapidash, Ninetales, and Silvally-Poison resist both Giga Drain and Pollen Puff. However, Lilligant is able to overwhelm them with a few Quiver Dance boots.

Klinklang: Klinklang also resists all of Lilligant’s attacks and is an excellent sleep absorber on Choice sets that utilize Sleep Talk as a fourth move. Klinklang doesn’t have any reliable recovery options, so it must be kept reasonably healthy to reliably check Lilligant.

Sap Sipper: Sap Sipper Miltank and Bouffalant are immune to Lilligant’s Grass moves and can either put Lilligant on a timer with Toxic or outright KO it.

Revenge Killers: Lilligant is slower than most Choice Scarf users such as Manectric, Gourgeist-S, and Jynx after a Quiver Dance and is prone to being easily revenge killed.

Quiver Dance.description:
Lilligant is a niche Quiver Dance sweeper that capitalizes on Sleep Powder generating one or two free turns to boost and break through the opposing team. Pollen Puff nails opposing Grass-types such as Appletun, Exeggutor, and Tangela. Life Orb gives Lilligant more firepower, which it desperately needs; however, Leftovers provides Lilligant with passive recovery, which can help it acquire Quiver Dance boosts against more passive foes such as Galarian Stunfisk. While this set isn't intended to take advantage of Chlorophyll, Lilligant provides some counterplay versus opposing sun sweepers, notably Shiftry.

Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr do a fantastic job of scaring out Klinklang, one of Lilligant's biggest checks, and can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from Flying-types such as Articuno and Altaria. Similarly, Ice-types such as Jynx and Froslass force out opposing Flying-types and can help Lilligant chip away at Klinklang and Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales. Both examples of offensive partners, however, result in overlapping weaknesses, limiting Lilligant's use to only offensive teams. Entry hazard setters such as Uxie, Qwilfish, and Froslass can provide Lilligant with the necessary chip damage needed to whittle down foes it struggles against. Pokemon such as Silvally-Dark and Choice Scarf Kabutops can also offensively pressure common Defog users for Lilligant.

Crustle.comments:
Other Options

Crustle can perform as a suicide lead on hyper offense teams thanks to having both Stealth Rock and Spikes. This set also runs Knock Off and Rock Blast, which beats suicide leads that depend on Focus Sash such as Froslass and Accelgor.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Physical walls such as Poliwrath, Sableye, and Gourgeist-XL can all survive a hit from Crustle, with the Ghost-types being able to cripple it with Will-O-Wisp. Poliwrath takes less than 50% at +2 and can OHKO in return with Scald. Pyukumuku hard counters Crustle thanks to its great bulk paired with Unaware.

Fighting-types: Gurdurr and Throh resist Crustle's STAB attacks, surviving +2 attacks with ease. Gurdurr can 2HKO with Drain Punch, while Throh can phaze it with Circle Throw.

Revenge Killers: Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Rotom can outspeed and revenge kill Crustle, even at +2 Speed. Thwackey can also revenge kill thanks to priority in Grassy Glide. Sturdy needs to be broken, however, in order for them to revenge kill.

Shell Smash.description:
Thanks to the combination of Sturdy and Heavy-Duty Boots, Crustle is almost always able to set up a Shell Smash. This allows Crustle to be a niche late-game cleaner, outspeeding the entire unboosted metagame apart from Accelgor. However, Crustle is susceptible to common Choice Scarf users in Rotom and Sawk. Stone Edge is Crustle's strongest move, hitting physical walls like Altaria and Miltank the hardest. X-Scissor provides coverage for other walls like Uxie, Tangela, and Alolan Persian, in addition to being the strongest accurate move. Earthquake covers Klinklang, Stunfisk, and Rhydon.

Crustle fits well on offense teams and is best saved for a late-game sweep once its checks are weakened or removed. Defensive checks include Poliwrath, Sableye, and Gurdurr, but teammates such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry can help weaken and pressure them. Offensive checks, on the other hand, include common revenge killers in Choice Scarf Sawk, Choice Scarf Rotom, and Thwackey. Sturdy needs to be broken first, however, for them to revenge kill Crustle. Other partners that can aid Crustle's cleaning chances are the aforementioned Sawk and Thwackey, as they weaken physical walls such as Tangela and Qwilfish. Crustle also works well on setup spam teams, as they can overwhelm defensive checks; partners on them include Klinklang, Qwilfish, and Silvally formes. Healing Wish support from Pokemon such as Hattrem and Galarian Rapidash works well on offense teams, giving Crustle a second chance of sweeping.

Cofagrigus.comments:
Other Options

Cofagrigus can run Nasty Plot instead of Iron Defense to better threaten physical walls like Tangela and Qwilfish; however, Nasty Plot can be hard to justify because it severely weakens the matchup against Miltank and makes Cofagrigus far easier to revenge kill. Cofagrigus can replace Rest with Trick Room to beat checks like Rotom and Thievul, or Substitute to evade status, but these options reduce Cofagrigus's overall durability. Another option for Cofagrigus is a utility set with its many excellent support options such as Will-O-Wisp, Toxic Spikes, Knock Off, Hex, and Pain Split, but it faces tough competition from Qwilfish and Roselia. Lastly, Cofagrigus can run Sleep Talk over Iron Defense on Rest sets to not completely waste 2 turns sleeping; however, this voids its sweeping potential.

Checks and Counters

Ghost- and Dark-types: Pokemon like Sableye and Spiritomb are immune to Body Press and neutral to Shadow Ball, so they can Encore or set up on Cofagrigus. Spiritomb, however, has to be wary of Nasty Plot. Other common Ghost- and Dark-types such as Silvally-Dark, Rotom, and Skuntank are only checks due to taking significant damage from either Body Press or Shadow Ball, but they can outspeed and do significant damage to Cofagrigus.

Alcremie: Alcremie outspeeds Cofagrigus and resists its Body Press. Once Alcremie enters the playing field it can freely set up Calm Mind, thus countering Cofagrigus.

Special Wallbreakers: Strong special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Manectric and Exeggutor can outspeed and threaten Cofagrigus with a 2HKO and OHKO respectively.

Setup Deterrents: Unaware Pyukumuku ignores the Defense boost from Body Press, heals off the negligible damage it does take, and can use Toxic on Cofagrigus; it can then Spite to remove Cofagrigus’s Rest PP. Other setup deterrents such as Encore from Liepard and Taunt from Qwilfish and Alolan Persian can stop Cofagrigus in its tracks. Perish Song Altaria can also trap and defeat Cofagrigus.

Status: Toxic from Altaria and Stunfisk can force Cofagrigus to Rest, while Tangela can use Sleep Powder. Once Cofagrigus falls asleep, a check can safely be brought in to beat it.

IronPress.description:
Cofagrigus is a frightening IronPress sweeper that is able to find setup opportunities against physical attackers such as Sawk, Gurdurr, and Rhydon as well as common walls like Cryogonal and Galarian Stunfisk. Shadow Ball covers for the Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Uxie and Palossand and physical walls like Tangela and Qwilfish that its main offensive move in Body Press does not threaten. Rest is Cofagrigus's most reliable form of recovery and removes status. 84 Speed EVs allow Cofagrigus to outspeed Rhydon and Gurdurr. A Colbur Berry allows Cofagrigus to eat strong Dark moves like Silvally-Dark's Multi-Attack and Thievul's Dark Pulse, while a Chesto Berry prevents Cofagrigus from wasting two turns sleeping.

Cofagrigus generally fits best on bulkier builds in need of a defensive sweeper. Cofagrigus appreciates Dark resistant-teammates like Skuntank, Silvally-Fighting and especially Alcremie due to its ability to cure status via Aromatherapy. It also appreciates a solid special wall, like Articuno or Clefairy. Spikes setters such as Qwilfish and Coalossal make it harder for Cofagrigus to be pivoted around. Cofagrigus can also appreciate physical walls like Tangela and Altaria to help it avoid hits from Gourgeist formes and common Toxic users.

Carracosta.comments:
Other Options

Carracosta can run Heavy-Duty Boots and Sturdy to guarantee the use of Shell Smash. However, Solid Rock is usually more useful as an ability and it lets Carracosta use less situational items. Lum Berry is another option that lets Carracosta set up more safely against passive walls like Miltank, Rapidash, and Altaria.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Most Grass-types including Tangela, Lurantis, and Gourgeist formes outspeed Carracosta and OHKO it with their super effective STAB moves. However, they cannot freely switch into it, as they take huge damage from Ice Beam and Stone Edge after a Shell Smash. Thwackey and Choice Scarf Gourgeist-S are notable examples, as they can both even revenge kill Carracosta even after a Shell Smash.

Bulky Fighting-types: Poliwrath resists every move from Carracosta and can nail it with its super effective STAB moves. Throh and Gurdurr have a harder time handling Hydro Pump variants, but the former can phaze Carracosta, while the later can beat a boosted Carracosta with the combination of Drain Punch and Mach Punch.

Fast Attackers: Choice Scarf users like Sawk, Manectric, and Rotom, and naturally fast attackers like Alolan Persian and Accelgor can outspeed Carracosta after a Shell Smash and revenge kill it. However, the frailer ones have to stay healthy enough to avoid being put into Aqua Jet range from entry hazards.

Strong Attackers: Due to its poor Speed tier, common weaknesses, and middling special bulk, many attackers including Jynx, Sawk, and Thievul can easily outspeed and OHKO Carracosta before it gets a chance to set up.

Shell Smash.description:
Carracosta is a niche but deadly Shell Smash sweeper. Aqua Jet lets it pick off weakened threats that outspeed Carracosta after a Shell Smash like Choice Scarf Rotom and Accelgor. Ice Beam lets it nail Grass-types like Tangela and Gourgeist formes, while Hydro Pump is an additional STAB move that lets it hit harder against Rock-resistant foes and physical walls like Klinklang and Cofagrigus. Solid Rock combined with Carracosta's solid bulk lets it set up on foes carrying super effective moves like Rhydon, Articuno, and Cofagrigus. With Life Orb, Carracosta needs less preliminary damage on foes like Choice Scarf Rotom and Miltank to clean after a Shell Smash. On the flip side, White Herb makes Carracosta harder to KO, as it allows it to take hits better from the likes of Alolan Persian's Foul Play and avoid recoil and Defense drops. With a Naive nature, Carracosta is able to outspeed the likes of maximum Speed Miltank, Gourgeist-S, and Galarian Rapidash after a Shell Smash, and nuke them with Stone Edge, whereas a Naughty nature provides stronger damage on Aqua Jet, requiring less chip damage on Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom.

Carracosta fits best on offensive teams, most notably on setup spam teams with other wallbreakers such as Silvally-Dark and Galarian Rapidash that can weaken or take advantage of its checks. Spikes support from the likes of Qwilfish, Roselia, and Froslass is much appreciated to put walls and Choice Scarf users in range of Stone Edge and Aqua Jet, respectively. Flame Body users like Coalossal and Rapidash make also for great partners, as they can cripple Thwackey and Choice Scarf Gourgeist with a burn, preventing them from reliably revenge killing Carracosta. Taunt users like the aforementionned Qwilfish and Froslass, Alolan Persian, and Skuntank can create setup opportunities for Carracosta against more passive walls and also prevent them from recovering preliminary damage needed for Carracosta's sweep. Dark-types like Morpeko and Silvally-Dark are able to weaken Fighting-types like Poliwrath and Gurdurr, putting them in range of Carracosta's attacks.

Emolga.overview: If you really want to use Emolga in ZU, consider playing BW where it is a top threat. In SS, however, Emolga's stats are underwhelming; it is both too weak to break anything and too frail to use its great typing for defensive purposes. It is outclassed as an offensive Electric-type by Rotom and Manectric, as a Flying-type pivot by Articuno, and as a fast pivot by Alolan Persian; there is truly nothing to save about this flying rat.

Offensive Utility.description: Emolga attemps to make some progress by removing items from opposing walls and generating momentum with U-turn. This set is highly inconsistent because Emolga is both too slow and too weak to force anything out, unless it's been very chipped, and it is too frail to switch into most threats in the tier. Alolan Persian and Rapidash are much more consistent as offensive utility options due to their superior stats, while Palossand, Rhydon, and Stunfisk are better Electric immunities. Will-O-Wisp Rotom is better as a Ground-immune, Electric-type offensive utility option, while Alolan Persian is a more effective fast pivot with access to Knock Off and a better Speed tier. These two also aren't crippled much by entry hazards, unlike Emolga, whose strongest STAB move in Acrobatic is anti-synergistic with Heavy-Duty Boots.

Klinklang.comments:
Other Options

Klinklang can run a Choice Specs set to surprise its checks, as a fully-invested Volt Switch can heavily damage switch-ins like Rapidash and Poliwrath. It also has Power Gem for surprising Rapidash, and Steel Beam as a powerful nuke. Unfortunately, it doesn't have a particularly high Special Attack, leaving it outclassed by other bulky Choice Specs wallbreakers, like Poliwrath and Exeggutor.

Checks and Counters

Electric-type Pokemon: Stunfisk can use its typing and bulk to consistently switch into Klinklang. Static also dissuades Klinklang from using Gear Grind. If used carelessly, though, Toxic can cripple it. Other Electric-types like the Rotom formes, Morpeko, Raichu, and Manectric can check Klinklang offensively. The Rotom formes can inflict burn, Morpeko is able to accumulate Speed boosts with its powerful Aura Wheel, and the latter two have higher Speed and super effective coverage.

Fire-type Pokemon: Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales can switch into Klinklang's Gear Grind and retaliate with a super effective attack, so long as they watch out for Toxic and Wild Charge. Rapidash and Coalossal have the added bonus of potentially burning Klinklang with Flame Body, although the latter is a less consistent switch in.

Fighting-type Pokemon: With its weakness to Fighting-types, Klinklang is forced out by threats like Sawk and Throh. Gurdurr can shrug off boosted attacks and fire back with Drain Punch and can even revenge kill a weakened Klinklang with Mach Punch. While it must be wary of Electric moves, defensive Poliwrath easily handles Gear Grind and can stop a sweep with Circle Throw. Choice Specs variants also effortlessly revenge kill it with Vacuum Wave.

Steel-type Pokemon: Klinklang has a hard time getting past Steel-types, including opposing Klinklang. Because of its typing, Alolan Dugtrio is able to switch in and KO Klinklang despite its frailty. Galarian Stunfisk, while niche compared to regular Stunfisk, is even more physically bulky and is immune to Toxic.

Alolan Persian: Thanks to its high Speed, insane physical bulk, and access to Foul Play, Alolan Persian is able to take a hit and threaten Klinklang. Its lack of recovery means that it can get worn down from repeated hits, though.

Sableye: With its access to Foul Play and Prankster Will-O-Wisp, Sableye can frustrate Shift Gear Klinklang. However, its low bulk makes it vulnerable against Choice Band variants.

Rocky Helmet: Qwilfish and Miltank, while not great answers, can significantly weaken Klinklang with Rocky Helmet's chip damage. This makes it significantly harder for Klinklang to successfully sweep through a team.

Shift Gear Sweeper.description:
Thanks to its great stats, amazing typing, and access to Shift Gear, Klinklang is one of the most terrifying sweepers in ZU. After a boost, its STAB Gear Grind breaks through most defensive Pokemon, including prominent walls like Articuno and Alcremie. Even neutral targets like Altaria, Tangela, and Uxie are used as setup fodder due to Klinklang's Steel typing. Klinklang can use Substitute to block weaker hits and status, but Magnet Rise is an option to avoid Earthquake from Rhydon and Alolan Dugtrio. Toxic cripples the few counters that Klinklang has, including Rapidash, Alolan Persian, Sableye, and Stunfisk. Alternatively, Wild Charge hits Water-types like Qwilfish, Poliwrath, and Cramorant. With 156 Speed EVs, Klinklang outspeeds Choice Scarf Manectric after a Shift Gear boost. The additional EVs are invested in bulk, making it even more difficult for revenge killers like Thwackey and Kangaskhan to pick it off at low health.

Klinklang fits on almost all types of teams, ranging from semi-stall to hyper offense, but is at its best when its counters get crippled over the long run. As a result, Toxic users like Miltank, Altaria, and Clefairy greatly assist Klinklang in wearing down counters like Rapidash and Stunfisk. In return, Klinklang threatens clerics like Alcremie and Articuno. Miltank and Clefairy also provide their own cleric support, healing Klinklang of any status it gets from Flame Body or Static. Klinklang also appreciates Knock Off support, removing crucial items from Rhydon and Tangela, as well as eliminating the chip damage from Rocky Helmet Miltank and Poliwrath. Thwackey, Alolan Persian, and Uxie are all good partners thanks to their ability to use Knock Off against Klinklang's checks. Gurdurr is a particularly good Knock Off partner, as Klinklang counters Gurdurr's biggest checks like Alcremie and Altaria.

Choice Band.description:
Klinklang's bulk and typing allow it to come in and fire off instantly powerful attacks, making it a versatile wallbreaker and pivot. As a Steel-type with solid bulk, Klinklang can directly switch into passive attacks from the likes of Articuno and Hurricane Altaria; it also comes in on Choice-locked wallbreakers like Thwackey, Froslass, and Gourgeist-S. Choice Band gives it the strength to immediately threaten walls like Alolan Persian, Rhydon, and Spiritomb. Wild Charge punishes bulky Water-types like Poliwrath, Qwilfish, and Pyukumuku, and Volt Switch provides useful pivoting for other switch-ins including Rapidash and Gurdurr. Facade is useful for doing meaningful damage to Stunfisk, especially if it gets afflicted with paralysis or burn. Toxic is also great on Choice Band sets to cripple switch-ins like the aforementioned Rapidash and Stunfisk.

Choice Band sets typically fit on more offensively-inclined teams looking for a physical wallbreaker that can switch into weak attacks. Its plethora of resistances help keep defensive partners like Poliwrath, Alcremie, and Tangela healthy. Those teammates can handle Fire-, Fighting-, and Ground-type attacks for Klinklang in return. Its offensive capabilities are further accentuated by chip damage, so entry hazards from Pokemon like Rhydon and Piloswine are helpful. They make especially useful partners, as they threaten Klinklang's biggest checks like Rapidash and Stunfisk. Spikes support from Qwilfish or Coalossal also helps rack up damage. VoltTurn wallbreakers including Rotom, Thwackey, and the Silvally formes can further add momentum with their pivoting. This constant damage is also helpful for fast cleaners like Galarian Rapidash, Froslass, and Choice Scarf Sawk, who appreciate the wallbreaking ability of Choice Band Klinklang. Although it does have good Speed, Klinklang gets outsped and OHKOed by Pokemon like Alolan Dugtrio and Ninetales, so revenge killers like Froslass and Manectric are essential for supporting Klinklang offensively.

Beheeyem.comments:
Other Options

Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots are options over Colbur Berry on the bulky sets; however, forgoing Colbur Berry makes Beheeyem very hard to use against Dark-types and jeopardizes its ability to check Fighting-types like Sawk and Gurdurr.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: The likes of Silvally-Dark, Skuntank, and Thievul can threaten Beheeyem with their super effective STAB moves. However, they still have to fear Nasty Plot and Analytic-boosted Thunderbolt and Meteor Beam, which can both eliminate Dark-types after preliminary damage. This is especially true if Trick Room is up or Colbur Berry hasn't been consumed, as Dark-types cannot threaten out Beheeyem in these situation. Shiftry is a notorious example that said, since it resists Thunderbolt and can threaten Beheeyem through Trick Room with Sucker Punch.

Steel-types: Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio resist most of Beheeyem's moves and can threaten Beheeyem with their SubTox sets, even if they huge damage from Beheeyem's Thunderbolt and Psychic, respectively.

Special Walls: Special walls like Clefairy and Stunfisk can take a hit from Beheeyem and stall out Trick Room turns with their terrific bulk. However, bulkier sets can take advantage of them. Nasty Plot Beheeyem can easily set up against them and stave off damage with Recover—though it still is chipped significantly by Toxic—while the Future Sight pivot set can punish them with Synchronize and safely use the combination of Future Sight and Recover to bring in a partner.

Faster Wallbreakers: Without Trick Room, Beheeyem's merely passable bulk and poor defensive typing leave it very vulnerable to strong Pokemon that can outspeed it, such as Rotom, Thwackey, and Jynx.

Future Sight Pivot.description:
Beheeyem acts as a defensive pivot that is able to use Future Sight and then pivot out into a partner with Teleport. Recover gives it sustainability, letting it switch reliably and constantly into walls and weaker attackers such as Tangela, Miltank, and Gurdurr. Thunderbolt is Beheeyem's best coverage option against Dark-types like Skuntank and Thievul; it also allows it to directly threaten foes like Qwilfish and Klinklang. Colbur Berry lets it take on Fighting-types like Sawk and Gurdurr which would hit it super effectively with Knock Off while also letting it pivot out against strong Dark-types like Shiftry and Silvally-Dark. Synchronize punishes Toxic users such as Miltank and Stunfisk that would try to beat Beheeyem.

Beheeyem works best on balance teams with physical wallbreakers like Silvally-Dark, Lycanroc-N, and Sawk. Thanks to Future Sight, physical attackers can break through their checks like Palossand, Tangela, and Qwilfish, making it almost impossible to wall them. Beheeyem, however, is not a great wall, so it needs to be supported with other defensive Pokemon like Tangela, Altaria, Articuno, and Stunfisk that can wall powerful attackers such as the Silvally formes, Exeggutor, and Rotom that easily break through Beheeyem. Having a cleric such as Miltank or Alcremie is particularly important to reset Synchronize. Dark-type checks such as Throh, Skuntank, and Clefairy are also appreciated, because Colbur Berry isn't enough to mitigate Beheeyem's glaring weakness to them.

Nasty Plot.description:
Beheeyem acts as a defensive sweeper with Nasty Plot, able to stomach powerful hits, sit on passive walls thanks to Recover, and retaliate back with powerful Analytic-boosted STAB Psychic. Thunderbolt hits common Psychic-resistant or immune foes such as Klinklang, Galarian Rapidash, and Skuntank for neutral damage while also dealing significant damage to Articuno, one of the most common special walls. Colbur Berry lets it handle Fighting-types with Knock Off like Sawk and Gurdurr and prevent Dark-types like Skuntank and Silvally-Dark from forcing it out with their super effective STAB moves.

This set works best on balance teams looking for a stallbreaker. Beheeyem works best when paired with an additional physical wall such as Tangela or Miltank to assist it versus strong physical attackers like Silvally-Dark, Thwackey, and Rhydon. Throh and Stunfisk make also for great partners, both being able to answer Rotom and Skuntank, which force out Beheeyem. Clerics like Miltank, Clefairy, and Articuno also make for great partners, taking care of Beheeyem's weakness to Toxic from passive walls such as Miltank and Stunfisk. Physical wallbreakers like the Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Perrserker make for great partners that can take advantage of the special walls that Beheeyem forces in. Fast but weak attackers like Rapidash, Alolan Dugtrio, and Throat Spray Accelgor appreciate Beheeyem weakening opposing walls into their KO ranges.

Offensive Trick Room.description:
Thanks to Beheeyem's sky-high Special Attack stat, terrible Speed stat, and access to Trick Room, it is a staple on said archetype. Meteor Beam OHKOes Pokemon that can switch into Psychic like Alolan Persian, Skuntank, and Thievul, OHKOes specially defensive Pokemon like Articuno and Coalossal, and boosts its Special Attack stat without wasting a Trick Room turn on setup when used with Power Herb. Thunderbolt OHKOes Cramorant while 2HKOing Articuno at +1. It is also Beheeyem's strongest spammable option against Dark- and Steel-types. Analytic takes advantage of how well Beheeyem forces switches, and it exploits Beeheeyem's very low Speed in the rare instances it attacks outside of Trick Room.

Due to Beheeyem's awful Speed, poor defensive typing, and merely decent bulk, it should mainly be used on dedicated Trick Room teams, as otherwise other Psychic-types and special wallbreakers outclass it. Other Trick Room setters, like Gourgeist-XL, Uxie, and Trevenant, can provide more chances for Beheeyem to attack without needing to set up Trick Room first, and teammates that lack Trick Room especially appreciate these chances. These teammates include Bouffalant, Flame Orb Throh, and Rhydon, which benefit from Beheeyem's wallbreaking and Trick Room, enabling them to more easily break holes against the opposition or clean late-game.

Cryogonal.comments:
Other Options

Defog can remove hazards in front of Ghost-types at the cost of removing its own. Haze is useful against special setup sweepers such as Skuntank, Alcremie, and Nasty Plot Rotom. Toxic is an option to cripple bulky foes such as Articuno, Miltank, and Rapidash. However, Knock Off is usually more reliable at it; it can also help pressure other spinblockers like Sableye, Cofagrigus, and Froslass.

Checks and Counters

Physical Attackers: Physical attackers such as Morpeko, Lycanroc-N, and Silvally formes threaten Cryogonal due to its low physical bulk.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, and Throh, can tank Freeze-Dry and threaten Cryogonal back with their STAB moves.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash resist Freeze-Dry and can force Cryogonal out.

Steel-types: Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio tank Freeze-Dry and can retaliate with their STAB attacks. However, they do not appreciate taking a Knock Off.

Item Removal: Knock Off users like Uxie, Alolan Persian and Clefairy and Trick users like Rotom and Jynx can threaten to cripple Cryogonal by removing its Heavy-Duty Boots, which makes it vulnerable to Stealth Rock and lowers its ability to switch in.

Special Wall.description:
Cryogonal is one of the best Rapid Spinners in the metagame thanks to its great special bulk and Speed. Cryogonal also performs well as a specially defensive wall and hazard remover, checking prevalent special attackers such as Articuno, Rotom formes, and Jynx. It has access to reliable recovery in Recover and great utility with the combination of Knock Off and Rapid Spin.

Cryogonal's low Defense stat and poor defensive typing make it vulnerable to a majority of physical attackers. Altaria can help Cryogonal check both Fire- and Fighting-type moves. Tangela can also check physical attackers such as Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Gurdurr, which force out Cryogonal. In return, Cryogonal counters special attackers such as Rotom formes and Appletun. On balance builds, Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash are great partners for Cryogonal, handling Steel-types such as Klinklang and Pawniard; in return, Cryogonal is able to pressure its checks such as Altaria and bulky Water-types like Qwilfish. Water-types like Qwilfish and Poliwrath help check Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales, which annoy Cryogonal. Bulky Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Throh also pair well with Cryogonal, threatening Steel-types.

Accelgor.comments:
Other Options

Choice Specs turns Accelgor into a threatening wallbreaker, outspeeding the whole unboosted tier. However, its STAB move is commonly resisted by a large portion of the tier, making it heavily reliant on predictions. In addition, it struggles to enter the field safely due to its susceptibility to hazards and frailty, making Accelgor hard to justify over more relevant special wallbreakers like Jynx, Rotom, and Thievul. A Heavy-Duty Boots set with Spikes and either Knock Off or U-turn are options on a utility set; however, Accelgor loses against most Defog users since it is frail and its coverage moves are inadequate to deal with them.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Accelgor struggles to threaten bulky Flying-types like Articuno, Altaria, Cramorant, and Golbat without extensive prior damage; in turn, they can easily defeat it with their STAB moves or remove entry hazards in front of it. Rotom-S and Silvally-Flying can take a hit from Accelgor if necessary but cannot switch in safely.

Fire-types: Fire-types like Rapidash, Ninetales, and Coalossal can threaten it out with their respective STAB moves, though the latter dislikes switching into Focus Blast.

Silvally-Poison: Silvally-Poison resists anything Accelgor can throw at and can deal heavy damage back, and is bulky enough to switch into it multiple times throughout a game.

Choice Scarf and Priority Users: If Accelgor hasn't activated Unburden, Choice Scarf users like Sawk, Manectric, and Silvally can outspeed and defeat it, though they are unable to switch in safely. Priority users like Kangaskhan, Choice Band Thwackey, and Piloswine can also finish it off if Accelgor has been weakened enough.

Throat Spray.description:
Bug Buzz triggers Throat Spray, not only giving it a +1 boost to its Special Attack, but also outspeeding every Pokemon in the metagame thanks to Unburden. This allows it to operate as a lethal late-game cleaner. Focus Blast targets Klinklang and Piloswine, OHKOing the former without a boost and the latter after Stealth Rock or a boost. Sludge Bomb breaks through Clefairy and Alcremie while crippling switch-ins, such as Altaria and Articuno. Giga Drain threatens walls like Rhydon, Palossand, and Qwilfish, 2HKOing all of them while providing recovery. The given EV spread allows Accelgor to outpace Alolan Persian before activating Unburden.

Accelgor appreciates having bulky Flying-types like Articuno, Altaria, and Golbat removed before attempting to sweep, as they can wall it without too much trouble. Pokemon like Rotom, Klinklang, and Lycanroc-N can switch in and pressure the aforementioned defensive Pokemon. Choice Scarf Pokemon like Sawk and Manectric outspeed and OHKO Accelgor before it can activate Unburden, so Pokemon that can switch into them, such as Palossand, Tangela, and Rhydon, can help stomach their blows while simultaneously providing early- to mid-game utility. Accelgor cannot OHKO Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales even when boosted, so it appreciates Knock Off support from users like Sawk, Thwackey, and Tangela to weaken them into KO range; they also help against the aforementioned Flying-types.

Suicide Lead.description:
Boasting the fastest Speed tier and a strong utility movepool, Accelgor is a potent Spikes lead. Final Gambit can be used to block and heavily weaken Defog and Rapid Spin users like Altaria, Cramorant, and Coalossal at the cost of sacrificing Accelgor. Encore can discourage sweepers like Gurdurr, Silvally-Poison, and Rapidash from setting up in front of it. Yawn discourages other leads like Froslass and opposing Accelgor from setting up their own entry hazards. Infestation traps passive Pokemon like Stunfisk and Clefairy trying to provide utility early-game; it can then lock these Pokemon into their status moves with Encore and set up multiple layers of Spikes reliably. Focus Sash allows Accelgor to be nearly guaranteed to set up a layer of Spikes, while Unburden allows Accelgor to outspeed the entire metagame after being hit with Knock Off or losing its Focus Sash. Sticky Hold is an alternative that prevents it from getting hit by Trick.

Accelgor is best suited as the lead slot on offense and hyper offense builds, where offensive Pokemon can capitalize on the entry hazards it sets. Setup sweepers such as Klinklang, Swords Dance Silvally formes, and Galarian Rapidash can pressure foes into either switching to a check or risking a trade with a Defogger like Altaria or Articuno. Pawniard can switch into most Defoggers and threaten them with a Defiant boost from Defog. Ghost-types like Froslass and Gourgeist-S can serve as emergency Rapid Spin blockers against foes like Cryogonal and Kabutops, though they should be aware of super effective coverage options and being pivoted on.

Stunfisk.comments:
Other Options

Rest provides Stunfisk with recovery and lets it remove status, but it makes Stunfisk even more passive. Thunder Wave provides a more reliable method of slowing foes like Sawk and Silvally formes, while Protect synergizes with Toxic and Leftovers, wearing down foes and providing Stunfisk with more recovery. However, Stunfisk often has difficulty fitting either move.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Appletun threaten Stunfisk with their attacks or status and force it out. However, they do not appreciate Toxic.

Water-types: Although they cannot directly switch into Discharge or Toxic, Water-types like Basculin, Poliwrath, and Pyukumuku can effectively handle Stunfisk.

Ice-types: Despite its great special bulk, Stunfisk is vulnerable to powerful Ice-types like Froslass, Abomasnow, and Jynx.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine target Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery and heavily damage or KO it with their strong attacks.

Strong Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Sawk heavily pressure Stunfisk with their attacks, although they dislike Static.

Residual Damage: Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery leaves it vulnerable to Spikes and Toxic from foes such as Qwilfish, Rapidash, and Clefairy.

Specially Defensive.description:
Stunfisk is a notable specially defensive wall and Stealth Rock setter in ZU that has good matchups against common threats like Rotom, Skuntank, and Manectric. Toxic wears down switch-ins like Tangela, Rhydon, and Piloswine and Defoggers like Articuno and Rotom formes. Earth Power prevents Stunfisk from being passive against prominent special attackers like Manectric, Skuntank, and Ninetales. Discharge allows Stunfisk to spread paralysis and deal with most Defoggers, while Foul Play lets it handle Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom and physical setup sweepers like Thwackey, which may try to take advantage of Stunfisk to safely set up. Static punishes physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Klinklang, and it can also give Stunfisk a chance to cripple checks like physical Basculin and Thwackey in an emergency situation.

Stunfisk fits primarily on balance and bulky offense teams and provides valuable role compression. Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S handle Water- and Ground-types like Poliwrath and Rhydon; in return, Stunfisk can take on Poison-types like Silvally-Poison and Skuntank for them. Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales pressure the aforementioned Grass-types, as well as Ice-types like Articuno and Froslass, for Stunfisk. As Stunfisk has a poor matchup against other Stealth Rock setters like Rhydon and Piloswine, it is advisable to pair it with Water-types like Poliwrath, Basculin, and Cramorant; Cramorant is a notable partner that can provide Defog and check powerful foes like Sawk while benefitting greatly from Stunfisk dealing with Electric-types. Toxic absorbers like Altaria and Qwilfish prevent Stunfisk from getting worn down; a Toxic Spikes absorber like Silvally-Poison or Qwilfish is likewise helpful. Cleric support from partners like Clefairy and Alcremie helps Stunfisk remain healthy, especially on bulkier teams.

Stunfisk-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Snap Trap traps and chips down targets while synergizing with Yawn to inflict foes with sleep. However, having one of these moves reduces Galarian Stunfisk's coverage and utility in other areas and leaves it unable to deal with Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom formes; they should only been used in specific situations. Thunder Wave cripples and forces out faster foes like Kangaskhan and Silvally formes; however, it leaves Stunfisk Galarian unable to punish Ground-types. Protect allows Galarian Stunfisk to gain more recovery from Leftovers and lets it scout Choice item users such as Sawk and Rotom. Rest is also used as a recovery option, but it is considerably niche and only fits on select teams. Rest is best used when paired with Heal Bell support from Articuno, Clefairy, or Altaria on stall teams.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types such as Basculin, Cramorant, and Poliwrath handle Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves.

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Silvally-Gound force out Galarian Stunfisk out, with the former two using that opportunity to set up Stealth Rock and the latter setting up with Swords Dance.

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr threaten Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves, while Cofagrigus can set up with Iron Defense and KO it with Body Press.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Galarian Stunfisk, although they cannot safely switch in due to Galarian Stunfisk's Rock / Ground coverage.

Strong Wallbreakers: While Galarian Stunfisk does have great bulk, it can easily get overwhelmed by strong setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Shiftry and Nasty Plot Rotom.

Item Removal: Pokemon carrying Knock Off or Trick, such as Uxie, Rotom, and Thwackey, can remove Galarian Stunfisk's main form of recovery in Leftovers, limiting its effectiveness as a special wall.

Hazards: Although Galarian Stunfisk takes little damage from Stealth Rock, Spikes chips down Galarian Stunfisk over time, limiting its switch-ins and effectiveness as a special wall.

Special Wall.description:
Galarian Stunfisk is a niche Stealth Rock setter in the metagame thanks to its great defensive stats and great defensive typing that lets it wall threats such as Rotom formes. Rock Slide hits Pokemon such as Cramorant, Articuno, and the aforementioned Rotom formes; Rock Slide is more consistent than Stone Edge and preferred due to its higher accuracy and PP. Curse turns Galarian Stunfisk into a threatening late-game cleaner while also making up for its passivity. Yawn forces switches from Pokemon that wall Galarian Stunfisk, such as Uxie and Tangela. Foul Play deals significant damage to Swords Dance users such as Silvally formes.

Galarian Stunfisk is a decent pick on balance and stall teams thanks to it compressing the role of an Electric immunity, Stealth Rock setter, and special wall. Bulky Water-types such as Cramorant and Poliwrath are great partners to Galarian Stunfisk, as they can take on Water-types such as Basculin and Poliwrath, which threaten Galarian Stunfisk, while also benefitting from Galarian Stunfisk's Electric immunity. Grass-types are also great partners to cover Galarian Stunfisk's weaknesses, with Appletun covering its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fire, while Gourgeist-S and Trevenant cover its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fighting. Uxie can also work as a partner, as it is resistant to Fighting and immune to Ground. Spikes stacking teams also appreciate Galarian Stunfisk's ability to force switches with Yawn, with a Spikes setter such as Qwilfish also covering Galarian Stunfisk's weakness to Fighting.

Pawniard.comments:
Other Options

Pawniard has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Gurdurr and Poliwrath can stomach +2 Iron Head without too much trouble and can force it out with their STAB moves. Offensive Fighting-types like Sawk and Silvally-Fighting outspeed Pawniard, resist Sucker Punch, and easily KO it.
