Bulky Pokemon: Without enough residual damage, walls like Miltank and Palossand can either whittle Pawniard down or outright KO it. They can set up Stealth Rock to capitalize on their good matchup against it.

Fire-types and Fire-type coverage: Though none of them like switching into Knock Off, Fire-types like Ninetales, Rapidash, and Coalossal can pick it off with ease. The latter two can potentially burn Pawniard with Flame Body. Pawniard also has to watch out for coverage moves like Mystical Fire and Flamethrower from Pokemon it switches into, such as Alcremie and Altaria.

Faster Pokemon: Even with Eviolite, faster Pokemon can take advantage of its low bulk and can pick it off without much prior damage. Examples include Lycanroc-N, Silvally-Poison, and Kangaskhan.

Swords Dance.description:
With an excellent offensive and defensive typing, acceptable Attack, and a great offensive movepool alongside Defiant, Pawniard is a solid deterrent against Defog users such as Articuno and Altaria lacking Flamethrower. However, Pawniard needs to be wary of pivoting and coverage due to its low bulk even with Eviolite. Swords Dance makes Pawniard even harder to switch into, making it a scary cleaner late-game. Knock Off is not only its primary attack, but also cripples walls like Tangela and Galarian Stunfisk. Most importantly, it cripples switch-ins reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots like Rapidash, Miltank, and Alolan Persian. Sucker Punch is useful late-game for sweeping through weakened foes like Froslass and Jynx.

Pawniard synergizes nicely with Pokemon that can provide entry hazards, such as Qwilfish, Palossand, and Stunfisk. Roselia pairs particularly well, as Pawniard can punish Defog attempts from Altaria and Articuno, while Roselia can switch into Stunfisk, Sawk, and Rhydon. Physical attackers like Swords Dance Rapidash and Silvally formes can capitalize on Pawniard's Knock Off support and clean up teams late-game. Rapid Spin users like Morpeko and Cryogonal can clear hazards while keeping their own for Pawniard to take advantage of.

Bouffalant.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Band set provides Bouffalant with immediate wallbreaking power and also has the element of surprise. Reckless is used to further increase the power of Head Charge. However, this loses the niche of Grass immunity and faces heavy competition from weaker yet more versatile Normal-types in Kangaskhan and Silvally.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-type Pokemon such as Sawk, Silvally-Fighting, and Poliwrath all threaten to OHKO Bouffalant with their powerful STAB attacks.

Physical Walls: Miltank and Qwilfish can wear down Bouffalant with Rocky Helmet damage, which adds to Head Charge recoil. Alolan Persian can survive a few hits and prevent setup thanks to Foul Play.

Strong Faster Pokemon: Strong, faster Pokemon such as Silvally-Dark and Basculin can hit Boufflant hard, preventing it from setting up.

Ghost-types: Sableye and Gourgeist-XL can sponge Bouffalant's attacks and prevent setup with Foul Play and Will-O-Wisp. Rotom can also threaten Bouffalant with Will-O-Wisp but doesn't take Throat Chop very well.

Sap Sipper Wallbreaker.description:
Bouffalant finds its niche in ZU as a bulky wallbreaker with a great ability in Sap Sipper. Sap Sipper allows Bouffalant to prey on ZU's Grass-types, such as the common blanket physical wall Tangela, using them as setup fodder with Substitute and Swords Dance. In addition, Bouffalant checks offensive Grass-type threats in Thwackey and Gourgeist-S. Head Charge is Bouffalant's standard STAB move thanks to its high power. Facade is sometimes used over Substitute and takes advantage of status. This then frees up Close Combat as a coverage option, which hits Pokemon that resist Bouffalant's STAB move such as Rhydon, Klingklang, and Coalossal. Throat Chop is used to hit Ghost-types like Rotom, Gourgeist formes, and Trevenant. The EV spread allows Bouffalant to outspeed uninvested Tangela and Alcremie whilst increasing bulk.

Bouffalant fits well on balance and bulky offense teams, helping break down defensive teams that rely on passive Pokemon to deal damage. Thwackey is a great partner for Bouffalant, as it can lure in Tangela before pivoting out with U-turn, bring in Bouffalant safely, and provide additional passive recovery on top of Leftovers. Kabutops and Morpeko are other pivots that can force Grass-types in. Strong special attackers such as Basculin, Thievul, and Appletun can help break through other physically bulky Pokemon such as Rhydon, Qwilfish, and Miltank. Uxie and Qwillfish can compress the roles of entry hazard setter and switch-in to Fighting-type attacks that threaten Bouffalant. Dark-type Pokemon such as Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can help pressure Ghost-types like Rotom and Sableye, which are immune to Bouffalant's STAB moves. Lastly, late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Sawk, Thwackey, and Klinklang can benefit from Bouffalant's wallbreaking abilities.

Trevenant.comments:
Other Options

Some attacks can be used over Trick. Horn Leech and Drain Punch give Trevenant recovery, with the latter hitting Sap Sipper Miltank and the rare Bouffalant harder. Shadow Claw can hit Pokemon without an item, which synergizes better with Knock Off teammates. Earthquake provides a stronger hit against Poison-types like Qwilfish and Skuntank. Offensive Trick Room sets can bypass Trevenant's low Speed and surprise offensive teams, though Gourgeist-XL tends to perform better thanks to its Explosion, superior bulk, and lower Speed. Harvest sets with Substitute can capitalize on passive teams, though they struggle to find other opportunities due to Trevenant’s middling bulk.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types like Tangela and itemless Gourgeist-XL should be wary of Trick but can stomach most of Trevenant’s hits relatively easily and force it out. Offensive Grass-types like Thwackey and Flapple can revenge kill it with some prior damage.

Dark-types: Skuntank and Shiftry resist both of Trevenant’s STAB moves and can revenge kill it with some prior damage. Other Dark-types like Silvally-Dark and Thievul can switch into Poltergeist but not Wood Hammer. Alolan Persian is notable for not only outspeeding it, but taking Wood Hammer if necessary and OHKOing with Foul Play.

Flying-types: Articuno can stall Trevenant out with the combination of Roost and Pressure. Offensive Flying-types like Silvally-Flying and Unfezant can revenge kill it but cannot safely switch into it.

Faster Attackers: Trevenant’s low Speed and mediocre bulk make it easy for faster attackers to revenge kill. Pokemon like Sawk and Rapidash can defeat it with minimal to no prior chip damage. However, Pokemon weak to Sucker Punch, such as Rotom and Froslass, need to be more careful.

Sap Sipper: Sap Sipper Miltank and the rare Bouffalant can freely switch into Trevenant and set up. However, Miltank does not appreciate Trick.

Choice Band.description:
Trevenant is a powerful wallbreaker that threatens teams without sturdy Ghost and Grass answers or sufficient offensive pressure. Thanks to Natural Cure, it can pivot into status better compared to other attackers and eases the need for a cleric. However, it faces competition from Gourgeist-S, which has significantly higher Speed. Trevenant compensates by hitting much harder, 2HKOing switch-ins like Altaria and Qwilfish, the latter after Stealth Rock damage. Sucker Punch nails faster foes like Rotom, Jynx, and Froslass. If Trevenant is paired with Thwackey, Grassy Glide can provide Trevenant with a safer priority move. Trick cripples lured walls like Tangela and Sap Sipper Miltank, which otherwise switch in safely. Natural Cure allows Trevenant to pivot into Pokemon reliant on status such as Stunfisk and defensive Poliwrath.

Despite Trevenant’s strength, it struggles to break through physical walls, especially ones that invalidate its STAB moves like Tangela, Sap Sipper Miltank, and itemless Gourgeist-XL. Special wallbreakers like Jynx, Skuntank, and Thievul overwhelm them with super effective coverage or setup. Pivots such as Uxie and Alolan Persian can help Trevenant get onto the field against faster builds. Coalossal can cover its Fire-, Ice-, and Flying-type weaknesses and provide Rapid Spin, while Dark-types like Skuntank can cover its Dark- and Ghost-type weaknesses. In return, Trevenant can offensively deal with many Water- and Ground-types, including Poliwrath, Rhydon, and Stunfisk. Thwackey not only gives Trevenant Grassy Glide, a more reliable priority move, but also an offensive partner that works together to overwhelm bulky Grass-types.

Gourgeist-Small.comments:
Other Options

Gourgeist-S can run a Life Orb set with three attacks and Synthesis, letting it change moves, but the boosts from Choice items are more consistently effective, and Trick lets these sets change moves later. Despite its miserable Special Attack, a Nasty Plot set can make Gourgeist-S deceivingly threatening. It has multiple setup opportunities, decent Speed, Fire Blast for coverage, and longevity with Giga Drain or Synthesis. As fun as this seems, though, its Special Attack is sadly still too low to properly break through common walls like Miltank.

Checks and Counters

Dark-type Pokemon and Coverage: Silvally-Dark, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian can all switch into Poltergeist and KO Gourgeist-S. Although it is bulky, Gourgeist-S's Dark weakness means it can't always freely switch into Knock Off users the likes of Thwackey and Sawk.

Bulky Grass-types: Tangela and other defensive Grass-types like Gourgeist-XL, Shiinotic, and Lurantis can easily take Power Whip. The latter three options all frequently run no item, making them immune to Poltergeist.

Fire-types: While they may fear its strong Poltergeist, Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash are faster than Choice Band Gourgeist-S and can KO any set with a Fire-type attack.

Flying-types: Bulky Flying-types like Altaria, Articuno, and Rotom-S easily switch into Power Whip and can KO Gourgeist-S with their STAB attacks if they avoid getting harmed by Poltergeist. Unfezant boasts an immunity to Poltergeist, making it a great check to Gourgeist-S.

Sap Sipper Normal-types: Sap Sipper Miltank and Bouffalant boast immunities to both of Gourgeist-S's STAB types. They must be wary of Trick, but they still wall it after Trick regardless.

Choice Scarf.description:
Gourgeist-S is a fantastic revenge killer thanks to its great Speed tier and strong STAB combination. Fast threats like Morpeko, Choice Scarf Rotom, and +1 Speed Silvally formes all get outsped and KOed after some chip damage. It has great utility beyond revenge killing, too. Its physical bulk lets it switch into attacks from Rhydon, and it also boasts a good defensive typing, letting it switch into Choice-locked wallbreakers like Thwackey and Sawk. Trick cripples checks like Miltank and Tangela switching in. This comes at the cost of its revenge killing abilities, though, so be careful to not use Trick too early. The last move is open for a variety of options. Bulky teams generally favor longevity from Synthesis, which lets Gourgeist-S further take advantage of its defensive typing after using Trick. However, more offensive teams will favor Destiny Bond to stop a sweep or Explosion as a one-time nuke.

Its combination of utility and offensive prowess makes Choice Scarf Gourgeist-S a solid option on most team styles, but bulky offense and balance teams benefit the most. However, remember that a team's Knock Off support can actually hurt Gourgeist-S because Poltergeist relies on opposing items. Arguably Gourgeist-S's most synergetic teammate is Miltank, which switches into Ice-type and Fire-type attacks from the likes of Articuno and Rapidash. In return, Gourgeist-S can handle Fighting-type attacks from Pokemon like Sawk, which scare Miltank out. Gourgeist-S fears Knock Off, but walls like Alcremie, Miltank, and Poliwrath can absorb it with little problem. Articuno, Altaria, and Silvally-Poison can weaken or even dismantle opposing Grass-types, letting Gourgeist-S more easily take advantage of Power Whip. Gourgeist-S is also a great fit on offense, as VoltTurn users like Klinklang and the Silvally formes greatly appreciate its ability to switch into and revenge kill threats. In return, those teammates can chip down the opposing team to make revenge killing easier, especially with Spikes support from Qwilfish. On offense, Gourgeist-S's ability to revenge kill fast threats like Alolan Dugtrio and Choice Scarf Sawk gives more room for sweepers like Silvally-Dark, Jynx, and Klinklang to take over the game.

Choice Band.description:
Thanks to its great Speed and powerful STAB attacks, Gourgeist-S can function as a fast wallbreaker with decent utility. With its good bulk and typing, it often gets opportunities to switch into the field and threaten a KO. It's able to take advantage of powerful foes such as Rhydon, Sawk, Thwackey, and Alolan Dugtrio. It also easily handles passive attacks from the likes of Qwilfish and Stunfisk, although it should watch for paralysis. Its strong dual STAB attacks are difficult to switch into, breaking through common walls like Alcremie, Altaria, and Poliwrath. Shadow Sneak makes Gourgeist-S a decent revenge killer, picking off weakened faster threats like Swords Dance Rapidash, Choice Band Froslass, and Choice Scarf Rotom. Trick lets it turn the tides against defensive switch-ins like Tangela and Sap Sipper Miltank.

Entry hazard support goes a long way to help Gourgeist-S thrive. For example, Stealth Rock gives it a good chance to 2HKO Skuntank. Defensive Stealth Rock setters including Stunfisk and Clefairy help keep hazards up over the course of a game. Offensive Stealth Rock setters like Rhydon and Piloswine particularly help, though, because they can KO the Defog users like Articuno and Altaria that Gourgeist-S can sometimes struggle against. Gourgeist-S is capable at breaking through the defensive Water-types and Ground-types that dominate the tier, giving Pokemon like Rapidash and Klinklang a greater chance of sweeping. With frequent Choice locks but no Synthesis or Speed boost, a good defensive backbone can help preserve Gourgeist-S's longevity. Poliwrath, Miltank, and Throh all provide the necessary type synergy and bulk to give it a Pokemon to fall back on. VoltTurn users like the Silvally formes and Manectric can chip foes and lure in Pokemon that lose to Gourgeist-S, like Poliwrath and Altaria, before pivoting into it. Furthermore, wallbreakers like Jynx, Sawk, and Ninetales take advantage of Gourgeist-S's checks like Tangela, Miltank, and Rapidash.

Gourgeist-Super.comments:
Other Options

Gourgeist-XL can run 144 Speed EVs to outpace Adamant Rhydon, giving it more consistency in the matchup. However, this sacrifices a significant amount of bulk, making it less reliable as a physical wall or tank. Colbur Berry helps Gourgeist-XL become an incredible Knock Off absorber, and also lets it take a Multi-Attack from Silvally-Dark before attacking or burning it, at the cost of losing to Poltergeist users like opposing Gourgeist formes. Gourgeist-XL can set up Trick Room and take advantage of it, due to its great bulk and low Speed. However, Trick Room is a niche playstyle and requires much more team support than Gourgeist-XL's standard sets. Choice Band maximizes Gourgeist-XL's strength, but faces severe competition from Trevenant, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S.

Checks and Counters

Special Wallbreakers: Albeit not fragile, Gourgeist-XL lacks the special bulk to consistently handle multiple hits from special attackers. They can't switch into it, and they should watch out for Shadow Sneak, but wallbreakers like Rotom and Jynx can hit it with strong super effective coverage. There also are breakers like Exeggutor and Appletun who hit it hard with neutral coverage.

Fire-type Pokemon: Fire-type Pokemon like Rapidash and Ninetales resist Power Whip and immediately threaten it, although Poltergeist can be scary to switch into for Ninetales and a weakened Rapidash. Coalossal is neutral to Power Whip, but has super effective STAB moves and Flame Body to cripple Gourgeist-XL.

Dark-type Pokemon: Gourgeist-XL may handle Knock Off decently, but its weakness makes it vulnerable to attacks from Silvally-Dark and Thievul. Alolan Persian has the physical bulk to handle its attacks and can weaken it with Toxic, Foul Play, or Parting Shot. Skuntank has the rare trait of resisting both of its STAB moves, and can immediately threaten Gourgeist-XL without worrying about status.

Flying-type Pokemon: Although Poltergeist can hit them hard, Articuno, Altaria, and Silvally-Flying can switch into Power Whip and directly threaten Gourgeist-XL with their super effective STAB moves. While it dislikes being burned, Unfezant is additionally immune to Poltergeist.

Sap Sipper Normal-types: Miltank and Bouffalant can use Sap Sipper to completely wall both of Gourgeist-XL's STAB attacks. They should be careful to not switch into Toxic, and Bouffalant gets crippled by Will-O-Wisp, but most Miltank run Heal Bell to negate this.

Physical Wall.description:
Boasting great bulk, a unique defensive typing, and a variety of utility moves, Gourgeist-XL is one of the most reliable counters to physical wallbreakers like Thwackey, Sawk, and Rhydon. Foul Play is the primary attacking option due to its ability to hit a wide range of attackers, including Piloswine and Klinklang, and the fact that nothing is immune to it. Toxic is a great way to pressure walls like Alcremie, Tangela, and Miltank, while Will-O-Wisp is another option that cripples physical foes like Qwilfish and Silvally-Dark who may try to switch into it. Power Whip is a powerful attack that destroys bulky Pokemon like Stunfisk, Rhydon, and Piloswine. Leech Seed makes Gourgeist-XL less reliable against the aforementioned Ground-types, but it provides consistent chip damage and recovery, making it less reliant on Synthesis. By not holding an item, Gourgeist-XL weakens opposing Knock Off users and gains a Poltergeist immunity to beat opposing Gourgeist formes and Choice Band Froslass.

Bulky offense and balance teams looking for a physically defensive behemoth that absorbs Knock Off well will highly benefit from Gourgeist-XL's presence. Gourgeist-XL's great matchup against Pokemon like Sawk and Thwackey is greatly appreciated by walls like Miltank, Rhydon, and Poliwrath. In return, these walls can absorb the Ghost-, Fire-, and Ice-type attacks that directly threaten Gourgeist-XL. Miltank is an especially good partner, as it resists all three of those types and can use Heal Bell to cure Gourgeist-XL of status. Entry hazard removers including Altaria, Articuno, and Cramorant also cover Gourgeist-XL's weaknesses and prevent hazards from withering it down. Late-game cleaners like Klinklang, Silvally-Poison, and Jynx love Gourgeist-XL spreading status, wearing down foes to make sweeping easier. Gourgeist-XL's ability to absorb hits from revenge killers like Sawk, Alolan Dugtrio, and Gurdurr is great for wallbreakers like Thievul, Skuntank, and Lycanroc-Midnight who fear revenge killers.

Tank.description:
Gourgeist-XL's raw power, thanks to its solid Attack and incredible STAB combination, and its excellent overall bulk make it a strong physical tank. Shadow Sneak makes Gourgeist-XL a potent revenge killer, picking off chipped foes like Froslass, Rotom, and Jynx. Synthesis keeps Gourgeist-XL healthy, allowing it to check Pokemon like Thwackey, Sawk, and Rotom throughout the game. To assist in its defensive versatility, Gourgeist-XL doesn't hold an item so that it can weaken Knock Off and be immune to Poltergeist from opposing Gourgeist formes and Froslass.

Offensive teams that want a physical attacker that can take multiple hits love Gourgeist-XL's combination of offensive and defensive prowess. However, Poltergeist's item requirement gives it negative synergy with Knock Off teammates. It enjoys pairing with wallbreakers that can threaten the Flying-, Grass- and Fire-types that switch into Power Whip. Jynx, Silvally-Poison, and Rhydon serve as great partners as a result. Rhydon, alongside Qwilfish and Piloswine, also provide entry hazard support to make Gourgeist-XL's attacks more difficult to switch into. Although it has significant bulk, Gourgeist-XL's common weaknesses require defensive partners like Poliwrath, Rapidash, and Stunfisk. Miltank is particularly good, providing Heal Bell support and resistances to Ghost, Fire, and Ice. In return, Gourgeist-XL handles Fighting-, Grass-, and Water-type attacks while putting out offensive pressure.

Avalugg.overview: Avalugg is listed as an unviable option in SS ZU due to its awful Special Defense and mediocre typing, which hold it back from performing a defensive role well. This makes it greatly outclassed as an entry hazard remover by the likes of Cryogonal and Articuno, since they have better overall stats and useful abilities. As a physical wall, Miltank and Tangela are preferred because they aren't as weak to the super common Knock Off and Toxic, have better movepools, stat distribution, and are able to handle some of the most common physical attackers in the tier like Sawk and Klinklang.

Defensive Rapid Spin.description: Avalugg attempts to perform the role of entry hazard remover and physically defensive wall. However, its typing and horrible Special Defense make it very hard for it to wall anything and make it easy to take down. Other physically defensive walls like Tangela and Miltank are more equipped to take on the tier with better typing, stats, and support movepools. There are also much better options like Crygonal and Articuno, which can remove hazards much more easily with the help of their better stats and movepool.

Lycanroc-Midnight.comments:
Other Options

Choice Scarf allows Lycanroc-N to be a revenge killer, though it has a much harder time breaking through bulky threats like Tangela, Poliwrath, and Qwilfish.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Gurdurr, Poliwrath, and Throh resist Stone Edge and can retaliate with their own STAB moves. Silvally-Fighting and Sawk are notable for outspeeding Lycanroc-N, though they don’t enjoy switching into Close Combat, Play Rough, or Psychic Fangs.

Grass-types: A healthy Tangela and Gourgeist-XL can easily switch into any of Lycanroc-N’s attacks and can threaten it out. More offensive Grass-types, like Thwackey and Shiftry, can outspeed and OHKO it with their STAB attacks, though they can’t switch into it; in addition, Sucker Punch can defeat them if they have been sufficiently chipped, so they have to remain healthy to check it.

Ground-types: Stunfisk resists Stone Edge and can stomach at least one coverage move before retaliating with Earth Power. Rhydon and Piloswine can beat it one-on-one, but they falter switching into Close Combat.

Faster Pokemon: Faster wallbreakers such as Silvally-Dark, Skuntank, and Kangaskhan can revenge kill it with some chip, though they do not appreciate directly switching into it.

Swords Dance.description:
Lycanroc-N is a potent cleaner thanks to its accurate Stone Edge and access to Swords Dance. Close Combat provides coverage against Ground- and Steel-types that resist Stone Edge, 2HKOing Piloswine, Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk, and OHKOing Klinklang. Sucker Punch allows Lycanroc-N to clean weakened teams, OHKOing faster threats like Choice Scarf Rotom and 2HKOing Gourgeist-S.

Lycanroc-N fits well on offensive teams, cleaning up late-game with its nearly-perfect neutral coverage. It can also pivot into bulkier threats that can’t do much damage in return, such as Altaria, Articuno, and Miltank. Lycanroc-N is weak to multiple priority moves from foes like Kangaskhan and Poliwrath and struggles to break through bulkier walls such as Tangela and Gurdurr. Bulky Pokemon like Rhydon and Tangela can handle prority users and ease pressure off Lycanroc-N. Pivots that can cripple or force them out, such as Rotom, Uxie, and Clefairy, can help it wallbreak easier. Lycanroc-N‘s terrible defensive typing means Pokemon that are faster than it, such as Sawk, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S, can easily force it out; therefore, Pokemon like Uxie, Silvally-Poison, and Skuntank that can threaten them out are appreciated. Pokemon that can cripple physical walls by removing items or inflicting status, like Thwackey, Rotom, and Sawk, are crucial in helping Lycanroc-N sweep.

Choice Band.description:
Lycanroc-N is a powerful wallbreaker with a decent Speed tier. Close Combat 2HKOes Ground- and Steel-types that can handle Stone Edge, such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Klinklang. Sucker Punch picks off weakened faster threats like Thwackey, Froslass, and Choice Scarf Rotom. Play Rough is its best option to hit Fighting-types like Throh and Gurdurr, while Psychic Fangs deals with Qwilfish better.

Lycanroc-N fits best on balance and offense teams in need of a strong, consistent wallbreaker. Due to its poor defensive profile and middling bulk, it appreciates pivots like Alolan Persian, Rotom, and Silvally formes that can help it get onto the field safely. Knock Off support from Thwackey, and Alolan Persian also helps it take on checks like Tangela, Gurdurr, and Stunfisk easier, allowing other sweepers like Silvally-Poison and Choice Scarf Sawk clean up late-game. Lycanroc-N can also pivot into bulkier Pokemon that cannot threaten it, such as Altaria, Clefairy, and Coalossal, giving it more opportunities to fire off powerful attacks. Pokemon that have trouble reliably breaking through these bulky Pokemon, such as Rotom and Rapidash, appreciate its wallbreaking capabilities.

Lurantis.comments:
Other Options

If entry hazard removal isn’t needed, Lurantis can run Aromatherapy over Defog to remove status that could cripple a Contrary sweep while curing its teammates in the process. Knock Off is also a useful fourth move to cripple switch-ins like Altaria and Tangela. Toxic is an option to put a timer on bulkier foes that resist Lurantis’s moves like Articuno but only compounds its weakness to opposing Poison-types. Setup support like Substitute and Safeguard can be useful, but Lurantis is often too slow to use these moves well and generally gains more advantage by simply using Leaf Storm or Superpower. Lurantis can also run a specially defensive set to check Rotom with the expectation that Superpower will then improve its Defense after one use. Heavy-Duty Boots is a good item for getting the most out of Defog, but Leftovers synergizes better with the high likelihood of staying in multiple turns to take advantage of Contrary. Leppa Berry can be used to remedy the PP issues Lurantis faces with Leaf Storm and Superpower and works especially well against Articuno's attempts to Pressure stall.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Pure Poison-types like Silvally-Poison resist Lurantis’s combo of Grass- and Fighting-type coverage, and others like Skuntank and Qwilfish resist just one of Grass or Fighting. Silvally-Poison and Skunktank can comfortably switch into even Knock Off variants of Lurantis, and all three Pokemon threaten Lurantis with super effective STAB Poison moves.

Flying-types: Articuno and Altaria resist Lurantis’s Grass STAB moves and Altaria resists Superpower too. Both Pokemon threaten Lurantis with STAB Hurricane and Articuno can even opt for a more accurate Freeze-Dry if needed. Roost also allows these Pokemon to stay healthy throughout a game, though Articuno must beware of Superpower when it loses its Flying typing and both Pokemon are significantly crippled by Knock Off.

Fire-types: Rapidash, Ninetales, and to a lesser extent Coalossal all threaten Lurantis with Fire STAB moves. Rapidash and Ninetales can boost alongside Lurantis, and Rapidash's Flame Body can punish repeated uses of Superpower.

Ice-types: Jynx, Froslass, and Cryogonal generally fear Lurantis's attacks but with momentum can force it out with Ice Beam or Freeze Dry. Articuno threatens Lurantis similarly but with the added benefit of resisting Leaf Storm. Abomasnow can switch into Leaf Storm too and immediately threaten to OHKO Lurantis with Blizzard.

Fast Special Attackers: Lurantis is a slow Pokemon and Superpower only boosts it Defense stat, making it susceptible to super effective attacks targeting its Special Defense from faster Pokemon like Poliwrath, Cramorant, or Manectric.

Grass-types: Lilligant can set up Quiver Dances and strike with a super effective Pollen Puff. Tangela and Roselia can stall out Leaf Storm and threaten with Sludge Bomb. Gourgeist can 2HKO with Poltergeist and is immune to Superpower. Chlorophyll sweepers like Ivysaur and Exeggutor can take advantage of Lurantis too.

Defog.description:
Lurantis combines a pure-Grass typing, serviceable mixed bulk, and strong Contrary move pool to effectively check common entry hazard setters like Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Qwilfish to either clear hazards with Defog or threaten to sweep. Leaf Storm is a strong STAB attack that boosts Lurantis’s Special Attack by two stages after each use due to Contrary. Superpower also benefits from Contrary, providing super effective Fighting coverage for Sap Sipper Miltank and Klinklang while also hitting Fire-types, Grass-types, and Articuno for neutral damage. Synthesis ensures Lurantis can remain healthy enough to repeatedly clear entry hazards or sustain itself for a Contrary sweep. 216 Speed EVs lets Lurantis outpace Adamant Rhydon and uninvested Alcremie. The remaining EVs are invested into bulk to better check physical entry hazard setters, notably allowing Lurantis to survive hits like +2 Stone Edge from standard Stealth Rock Rhydon.

Lurantis is most valuable when clearing entry hazards but thanks to Contrary, Leaf Storm, and Superpower, Lurantis can often scale its damage output enough to break through the healing moves of bulkier cores. Rhydon, Palossand, and Stunfisk all specifically have trouble defeating Lurantis, which opens opportunities for teammates like Silvally-Poison and Rotom which are usually stopped by these Pokemon. Lurantis struggles greatly against bulky Poison- and Flying-type foes like opposing Silvally-Poison and Altaria. Lurantis is also quite slow, so it is forced out by any faster Pokemon, such as Rapidash, Ninetales, Froslass, Jinx, and Articuno. Klinklang is a good partner because of its resistances and ability to OHKO Ice-types with an unboosted Gear Grind. In return, Lurantis handles Stunfisk, Galarian Stunfisk, and Palossand, all of which commonly shrug off Klinklang’s moves. Rapidash and Coalossal are good teammates too because they check offensive Fire- and Ice-types, and Lurantis can handle opposing Rock- and Ground-types in turn.

Shiinotic.comments:
Other Options:

Choice Specs sets can surprise opponents expecting the standard set, and have decent breaking power. However, they lose out on most of what makes Shiinotic effective and are usually outclassed by other options such as Exeggutor and Appletun.

Checks and Counters:

Poison-types: Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Ivysaur are immune to Toxic, resist Moonblast, and threaten to OHKO Shiinotic.

Steel-types: Steel-types are immune to Toxic, resist Shiinotic's STAB moves, and hit it super effectively. Most of them also have other ways to abuse it, like Substitute + Toxic Alolan Dugtrio or Klinklang's Clear Body, which denies Strength Sap.

Ice-types: Ice-types such as Abomasnow and Froslass threaten Shiinotic with their strong, super effective STAB attacks and do not grant much recovery if Strength Sap is used against them. Most of them also have ways to prevent or alleviate the status Shiinotic inflicts.

Super Effective Coverage: Shiinotic needs to be wary of foes running super effective coverage for it, like Iron Head Silvally-Dark, Ice Beam Poliwrath, and Sludge Bomb Tangela.

Strong Attackers: Some powerful breakers whose STAB moves are not resisted by Shiinotic, like Choice Banded Lycanroc, Choice Specs Exeggutor, and Choice Specs Rotom, can brute-force their way through it.

Physical Wall.description:
Shiinotic is a great physical wall due to its unique typing and moveset letting it check a number of threats like Sawk, Thwackey, and Appletun. Spore can put switch-ins like Silvally-Poison and Ninetales out of commission, and the move itself forces many switches. The last moveslot can be dedicated to either Toxic, which punishes Pokemon that are immune to Spore like Tangela and Sap Sipper Miltank and puts foes on a timer, or Giga Drain, which makes Shiinotic more reliable at dealing with Ground- and Water-types, such as Rhydon and Poliwrath. No item is run to avoid Poltergeist from Gourgeist formes and Trevenant; however, Rocky Helmet can be used to punish Pokemon that use contact moves such as Kangaskhan and Gurdurr.

Slower wallbreakers, like Thievul and Swords Dance Rhydon, that are weak to common fast Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Thwackey appreciate Shiinotic's ability to answer them and create opportunities for them to wallbreak with Spore and Effect Spore. Popular Ground-types and Water-types such as Stunfisk and Poliwrath easily fold to threats handled by Shiinotic like Appletun, Morpeko, and Basculin. In return, they answer Poison- and Flying-types like Skuntank and Unfezant and Steel- and Fire-types like Klinklang and Ninetales, respectively, that Shiinotic is weak to. Offensive teammates like Rotom and Jynx as well as defensive options like Rhydon and Hattrem greatly appreciate Shiinotic's ability to absorb Knock Off. Setup sweepers like Ninetales and various Silvally formes also get an immense advantage out of the free turns provided by Spore, and enjoy walls getting crippled by a surprise Toxic.

Palossand.comments:
Other Options

Toxic can be used over Stealth Rock to put Pokemon that wall Palossand, such as Appletun, Cramorant, and non-Aromatherapy Alcremie, on a timer. This forces teams to pair Palossand with another Stealth Rock setter, though, making Palossand less easy to fit onto defensive cores. Palossand can run different items, with Kasib Berry surprising Rotom and Leftovers making Palossand less reliant on Shore Up for recovery. Unfortunately, these items only have very situational uses, whereas Colbur Berry and Rocky Helmet are more versatile.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Palossand's weakness and lack of coverage for Grass-types give it a hard time. Tangela, Thwackey, and Appletun can switch into Earth Power and directly threaten it. The Gourgeist formes do the same, but do fear Shadow Ball.

Ice-types: While Froslass and Jynx cannot switch into Palossand's Shadow Ball, they both are massive threats to Palossand once they safely enter. Piloswine isn't as inherently powerful, and should be weary of a Scorching Sands burn, but it can safely switch into variants without it. Articuno can directly switch into it and use Freeze-Dry and Defog to mitigate Palossand's progress.

Special Wallbreakers: In general, special attackers can excel at threatening Palossand. Common special wallbreakers like Rotom, Poliwrath, and Exeggutor threaten to deal large amounts of damage to Palossand, often forcing Palossand to either switch out or get KOed.

Special Walls: Without super effective coverage, Palossand has a difficult time getting past most specially defensive Pokemon. It doesn't have any way to break past walls that can wear it down through Toxic, like Miltank, Altaria, and Clefairy.

Dark-types: Even with Palossand holding a Colbur Berry, it still gets threatened out by Dark-types like Silvally-Dark, Thievul, and Shiftry. Without Colbur Berry, then Palosand also struggles to check Skuntank and Morpeko.

Water-types: Despite having Water Compaction, Palossand has a poor matchup versus most of the metagame's Water-types, like Poliwrath, Silvally-Water, and Cramorant.

Physical Wall.description:
Palossand's solid bulk, great typing, and instant recovery make it a great physical wall. Its Ghost / Ground typing lets it switch into common physical threats, including Sawk, Lycanroc-N, and multiple Silvally formes. Its raw bulk also allows it to handle neutral hits well, weathering attacks from Klinklang, Rapidash, Rhydon, and more. This makes it easy for it to come in and set up entry hazards while also using Shore Up to retain its longevity. Colbur Berry makes Palossand a premier Knock Off absorber, notably letting it hard counter Sawk and Gurdurr. Rocky Helmet's chip damage makes Palossand a better check to Klinklang, as well as U-turn pivots like Uxie and the Silvally formes. Scorching Sands can be run alongside Rocky Helmet to get a burn chance, as the extra damage from the item compensates for Scorching Sands's lower power.

A variety of teams use Palossand to complete defensive cores, ranging from bulky offense to semi-stall. Defensive partners including Articuno, Appletun, and Rapidash absorb attacks from Grass-, Water-, and Ice-types, respectively. These teammates also appreciate Palossand's ability to handle hits from Rock- and Electric-types. Clerics like Miltank and Alcremie can also heal Palossand from Toxic and enjoy Palossand checking Klinklang and Lycanroc-N. Knock Off users like Sawk, Thwackey, and Gurdurr put on offensive pressure versus walls like Altaria and Articuno which Palossand is forced out by. Offensive pivots including Morpeko, Unfezant, and the Silvally formes love being able to switch out safely and bring out Palossand to defend their team against wallbreakers like Sawk and Manectric.

Pyukumuku.comments:
Other Options

Pyukumuku can sometimes forgo Block to run Rest with both Spite and Toxic. Soak lets Pyukumuku inflict Toxic poison on Steel- and Poison-types Klinklang and Silvally-Poison and helps it better take on Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Klinklang, and other Silvally formes by making them lose their STAB bonus.

Checks and Counters

Taunt: Pyukumuku is forced to use Struggle if it gets afflicted by Taunt. Taunt users like Skuntank, Alolan Persian, and Qwilfish beat Pyukumuku, but some of them should be wary of being inflicted by Toxic poison on the switch.

Substitute: Substitute users such as Rotom, Klinklang, and Articuno are major threats to Pyukumuku due to them being immune to Block and Toxic; however, PP stalling with Spite and Rest can help against them.

Electric- and Grass-types: Since Pyukumuku is weak to Grass- and Electric-type moves, Pokemon such as Rotom formes, Shiftry, and Flapple are big threats to it.

Strong Wallbreakers: Strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Sawk and Lycanroc-N 2HKO Pyukumuku.

Stored Power Users: After several Calm Minds, Alcremie, Uxie, and Swoobat can overcome Pyukumuku's Unaware with Stored Power. They also have Substitute or Rest to combat Toxic.

Unaware Wall.description:
Pyukumuku is the sole viable user of Unaware in ZU, making it a cornerstone on stall teams. Unaware allows Pyukumuku to take on setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Rhydon, non-Stored Power Alcremie, and Silvally formes. Block prevents the foe from switching and allows Pyukumuku to remove them with Toxic or PP stall with Spite. Rest removes status and helps to PP stall foes that cannot 3HKO Pyukumuku, such as Choice Scarf Sawk. Leftovers is normally preferred when entry hazard removal is prevalent on the team, while Heavy-Duty Boots may be used to help against entry hazard stacking matchups.

Pyukumuku's passive nature limits it to fitting exclusively on stall teams. Specially defensive clerics such as Clefairy and Articuno form a good core with Pyukumuku. Physically defensive Pokemon such as Altaria, Tangela, and Golbat, which can take on offensive Grass-types, make for good partners with Pyukumuku. Pokemon that can beat Electric-types such as Rotom-S and block Volt Switch such as Stunfisk are also great partners. If not running Heavy-Duty Boots, or if the item gets removed, Pyukumuku can take big damage from entry hazards and have a harder time checking Silvally-Dark and Rapidash. To avoid this, entry hazard removers such as Altaria and Articuno are essential on stall teams.

Type: Null.comments:
Other Options

A set with Iron Defense / Swords Dance / Crush Claw / Rest and an EV spread of 248 HP / 8 Def / 252 SpD is sometimes used to turn Type: Null into an unbreakable and powerful sweeper. However, this set is not consistent due to it only having Normal-type coverage and is walled by the common Ghost-types in the tier; in addition, it is passive thanks to the lack of Sleep Talk. This set also lacks the utility of the pivot set, and Type: Null also needs multiple boosts to become threatening due to its low Attack stat.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon: Type: Null is weak to Fighting, so it should be careful of Pokemon like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Strong physical wallbreakers such as Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes can muscle their way through Type: Null.

Knock Off: Any Pokemon with Knock Off is a threat, as losing Eviolite significantly decreases Type: Null's bulk.

Taunt: Taunt users such as Skuntank and Qwilfish stop Type: Null from recovering and spreading status, forcing it to pivot.

Setup Sweepers that Bypass Toxic: Setup sweepers with Substitute such as Rotom formes can freely set up in front of Type: Null. Poison- and Steel-types such as Skuntank and Klinklang, as well as Pokemon that can cure status like Spiritomb and Aromatherapy Alcremie, can also set up for free.

Entry Hazards: Although Type: Null is not weak to Stealth Rock, its lack of passive recovery and constant pivoting cause it to get easily chipped down, limiting the amount of times it can switch in and lowering its usefulness as a wall.

Defensive Pivot.description:
Type: Null acts as a solid defensive pivot in the metagame thanks to its sizable bulk with Eviolite and access to U-turn. This bulk allows it to check top-tier special wallbreakers such as Jynx, Ninetales, and Thievul. Type: Null's slow U-turn allows it to pivot and safely bring in a teammate. Toxic cripples foes and prevents Pokemon such as Rhydon, Rapidash, and Silvally formes from freely setting up in front of it. RestTalk is Type: Null's only form of recovery and lets it consistently pivot. A Sassy nature and 0 Speed IVs minimize Type: Null's Speed, allowing for the slowest U-turns.

Type: Null is a great pick for teams looking for a pivot, special wall, and status absorber condensed into one Pokemon. It pairs well with other pivots, forming a VoltTurn core. Uxie is an excellent pivot to pair with Type: Null, as it benefits from Type: Null's immunity to Ghost and ability to sponge strong special hits; in return, Uxie is able to switch into strong Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr that trouble Type: Null. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Jynx, and Sawk appreciate Type: Null's slow U-turn safely bringing them in. Although Type: Null can sponge special wallbreakers, it cannot do much damage back and is heavily dependent on pivoting into revenge killers to adequately check special sweepers. Thus, priority users like Kangaskhan and Gurdurr are necessary when dealing with foes such as Alcremie and Ivysaur. Finally, Knock Off absorbers such as Qwilfish and Silvally formes work as partners, as they prevent Type: Null from losing its Eviolite.

Silvally.comments:
Other Options

Silk Scarf feigns Choice Band, but significantly decreases the power of Silvally’s coverage moves. A fully physical Swords Dance set alongside Flame Charge allows Silvally to be a threatening late-game cleaner, though it faces significant competition with its other formes.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Physically bulky Ghost-types like Cofagrigus, Palossand, and Gourgeist formes can freely switch in against most Silvally variants. Life Orb sets with Shadow Ball can 2HKO them, however. Frailer Ghost-types like Froslass and Choice Scarf Rotom can revenge kill it but cannot handle super effective attacks. Sableye, in particular, is not hit super effectively by any of its moves and can easily wall it.

Phyiscal Walls: Physical walls like Tangela and Qwilfish can status it before whittling it down with residual damage from either Leech Seed, entry hazards, or attacks. Miltank and Alolan Persian can outpace non-Choice Scarf sets and cripple it with status or wear it down with chip damage.

Rock-types: Without Surf, Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal can switch into Silvally without much risk. They can proceed to set up Stealth Rock or whittle it down with attacks. Shell Smash users like Carracosta and Crustle can set up on it freely if Silvally is locked into the wrong move.

Steel-types: Klinklang and Pawniard resist Multi-Attack and Crunch and can beat it in a one-on-one situation. However, both are 2HKOed by Flamethrower.

Faster Pokemon: Faster Choice Scarf users like Manectric and Alolan Persian can revenge kill Choice Scarf Silvally with enough prior chip. If Silvally lacks a Choice Scarf, then Pokemon like Alolan Dugtrio, Galarian Rapidash, and Ninetales can similarly pick off Silvally with sufficient prior residual damage.

Status: Toxic wears Silvally down even faster, burns neuter its offensive capabilities, and paralysis hampers its good Speed.

Choice Scarf.description:
Silvally uses its good Speed, Attack, and coverage along with Choice Scarf to function as a solid revenge killer and offensive pivot. U-turn maintains momentum on Normal-resistant foes such as Galarian Stunfisk, Rhydon, Sableye, and Tangela. Explosion deals heavy damage to most neutral targets and prevents Defoggers like Altaria, Articuno, and Cramorant from clearing entry hazards. Crunch provides super effective damage against Ghost-types like Froslass, Rotom, and Gourgeist-S.

Silvally pairs well with pivots such as Thwackey, Articuno, and Rotom, forming VoltTurn cores to chip down the opposition. As it invites and pivots out on Rock-, Steel-, and Ghost-types such as Rhydon, Klinklang, and Rotom with U-turn, teammates that can take advantage of them like Alolan-Dugtrio and Thievul are appreciated. Similarly, physical walls like Tangela, Cofagrigus, and Palossand can switch in on Silvally without too much trouble, so special wallbreakers that can threaten them like Jynx, Thievul, and Choice Specs Exeggutor are also good partners.

Choice Band.description:
Choice Band amplifies Silvally’s wallbreaking prowess while still making it an effective pivot. U-turn allows Silvally to escape bad matchups against Pokemon like Tangela, Cofagrigus, and Sableye. Crunch hits frailer Ghost-types such as Froslass and Rotom. Flamethrower targets Tangela and Steel-types such as Klinklang and Perrserker, while Surf discourages Rock- and Ground-types like Rhydon, Palossand, and Coalossal from switching in.

Pivots like Rotom, Thwackey, and Articuno can help get Silvally onto the field safely and form VoltTurn cores. Pokemon that can deal with Rock- and Ghost-types like Tangela, Lurantis, and Alolan Persian ease the need for prediction, allowing Silvally to use its powerful Multi-Attack more freely as the game progresses. While Silvally does have coverage to discourage Rock-types and bulky Grass-types from freely switching in, it still appreciates Pokemon that can switch into them, such as Tangela and Altaria. In return, Silvally can threaten slower wallbreakers like Skuntank and Exeggutor. Physical attackers like Sawk, Rapidash, and Alolan Dugtrio appreciate Silvally weakening physical walls for them.

Mixed Attacker.description:
With either Swords Dance or Work Up, Silvally becomes an imposing physical or mixed attacker thanks to its diverse coverage choices. Flamethrower hits Klinklang and Pawniard super effectively, preventing them from safely switching in. Crunch hits Rotom and Froslass, while Shadow Ball targets physically defensive Ghost-types like Cofagrigus, Palossand, and Gourgeist formes. However, opting for Shadow Ball encourages Silvally to run Work Up to boost the power of all its coverage moves. Surf targets Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal. Life Orb boosts all of Silvally's attacks at the cost of wearing it down whenever it attacks.

Silvally appreciates other wallbreakers like Sawk or Skuntank spreading chip damage and providing Knock Off utility, as even at +1, it can have difficulty securing KOs on defensive Pokemon like Stunfisk and Altaria. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Miltank and Rhydon can help rack up residual damage, letting Silvally more easily set up as the game progresses. Due to Silvally's four-moveslot syndrome, Pokemon that can cover specific threats are appreciated to make it as difficult to wall as possible. If Silvally decides to run Shadow Ball or Crunch for the last moveslot, Water- and Grass-types like Poliwrath and Kabutops would be appreciated to handle Rock-types. However, if Surf is chosen, Pokemon to deal with Ghost-types like Rotom and Froslass, such as Throh and Qwilfish, are appreciated.

Silvally-Bug.overview: Despite Silvally-Bug's decent stats, its horrific defensive typing and useless item and ability make it completely outclassed. Other Silvally formes like Silvally-Dark and Silvally-Poison have better offensive and defensive utility by virtue of their superior typings. Crustle serves as a much better Bug-type physical sweeper thanks to its access to Shell Smash and Knock Off and additional Rock STAB. Silvally-Bug also suffers from being unable to fit all of its desired coverage and being terribly weak to entry hazards without being able to run Heavy-Duty Boots.

Swords Dance.description: Silvally-Bug can attempt to leverage its decent bulk, Speed, and power to clean late-game and use its coverage to overwhelm the opposition. Due to its atrocious typing, vulnerability to residual damage, and awkward coverage choices, it is outclassed as a Bug-type physical sweeper by Crustle, which has Smell Smash, Knock Off, and additional STAB in Rock.

Silvally-Dark.comments:
Other Options

X-Scissor is an option over U-turn for a stronger move to threaten opposing Dark-types. Toxic can be used to cripple physical walls such as Tangela and Pyukumuku, but it makes Silvally-Dark less effective at wallbreaking. Defog provides role compression, and it is a niche option on certain teams. A bulkier Swords Dance with RestTalk replacing its coverage options can set up on passive foes like Miltank and defensive Qwilfish more easily at the cost of making it more passive itself.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Although they do not appreciate U-turn, Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank can take Multi-Attack from Silvally-Dark and threaten it back with status or a powerful hit.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Sawk, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr are able to take Multi-Attack and pressure back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr can also revenge kill Silvally-Dark with Mach Punch, even after it has set up; Choice Scarf Sawk can similarly revenge kill it due to outspeeding it. However, all Fighting-types should be wary of +2 Psychic Fangs.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Alcremie, Clefairy, and Galarian Rapidash can threaten Silvally-Dark with their STAB options, but they have to watch out for Iron Head variants.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers such as Alolan Dugtrio, Rapidash, and Froslass can outspeed and threaten Silvally-Dark. Pokemon with priority moves such as Kangaskhan and Thwackey can similarly KO it once it has been weakened enough.

Swords Dance Sweeper.description:
Silvally-Dark finds a niche in ZU as a powerful setup sweeper, capable of setting up with Swords Dance and utilizing its Multi-Attack to threaten prominent Pokemon such as Froslass, Palossand, and Rotom. However, it faces competition from other Silvally formes. U-turn allows Silvally-Dark to function as an early-game pivot and lets it weaken Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, while Flame Charge allows it to outspeed revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Rotom. Psychic Fangs can threaten Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and Sawk, while Iron Head weakens Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Galarian Rapidash.

Silvally-Dark fits best on offensive teams as an early-game pivot that can wallbreak with its powerful Multi-Attack. If running Flame Charge, Silvally-Dark should be preserved for late-game, when it can set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge and sweep. Silvally-Dark has trouble with Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, so checks to them such as Alcremie and Piloswine, respectively, are appreciated. Checks to Fighting-types such as Choice Scarf Rotom, Qwilfish, and the aforementioned Alcremie are also appreciated, with Rotom forming a VoltTurn core with Silvally-Dark and Qwilfish providing Spikes support, weakening foes such as Qwilfish into the range of +2 Multi-Attack. As Silvally-Dark lacks recovery, entry hazard removal from the likes of Cryogonal and Cramorant is necessary to keep Silvally-Dark healthy to keep pivoting with U-turn. Memento support from Uxie can help Silvally-Dark more easily set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge.

Silvally-Electric.comments:
Other Options

Silvally-Electric has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Stunfisk is the best of the Ground-types to counter Silvally-Electric, being 4HKOed by Silvally-Electric's coverage moves. Rhydon and Piloswine also work well to check Silvally-Electric, however both need to be vary of switching into Surf. Alolan Dugtrio outspeeds Silvally-Electric and OHKOes with Earthquake, but also cannot switch into Surf.

Bulky Foes: Miltank can comfortably tank any of Silvally-Electric's attacks and can chip it down with Seismic Toss or stall it out with Toxic. Alcremie can also survive Silvally-Electric's attacks relatively easily and can boost up alongside Silvally-Electric's Work up with Acid Armor and Calm Mind.

Faster Threats: Choice Scarf Sawk and Rotom can outspeed and revenge kill Silvally-Electric. Naturally faster Pokemon such as Froslass and Rapidash can also revenge kill once its chipped down into range.

Mixed Wallbreaker.description:
Silvally-Electric functions as a solid mixed wallbreaker thanks to its great coverage breaking down common Fire / Water / Grass cores. Multi-Attack is Silvally strongest STAB move with no drawbacks, hitting specially bulky Pokemon such as Articuno and Clefairy harder than Thunderbolt. Surf targets Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Alolan Dugtrio, and Ice Beam provides coverage against Altaria, Tangela, and Thwackey. Flamethrower can be used to hit Shedinja, Klinklang, and the aforementioned Grass-types, at the cost of not being able to hit Altaria as hard. Work Up allows Silvally-Electric to boost pass walls such as Clefairy, Miltank, and Alcremie depending on their sets.

Silvally-Electric fits best on balance teams that can use its wallbreaking prowess to break down opposing cores on balance builds. Stunfisk can be problematic for Silvally-Electric, as Ice Beam and Surf only 4HKO it. Skuntank and Choice Scarf Rotom can help wear down Stunfisk as well as cripple it with Corrosive Gas and Trick, respectively. Thwackey can also pressure Stunfisk and also pivot in Silvally-Electric safety. In return, Silvally-Electric threatens out Pokemon that wall Thwackey such as Tangela and Altaria. Switch-ins to Ground-types Rhydon, Piloswine, and Alolan Dugtrio are needed, so teammates like Tangela, Poliwrath, and Miltank fit well to help cover them.

Silvally-Fighting.comments:
Other Options

A fully physical Swords Dance set alongside Flame Charge and either Iron Head or Psychic Fangs makes Silvally-Fighting a late-game sweeper. At +2, a healthy Silvally-Fighting can lure in and defeat Alcremie with Iron Head, something other Fighting-types like Sawk cannot do, though this set can't beat defensive Pokemon like Qwilfish, Tangela, and Altaria. This set also faces tough competition from other Silvally formes due to their better offensive or defensive typings.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Alcremie and Clefairy do not take much damage from any of Silvally-Fighting's attacks and can freely set up on it, forcing it to switch. Galarian Rapidash can use it as setup fodder and heal damage inflicted with Morning Sun.

Bulky Pokemon: Articuno, Stunfisk, and Uxie don't take much damage from even Silvally-Fighting's super effective coverage attacks, with the former healing off damage with Roost, though Stunfisk and Uxie lack reliable recovery.

Ghost-types: Spiritomb can switch into any of Silvally-Fighting's attacks with impunity and use it as setup fodder. More offensive Ghost-types, like Rotom and Gourgeist-S, are immune to its STAB move and can revenge kill it with prior damage, though they can't repeatedly switch into Silvally-Fighting's coverage.

Faster Pokemon: With some chip damage, faster Pokemon like Manectric, Ninetales, and Galarian Rapidash can revenge kill Silvally-Fighting, though they do not want to directly switch into any of its attacks.

BoltBeam Pivot.description:
Silvally-Fighting is an excellent mixed wallbreaker and pivot thanks to its typing and movepool beating common Silvally checks, Defoggers, and entry hazard setters like Rhydon, Altaria, and Qwilfish in one teamslot. U-turn maintains momentum and chips bulkier checks like Alcremie, Stunfisk, and Articuno. Thunderbolt 2HKOes Qwilfish and 3HKOes Poliwrath, while Ice Beam targets Tangela, Altaria, and Gourgeist-S. These coverage moves allow Silvally-Fighting to beat common Fighting-type checks that would otherwise switch in safely.

Silvally-Fighting fits well on VoltTurn teams thanks to its good Speed tier, bulk, and coverage against defensive staples like Cramorant, Qwilfish, and Alolan Persian. Fast and slow pivots like Rotom formes, Type: Null, and Uxie chip down checks like Articuno, Stunfisk, and Rotom. Silvally-Fighting heavily struggles to break through Fairy-types and generally bulky Pokemon like Articuno or Stunfisk without support, so partners that can take these Pokemon on, like Alolan Dugtrio and Piloswine, can help it pivot more easily. In return, Silvally-Fighting can take on bulky staples weak to its coverage, like Tangela and Poliwrath, which the aforementioned Steel-types struggle against. Checks to Rotom and Gourgeist-S, such as Stunfisk and Sap Sipper Miltank, are appreciated. Stunfisk and Miltank can use Toxic to wear down checks to Silvally-Fighting, like Articuno and opposing Stunfisk. Miltank can provide cleric support to alleviate Silvally-Fighting's vulnerability to residual damage.

Silvally-Flying.comments:
Other Options

Silvally-Flying has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-type Pokemon such as Rotom, Manectric, and Stunfisk resist Multi-Attack and can force Silvally-Flying out with their own STAB attacks. Choice Scarf Manectric is especially notable, outspeeding Silvally-Flying after a Flame Charge.

Rock-types: Rock-type Pokemon such as Rhydon, Coalossal, and Kabutops resist Multi-Attack and can threaten Silvally-Flying back. Rhydon and Coalossal can only check it, however, as they cannot switch into Surf.

Steel-types: Steel-type Pokemon such as Klinklang, and Alolan Dugtrio resist Multi-Attack. Silvally-Flying can break through them with Flame Charge after a Swords Dance boost, though.

Ice-types: Ice-type Pokemon such as Jynx and Articuno can check Silvally-Flying with their super effective STAB attacks. However, Jynx needs a Choice Scarf to be a consistent check. Piloswine, on the other hand, can easily take a hit and retaliate with Icicle Crash or just threaten it with a priority Ice Shard.

Swords Dance.description:
Silvally-Flying carves its niche out in ZU as a strong setup sweeper and wallbreaker. Its powerful STAB Multi-Attack especially threatens Pokemon such as Tangela and Throh. Flame Charge enables Silvally-Flying to outspeed revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Rotom, Sawk, and Kabutops. U-turn allows it to retain momentum against Pokemon that handle its attacks like Kabutops. Surf is the coverage move of choice, allowing Silvally-Flying to 2HKO Rhydon and Coalossal.

Silvally-Flying fits well on offense teams as a late-game sweeper, although it can function as a standalone wallbreaker too. Unfezant and Nasty Plot Rotom-S can aid Silvally-Flying by forming an offensive Flying-type spam core, wearing down shared checks and physical walls such as Rhydon, Qwillfish, and Miltank. This core, however, makes the team very weak to Stealth Rock, so it's important to have entry hazard removers such as Kabutops and Rotom. Hattrem is also a great partner, preventing Stealth Rock thanks to Magic Bounce and providing Healing Wish, which is great for offensive teams. Electric-type foes that threaten Silvally-Flying such as Rotom and Manectric can be covered by Stealth Rock setters in Rhydon and Piloswine. Fire-type Pokemon such as Rapidash and Ninetales can help cover the Ice weakness, in addition to Steel-types like Klinklang. Neither covers these weaknesses perfectly, however, due to Alolan Dugtrio and Piloswine threatening them out. A bulky Water-type such as Poliwrath fill in these gaps. Pokemon such as Sawk, Rotom, and Thwackey appreciate wallbreaking from Silvally-Flying opening up a path for a late-game sweep.

Silvally-Grass.comments:
Other Options

Flamethrower deals more damage to Grass-resistant Pokemon like Klinklang, Tangela, and Ivysaur, but losing Flame Charge worsens Silvally-Grass's cleaning potential.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types like Tangela, Gourgeist-S, and Lurantis can freely switch into all of Silvally-Grass's standard attacks and can whittle it down with their own. All of them can heal damage off with their recovery moves, with Tangela gaining additional recovery with Regenerator.

Poison-types: Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Skuntank, and Ivysaur resist Multi-Attack and can heavily threaten Silvally-Grass with their STAB attacks. While Qwilfish is neutral to Multi-Attack, it can cripple Silvally-Grass with Thunder Wave or chip it with entry hazards and Rocky Helmet.

Fire-types: Rapidash and Ninetales can outspeed Silvally-Grass and revenge kill it. Coalossal can cripple it with Flame Body. All of them dislike switching into a boosted Rock Slide, however.

Sap Sipper Pokemon: Miltank and Bouffalant can switch in comfortably against any of Silvally-Grass's moves and proceed to wear it down with status or attack it directly.

Faster Pokemon: While Silvally-Grass has good bulk and Speed, it can be picked off by naturally faster Pokemon like Accelgor, Froslass, and Rapidash, as well as Choice Scarf users like Sawk, Rotom, and Alolan Persian.

Swords Dance.description:
Silvally-Grass serves as a decent cleaner thanks to beating Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Palossand, all common Silvally checks. Rock Slide nails Flying-types like Articuno, Altaria, and Golbat that would comfortably switch into Multi-Attack. Flame Charge increases Silvally-Grass's cleaning potential, with it outpacing Rapidash, Accelgor, and Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom after a boost. Flame Charge also is its this set's strongest move against some Grass-resistant Pokemon like Klinklang and Ivysaur.

Silvally-Grass fits nicely on hyper offense teams looking for a Water-, Ground-, and Grass-resistant sweeper. Specially offensive wallbreakers and cleaners such as Lunatone, Skuntank, and Rotom work well with it, taking advantage of their typing or power to force out the walls Silvally-Grass struggles with, gaining setup opportunities. In return, Silvally-Grass can break through special walls like Articuno and Cryogonal. Before a boost, faster Pokemon like Froslass, Rapidash, and Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Jynx can revenge kill it without too much trouble. Teammates like Piloswine, Alcremie, and Articuno that can switch into them and threaten them off. Other physical attackers like Swords Dance Rapidash and Lycanroc-N can weaken Grass-type checks like Tangela and Ivysaur so Silvally-Grass can sweep late-game. Tangela is particularly difficult to deal with; Knock Off users like Sawk and Uxie can make progress and make it easier to deal with later on.

Silvally-Ice.overview: Silvally-Ice's good offensive typing, all-around stats, and movepool are let down by its abysmal defensive utility, as well as its fixed item and ability. These factors cause it to get worn down quickly by residual damage, which includes Stealth Rock, and make it very difficult to switch in safely. Silvally-Ice also faces overwhelming competition as a setup sweeper from its other formes, such as Silvally-Dark and Silvally-Poison, both of which have better typings to be overall better offensively and defensively.

Swords Dance.description: Silvally-Ice can use its good coverage and stats to try to clean mid- or late-game, forcing out Pokemon like Altaria, Tangela, and Stunfisk. However, its vulnerability to all entry hazards and terrible defensive utility make it difficult to pull off a sweep with it. Silvally formes like Silvally-Dark and Silvally-Poison can both do the same thing but better because of their superior typings.

Silvally-Poison.comments:
Other Options

Ice Beam is an option over Surf for mixed sets, allowing Silvally-Poison to OHKO Altaria while keeping neutral coverage on the whole tier bar Piloswine when paired with Thunderbolt. However, this leaves Silvally-Poison far less consistent versus Ground- and Rock-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Coalossal. Parting Shot can be used over U-turn on Defog sets, but U-turn's damage is often preferred and Klinklang's Clear Body would prevent Silvally-Poison from freely pivoting. Surf and Thunderbolt are options over U-turn and Flame Charge on Swords Dance Silvally-Poison, giving it better coverage. Grass Pledge is a coverage move hitting Ground-types like Rhydon and Stunfisk while still hitting Water-types like Kabutops and Qwilfish, but it is signficantly weaker than Surf + Thunderbolt.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Even if carrying Surf, Silvally-Poison needs to heavily weaken Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Stunfisk before sweeping.

Rotom: Rotom resists Silvally-Poison's STAB Multi-Attack and can threaten it back with its STAB moves or a burn with Will-O-Wisp. However, sets without Choice Scarf get outspeed by Silvally-Poison and are quickly put in range of a +1 Surf.

Qwilfish: If Silvally-Poison isn't running Thunderbolt, it gets hard walled by Qwilfish, which can cripple it with paralysis and chip it down with Rocky Helmet damage.

Rock-types: If Silvally-Poison doesn't carry Surf, it can't significantly damage Coalossal and risks a Flame Body burn with its contact moves. On the other hand, if it does not have Thunderbolt, it struggles with Kabutops, which can hit it hard.

Mixed Walls: Very bulky Pokemon like Altaria, Miltank, and Uxie can stomach Silvally-Poison's hits and heavily damage it with their repeated attacks, even if Silvally-Poison can break through them after several boosts.

Steel-types: If Silvally-Poison isn't using Flamethrower, it can't really deal damage to Klinklang, and it can significantly weaken Silvally-Poison with its powerful STAB moves.

Faster Attackers: Pokemon like Froslass, Alolan Persian, and Rapidash outspeed Silvally-Poison and can 2HKO it while avoiding an OHKO from it.

Work Up.description:
Work Up Silvally-Poison is a powerful mixed attacker thanks to its great bulk and coveted Poison typing, which let it take advantage of common threats like Alcremie and Thwackey. Flamethrower lets Silvally-Poison 2HKO Tangela and OHKO Steel-types like Klinklang after a boost. Thunderbolt is an alternative for massive damage to Qwilfish, Kabutops, and Cramorant, the former resisting every other move Silvally-Poison commonly runs. Surf removes Ground- and Rock-types like Piloswine, Rhydon, and Coalossal after chip damage, as well as beating Rapidash without risking a burn from Flame Body.

Since Silvally-Poison misses a lot of OHKOs after a Work Up, it works better as a mid- or late-game wallbreaker, so it appreciates early-game wallbreakers like Black Belt Sawk and Thwackey weakening walls and removing their items with Knock Off. Rotom formes make for great partners, weakening Ground-types with Will-O-Wisp and their secondary STAB moves so Silvally-Poison can OHKO them later with Surf. Furthermore, most Electric-types like Rotom, Stunfisk, and Manectric can force in Grass-types like Thwackey and Tangela for Silvally-Poison to take advantage of. That said, Tangela can put it to sleep with Sleep Powder on the switch, so Silvally-Poison should be careful setting up versus it. These Electric-types also take care of Steel-types for Silvally-Poison. Defensive pivots like Uxie, Clefairy, and Tangela are appreciated to switch into revenge killers like Froslass and Choice Scarf Sawk or defensive checks like Stunfisk and Miltank, in addition to providing it switch-in opportunities.

Defog.description:
Silvally-Poison makes a good pivot with its great bulk and useful set of resistances letting it check attackers like Sawk and Thwackey. It is also one of the few Pokemon packing both a pivoting move and entry hazard removal, bringing great role compression. Surf lets it threaten common hazard setters such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Coalossal, while Thunderbolt hits Qwilfish, another premier Spikes setter.

Silvally-Poison's key defensive utility, along with its pivoting, makes it a premier choice for VoltTurn teams. As a result, other staples of this archetype like Alolan Persian, Rotom, and Articuno make for great partners to consistently chip the opposing team. Thwackey is a particularly noticeable partner, forcing in Grass-types such as Shiinotic and Tangela, which Silvally-Poison takes advantage of, and providing Grassy Terrain support, negating Silvally-Poison's weakness to Earthquake and providing it passive recovery. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Arctovish, and Jynx love getting safe switch-in opportunities from pivoting moves, and Silvally-Poison can switch into their checks like Sawk and Thwackey.

Swords Dance.description:
Swords Dance Silvally-Poison doubles up as an offensive pivot and late-game cleaner. U-turn allows it to generate momentum and chip its checks like Rhydon and Alolan Persian early-game. Flame Charge lets it outspeed common Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom, and it also provides coverage for Steel-types like Klinklang.

This set fits better on offensive teams due to how immediately threatening it is. It appreciates Pokemon able to take advantage of Rock-, Ground-, and Steel-types such as Thwackey, Poliwrath, and Sawk, which help it sweep late-game, while they enjoy Silvally-Poison forcing these checks in. Offensive pivots like Rotom, Articuno, and Klinklang make for great partners, forming VoltTurn cores with Silvally-Poison. Thievul is a noticeable partner that can heavily weaken physically bulky foes like Rhydon and Miltank, opening the way for a Silvally-Poison sweep, while in return Silvally-Poison can take advantage of the Fighting- and Fairy-types such as Sawk and Alcremie that Thievul forces in.

Silvally-Psychic.comments:
Other Options

Silvally-Psychic has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-type Pokemon such as Alolan Persian, Morpeko, and Skuntank can all threaten Silvally-Psychic with their STAB attacks while being immune to Multi-Attack. In addition, Alolan Persian deters Swords Dance thanks to Foul Play, making it a very consistent counter.

Ghost-types: Ghost-type Pokemon such as Gourgeist-S and Rotom can revenge kill Silvally-Psychic with their STAB attacks. Choice Scarf Gourgeist-S is especially notable, outspeeding Silvally-Psychic even after a Flame Charge.

Steel-types: Steel-type Pokemon such as Klingklang and Alolan Dugtrio easily take most of Silvally-Psychic’s attacks and hit hard back. However, Silvally-Psychic can break through them with Flame Charge after a Swords Dance boost.

*Physical Walls: Miltank, Rhydon, and Tangela can often trade hits with Silvally-Psychic thanks to their great bulk. However, they are threatened by a boosted Multi-Attack.

Swords Dance.description:
Silvally-Psychic acts as a powerful offensive pivot, wallbreaker, and late-game cleaner, threatening common walls such as Qwilfish, Throh, and Poliwrath; however, being vulnerable to Sucker Punch and faster Ghost-types in Choice Scarf Rotom and Gourgeist-S limits its sweeping capabilities. Silvally-Psychic is also often outclassed by better Silvally formes with more desirable types such as Dark and Poison. Flame Charge allows Silvally-Psychic to outspeed Alolan Persian and Choice Scarf users, such as Sawk and Rotom, while also providing coverage for Steel-types such as Klinklang and Alolan Dugtrio. U-turn retains momentum and weakens its checks such as Alolan-Persian, Skuntank, and Uxie. X-Scissor provides coverage for the aforementioned Dark- and Psychic-types and hits harder than U-turn while also not forcing Silvally-Psychic out after it sets up.

Silvally-Psychic fits best on offense teams, where it can break through Fighting-type foes such Gurdurr, Throh, and Poliwrath. Removing them allows Steel- and Normal-types such as Klingklang and Kangaskhan to wreck havoc. Dark-types such as Alolan Persian, Spiritomb, and Skuntank are problematic, so checks to them such as Alcremie and Rhydon are welcomed, as are Dark- and Ghost-type teammates like Skuntank and Gourgeist-S to draw in and chip these threats. Opposing Ghost-types such as Choice Scarf Rotom and Gourgeist-S can revenge kill Silvally-Psychic, so checks to them including Rhydon and Miltank and are appreciated.

Silvally-Water.comments:
Other Options

Silvally-Water has no viable other options.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Manectric, Morpeko, and Choice Scarf Rotom all outspeed Silvally-Water and threaten it with their STAB attacks. They all need to be wary of switching in, however, due to their frail nature.

Grass-types: Offensive Grass-types like Thwackey and Gourgeist-S can nail Silvally-Water with their super effective STAB moves before it can attack. Defensive Grass-types like Gourgeist-XL and Tangela can wall it with ease.

Special Walls: Articuno, Clefairy, and Alcremie can all switch into Silvally-Water's special moves with ease and pivot out into the aforementioned Grass- and Electric-type checks. They can also stall Silvally-Water out with Toxic and recovery moves.

Physical Walls: The likes of Miltank, Sableye, and Altaria can easily take on Swords Dance sets and can afford to scout Silvally-Water's set by taking a special attack.

Residual Damage: Unlike most entry hazard removal options, Silvally-Water isn't protected from taking entry hazard damage due to its mandatory held item and lack of recovery. This can give it a bit of trouble in long games and forces it to try to come in when minimal layers of hazards are up. It also doesn't enjoy status like poison or burn adding onto this residual damage.

Defog.description:
Silvally-Water can serve a support role when running a Defog set. Its stats and great defensive typing allow it to stifle strong physically offensive Pokemon such as Klinklang, Rapidash, and Qwilfish. Surf can be utilized over Multi-Attack to deal with physically defensive Ground-types. Thunderbolt is great coverage to hit opposing Water-types such as the aforementioned Qwilfish as well as Poliwrath and Cramorant. Its slow U-turn and good bulk can help provide some chip damage while bringing in its teammates safely. With Water + Electric coverage, Silvally-Water has a favorable matchup into the top entry hazard setters in the tier.

Defog Silvally-Water can fit well on bulky offense team styles looking for an entry hazard removal option that can keep up the pressure. It can pair well with the likes of Rapidash, Skuntank, and Klinklang to help deal with Grass-types that it invites in. Also, Pokemon such as Rhydon and Morpeko can help deal with the Electric-types that check Silvally-Water. With its physically defensive build, Silvally-Water can struggle against hard-hitting special attackers; specially defensive walls such as Clefairy, Articuno, and Stunfisk make for great teammates to combat this issue. Also, Pokemon that outspeed popular threats to Silvally-Water can help force them out or take them down when the former are brought in by U-turn; these include Alolan Persian, Rapidash, Jynx, and any fast Pokemon that covers the weaknesses mentioned above. Silvally-Water can help form a great VoltTurn core with the likes of Rotom and Manectric, as they can help put on pressure by covering each other's weaknesses.

Swords Dance.description:
Silvally-Water serves as a niche physical wallbreaker sporting a Swords Dance set. Psychic Fangs is a great coverage move for dealing with common Water-resistant walls such as Qwilfish, Roselia, and Poliwrath. Bug-type coverage helps with Grass-types that resist Multi-Attack, such as Appletun, Thwackey, and Lurantis. U-turn lets Silvally-Water pivot and chip its checks like Altaria and Gourgeist formes, while X-Scissor is more useful for facilitating a sweep.

Swords Dance Silvally-Water fits best in bulky offense teams looking for a physical Water-type wallbreaker. Grass-type checks such as Tangela, Rapidash, and Skuntank can take advantage of the Grass-types that Silvally-Water invites in. Similarly, Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine are appreciated to cover Electric-types like Rotom and Manectric. Special wallbreakers like Thievul, Jynx, and Exeggutor can take advantage of the physical walls that Silvally-Water forces in, especially if Silvally-Water can provide safe switch-ins for them with U-turn.

Special Attacker.description:
Thanks to Silvally-Water's solid defensive typing and great BoltBeam coverage, it is a special attacker in ZU. Thunderbolt is great at targeting opposing Water-types such as Qwilfish, Poliwrath, and Cramorant. Ice beam strikes Grass-types such as Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S hard. Flamethrower can be used to hit Klinklang harder while still targeting the aforementioned Grass-types, but it leaves Silvally-Water unable to hit Altaria hard. U-turn allows Silvally-Water to pivot out of unfavorable matchups such as Articuno, Clefairy, and Type: Null while retaining momentum.

Silvally-Water fits well on bulky offense and balance teams looking for a Water-type that provides bulk while also keeping up pressure and momentum. It also fits within VoltTurn cores, so staples such as Uxie, Rotom, and Thwackey work as great partners to help chip down the opposing team. Strong physical wallbreakers such as Lycanroc-N, Klinklang, and Sawk also work well as teammates, taking advantage of Silvally-Water's pivoting on special walls such as Articuno, Clefairy, and Type: Null. As Silvally-Water is vulnerable to faster Electric- and Grass-type attacks, Eject Pack Appletun can help cover them while keeping up momentum. Further switch-ins to Grass-types include Rapidash, Tangela, and Altaria with Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Manectric being switch-ins for Electric-types.

Thwackey.comments:
Other Options

Drain Punch is an option on Swords Dance sets, super effectively hitting Steel-types like Klinklang as well as Sap Sipper Bouffalant and Miltank. However, due to its low Base Power and the importance of Knock Off and U-turn for Thwackey's offensive pivot role, it is often not worth using. Terrain Extender is an option if paired with other Grassy Glide users like Flapple, Trevenant, and Gourgeist-S. However, teams built around Grassy Terrain are quite bad due to having few other ways to maximize the Terrain.

Checks and Counters
